<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="BBHUUX7DD108">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">May 06, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.4 </span>CONSULTANT SERVICES CONTRACT WITH MEAD &amp; HUNT FOR CONSTRUCTION ADMINISTRATION SERVICES FOR TAXIWAY G RECONSTRUCTION PROJECT IN THE AMOUNT OF $592,204.85</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Recommended Action</div>
<div class="rightcol">- Move to authorize staff to execute contract with Mead &amp; Hunt in the amount of $592,204.85 for construction administration services associated with the Taxiway G Reconstruction Project.</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW934Y6FE44C"><div class="name">Goal #2 - Customer Service</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOHN BARSALOU - AIRPORT DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City contract with Mead &amp; Hunt to provide construction administration services for the Taxiway G Reconstruction Project?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The Airport and the FAA have identified Taxiway G, the primary parallel taxiway to Runway 14-32, for a full length rehabilitation due to a majority of the taxiway having a Pavement Condition Rating (PCR) of "Very Poor".&nbsp; The rehabilitation of Taxiway G will include a new asphalt surface, new pavement markings, replacement of 12' of asphalt millings shoulders, construction of under drains, replacement of edge lighting cable, edge lights, airfield guidance signs and relocation of Runway 32 secondary windcone.&nbsp; On September 17, 2018 Council approved a contract with Mead &amp; Hunt for the design of the Taxiway G Reconstruction Project in the amount of $538,307.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The project will begin construction upon award of the construction contract by Council and once the Airport receives an Airport Improvement Project (AIP) grant funding from the FAA.&nbsp; The project is scheduled to take 180 days to complete and the Airport proposes to utilize Mead &amp; Hunt to provide the services to manage the project during construction.&nbsp;&nbsp;The services will consist of pre-construction services, construction administration, resident engineering and post-construction services necessary to meet FAA requirements for a project funded with AIP funds.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Scope of Work for their proposed construction administration services was reviewed and approved by the FAA.&nbsp; The fee for their proposed services has undergone an Independent Fee Estimate (IFE) by a neutral third party and&nbsp;the two&nbsp;fees were&nbsp;within 2.7%&nbsp;of each other,&nbsp;well within the allowed 10% variance.&nbsp; As with all&nbsp;approved costs associated with the Taxiway G Reconstruction Project, the FAA will fund 93.75% of the contract cost with the Airport providing the&nbsp;required 6.25% matching funds.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve&nbsp;the proposed&nbsp;contract with Mead &amp; Hunt.</li>
	<li>Reject&nbsp;the proposed&nbsp;contract with Mead &amp; Hunt and direct staff to seek a modification to the Scope of Work from the FAA and renegotiate&nbsp;the contract with Mead &amp; Hunt.</li>
	<li>Reject the proposed contract with Mead &amp; Hunt.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>A FAA Airport Improvement Project (AIP) program grant will fund 93.75% ($555,192) of the contract with a local match of 6.25% ($37,013) from budgeted Airport funds completing the total funding needed.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>- Mead &amp; Hunt</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Draft Contract with Mead &amp; Hunt</p>
</div>

<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p>Consent Agenda. If pulled and questions presented, Mayor Westfall to answer.</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="BA2PYD6047CB">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Apr 15, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.1 </span>AMENDMENT OF CONTRACT WITH HDR, INC. FOR EXTENDED OWNER’S REPRESENTATIVE SERVICES AND ADDITIONAL PROJECT SUPPORT SERVICES FOR THE SPRING STREET SEWAGE TREATMENT PLANT UPGRADE PROJECT IN THE AMOUNT OF $327,025</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Recommended Action</div>
<div class="rightcol">- Move to authorize a contract amendment with HDR, Inc. for extended owner’s representative services and additional project support services for the Spring Street Sewage Treatment Plant Upgrade Project in the amount of $327,025.</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;RAY BUSCH - WATER RECOVERY DIVISION MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;<span style="font-size: 11px;"><span style="font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="line-height: 115%;"><span new="" roman="" times="">Should the City amend our existing contract with HDR, Inc. for <span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">extended owner’s representative services and additional project support services for the Spring Street Sewage Treatment Plant Upgrade Project.</span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">The City of Klamath Falls owns and operates the Spring Street Sewage Treatment Plant (STP) and discharges treated wastewater effluent into Lake Ewauna under the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination (NPDES) permit last issued in 1990 by the State of Oregon’s Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ). Delays in the issuance of total maximum daily limits (TMDL), and the associated waste load allocations (WLAs) by DEQ has caused the City to delay major upgrades to its treatment plant as uncertainty remained about the final TMDL and WLA ruling.</span></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">Despite the delays and uncertainty regarding the regulatory drivers, the City has continued to take the necessary steps to plan for the needed upgrades and improvements to the aging facilities at the Spring Street STP. Some key steps taken so far to move the City forward to make those upgrades and improvements include:</span></span></p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">Spring Street Sewage Treatment Plant Facilities Plan (December 2009)</span></span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">Secured funding through Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ), Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF) program (November 2011, amended January 2016)</span></span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">Beginning in 2009, the City Council approved a series of sewer rate increases to ensure that sufficient funding would be available to address continued rehabilitation and improvements to the City’s wastewater infrastructure. After enacting several large increases to rates, the City Council opted to hold off on future increases until the full cost of the plant was understood.</span></span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">The City Council approved Resolution 16-01 (January 2016) granting an exemption from the competitive bid requirements for use of the design-build method of contracting for the Spring Street Sewage Treatment Plant Progressive Design/Build Project. This alternative progressive design/build delivery option will provide a more collaborative approach to the complex design process, will be more cost effective and will shorten the overall design and construction process. </span></span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">Awarded a contract with HDR to be the Owner’s representative handling the bulk of the project management tasks.</span></span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">Awarded a contract with Slayden Constructors, Inc. for Phase 1A&nbsp;</span><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">(an extensive discovery and exploratory process to develop a design concept to provide the best long-term value to the City). A subsequent amendment (Phase 1A1) led to cost reductions and refinement of the estimated design and construction costs.</span></span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">Awarded a contract with Slayden Constructors, Inc. for Phase 2 design services.</span></span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">Nearly completed 100% design efforts for the construction of the Spring Street Sewage Treatment Plant Upgrade Project.</span></span></li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">Most entities, unless they are large and, consequently well-staffed, do not have the resources or experience necessary to manage a construction project of this scale and complexity. To address this shortcoming, and to ensure a successful and cost-effective outcome, owners, like the City, will generally contract with an independent, third-party firm, such as an owner's representative, to fill that gap. This strategy is particularly necessary for today’s wastewater projects which have to take into consideration not only building or rehabilitating structures that have to last 50-75 years, but facilities that also have to have operational flexibility that is adaptable to the variabilities of wastewater systems and can respond effectively to the continuous changes in regulatory standards. The City’s owners representative (owner's rep), in partnership with City staff, acts as the City’s primary project manager on the project and, because of their strong experience and industry knowledge, the owner's rep is able to provide City staff with a range of focused assistance throughout the design, procurement and construction phases. HDR has been providing Owner’s Representative services to the City in support of this project since the execution of the original contract on June 3, 2016</span></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">The reason for this amendment is due to the following factors:</span></span></p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">There is a need for extended Owner’s representative services as the original construction phase of the project (upon execution of HDR’s contract with the City) was assumed to be 18-months. The current estimated construction duration is 24-months.</span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">The State Revolving Funds (SRF) loan has added new requirements since the original loan was initiated. These requirements include a significant level of effort to complete a thorough Environmental Review Update, an Endangered Species Act Compliance evaluation, and a Cultural Resources Survey.</span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">The original schedule for this project (upon execution of HDR’s contract with the City) was assumed to begin on January 31, 2017 and be completed (including construction) December 3, 2018. The execution of this project has resulted in an estimated construction completion date of March 25, 2021. This is an increase in the overall schedule of approximately 28 months. This amendment increases the level of effort required for HDR to continue supporting the project through completion at the end of March 2021.</span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">The development of the new N.P.D.E.S. permit has begun and is very complex. There is a need for HDR to continue to</span> <span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">provide technical and administrative support in coordinating with Oregon DEQ regarding the City’s new (NPDES) permit. This support will include: review of historical data related to influent and effluent characteristics, development of compliance strategies related to anticipated permit limits, and written correspondence with DEQ regarding HDR’s interpretation of permitting related data and recommendations for pending permit limits.</span></li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">This amendment is intended to modify HDR’s scope of work to more accurately reflect the work performed to date and HDR’s anticipated efforts for completion of the project.</span></p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) support with continued design support services are estimated to be $87,716. This task was originally scheduled to be negotiated in October 2017. It will now be negotiated sometime in the second quarter of 2019.</span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">Extension of administration and project support through March 2021 is estimated to be $100,924 (based at an average billing rate of $3,500 /month for an extra 28 months).</span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">Oregon DEQ permitting support is estimated to be $49,526</span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">Environmental Review $88,860</span></li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">This additional work is estimated to take 1,767 hours. The total cost of this owner’s representative services amendment is $327,025.</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 6pt;"><span style="letter-spacing: -0.25pt;">The project has been impacted by significant delays, from pre-design through design due in part to cost reconciliation efforts. Another reason for the extended schedule has to do with a longer, more involved design schedule to define the project (Phases 1A &amp; 1B). Additionally, the decision to address the full plant with this project to ensure its ability to meet new stringent permit requirements and not just the deferred maintenance, has made for a longer design period and a longer construction period as well. The original design phase of the project was assumed to begin January 31, 2017, and be completed November 6, 2017. The execution of this project has resulted in an actual design schedule that began on January 31, 2017 and is currently projected to be completed April 24, 2019. This is an increase in the design schedule of approximately 19 months. The original construction management schedule assumed a construction duration to be 8/15/17 – 12/3/18, the new schedule assumes construction to start in late May 2019 with completion in March 2021.</span></p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Deny authorization to amend the existing contract with HDR, Inc. for extended owner’s representative services.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Direct City staff to negotiate a lower fee and reduced scope of work with HDR, Inc. as an amendment to the existing contract</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Authorize the City to amend the existing contract with HDR, Inc. to provide extended owner’s representative services.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Not authorizing the amendment could initially save $327,025 in Owner’s representative fees, but the City does not have the resources or experience necessary to manage a construction project of this scale, as well as deal effectively with the complexity in negotiating a new N.P.D.E.S. permit.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Negotiating a lower fee would result in a reduced scope of services which would impact project oversight but also permit negotiations with DEQ.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Funding for this phase of the project is available in the FY 19/20 budget. Both operating revenue and State Revolving Loan Funds are available.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council to approve <span style="line-height: normal;">Option 3.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:&nbsp;HDR, Inc.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">- Existing Contract</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">- HDR contract amendment-scope of work</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">- HDR contract amendment-fee schedule</span></p>
</div>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="BAA2RX79C024">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Apr 15, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.2 </span>CONSTRUCTION SERVICES CONTRACT WITH ROCKY MOUNTAIN CONSTRUCTION, LLC FOR THE WASHBURN WAY SIDEWALKS PROJECT PHASE II IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $719,719.19</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Recommended Action</div>
<div class="rightcol">- Move to authorize staff to enter into a Construction Services Contract with Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC for the Washburn Way Sidewalks Project Phase II in the not-to-exceed amount of $719,719.19, and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $71,971.</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;MARK WILLRETT - PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;<span style="line-height: normal;">Should the City execute a construction services contract with Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC in the not-to-exceed amount of $719,719.19 for construction of the Washburn Way Sidewalks Project Phase II?</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">In 2013 sidewalks were installed on the east side of Washburn Way between Pershing Way and the Crater Lake Parkway. Sidewalks were also installed on the west side of Washburn Way between Radcliffe and Union and on the south side of Eberlein between Washburn Way and the A Canal. Prior to this project starting, the original intent was to construct sidewalks on both sides of Washburn Way, but adequate funding was not available at that time.</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">The second phase of the project, constructing sidewalks on the west side of Washburn Way was ranked high by the Southern Oregon Area Commission on Transportation (SOACT) for funding within the Oregon Department of Transportation’s (ODOT) Statewide Transportation Improvement Program (STIP). However, funding of this project would have eliminated another passing lane project on Highway 97 so it was voted to slip this project just below the passing lane project and ultimately out of funding. In 2014, ODOT contacted City staff with the news that they were able to come up with $500,000 towards the project if the City could find the rest of the funds. </span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Staff went before the Klamath County Board of Commissioners to request $175,000 for the project in April of 2015. Staff received unanimous support for the project which facilitated an Intergovernmental Agreement (IGA) with the County that was approved by Council.</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">On January 4, 2016 Council authorized the City to enter into an agreement for construction of the sidewalks with the ODOT (Agreement No. 30315).</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">On December 5 2016, Council authorized the City to enter into an agreement with the ODOT (Agreement No. 31349) for right-of-way acquisition on Washburn Way. All right-of-way acquisition was completed in July 2016 by ODOT.</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">In the Fall of 2017, Council authorized staff to enter into a Design Services Contract with Adkins Consulting Engineers to perform the design and preparation of the bid documents for this project. One of the challenging aspects of&nbsp;this phase of the project is that there was insufficient room behind the sidewalk to construct standard sidewalks. In lieu of acquiring right of way from every resident along the project, the decision was made to shift the curb line approximately two feet into the roadway. As part of this project we will continue the three lane section that exists north of Eberlein, and south to Radcliffe. Staff consulted with a traffic engineering firm to verify that this would not impede traffic flow.</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="tab-stops: -1.0in;">Construction costs have escalated in the intervening years, and the project costs have risen more than a&nbsp; hundred thousand dollars.&nbsp; The City originally was to contribute $75,000 from our bike and ped funding.&nbsp; With the cost increase, it will be necessary to increase the City's contribution to $234,000 or about 27% of the total project.&nbsp; A portion of this amount will fund the contingency and may or may not be expended.&nbsp;&nbsp;A formal request for construction bids was publicly advertised in the <i>Herald and News</i> and the <i>Daily Journal of Commerce</i>. A non-mandatory pre-bid meeting was held on January 22, 2019 where bidders had the opportunity to discuss the project with the design team and staff. Bids were received from five companies on February 21, 2019 when they were publicly opened. Each bidder and their total bid prices are summarized below.&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="tab-stops: -1.0in;"><u>Engineer's Estimate (Published) $730,000 to $770,000</u></span></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="tab-stops: -1.0in;"><b>Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC $719,719.19</b></span></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="tab-stops: -1.0in;">Nevel Concrete &amp; Curb, Inc. $724,623.40</span></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="tab-stops: -1.0in;">Concrete &amp; Utilities, Inc. $778,990</span></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="tab-stops: -1.0in;">Alex Hodge Construction $766,061.70</span></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="tab-stops: -1.0in;">Central Pipeline, Inc $769,875</span></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="tab-stops: -1.0in;">Staff reviewed all documents submitted and determined the Bid from Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC was acceptable. A formal Notice of Intent to Award was sent to all bidders on February 27, 2019.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Approve a Contract with Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC in an amount not-to-exceed $719,719.19 and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $71,971.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Reject a Contract with Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC, modify the project scope and rebid the project.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Reject a Contract with Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC. and postpone the project.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Design Phase and Bid Phase soft cost expenditures are anticipated to total approximately $56,575. Staff anticipates an additional soft cost allowance of $13,000 for construction inspection and materials testing during construction. The total probable project expenditure equals $862,000, including a 10% construction contingency allowance of $71,971, if necessary. Refer to the attached Budget Analysis Form for further detail. </span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Funding will come from a variety of sources as reflected on the Budget Analysis Form. ODOT is contributing $500,000 for the project but $46,899 was used for right-of-way acquisition.&nbsp; &nbsp;The County is providing $175,000.&nbsp; The City's contribution is $75,000 from bike and ped funds, and an additional $159,000 from the Streets capital funding.&nbsp;Contingency makes up $71,972 of the $159,000.&nbsp;Since completion is anticipated for October, it will also be necessary to secure funds in the next fiscal year budget.</span></p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Council Option 1 will utilize FY 18/19 funds available for this project and a portion of funds allocated in the City’s FY 19/21 Budget.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Council Option 2 will delay the project and potentially utilize available funds.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Council Option 3 will cancel the project for construction for the anticipated fiscal year.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: C<span style="line-height: normal;">ouncil to approve Option 1.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">- Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">- Klamath County Public Works</span></p>

<p>- All project bidders (via email)</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">- Project Location Exhibit</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">- Budget Analysis Form</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">- Confirmation of Bid Opening</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">- Notice of Intent to Award</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">- Sample Contract</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Apr 15, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.3 </span>HOME IMPROVEMENT GRANT PROGRAM REVISIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Recommended Action</div>
<div class="rightcol">- Move to adopt the attached proposed policy for the City's Home Improvement Grant Program.</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: NATHAN CHERPESKI - CITY MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the Council adopt the attached policy updating the City's Home Improvement Grant Program?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>: Several years ago, the City Council approved a pilot Home Improvement Grant Program.&nbsp;The intent of the Program was to incentivize property owners to reinvest in properties in targeted neighborhoods.&nbsp;The grants provided up to $250 as a 50% match for improvements to&nbsp;single-family properties.&nbsp;The initial pilot rounds saw limited success.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The pilot program consisted of two rounds. We&nbsp;learned some valuable lessons from this effort.&nbsp;First, the grant at $250 was not sufficient for the properties and neighborhoods we were targeting.&nbsp;Much of the work would require a more significant investment.&nbsp;Second, there was a desire to distinguish between owner occupied and rental properties.&nbsp;The attached policy incorporates those ideas.&nbsp;If approved by City Council, it is anticipated we would fund this program at $15,000 for the next grant cycle.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1. Move to adopt the policy as drafted.</p>

<p>2. Move to adopt the policy with amendments.</p>

<p>3. Take no action and provide staff further direction.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>These funds will be contained within the City's Economic Development Fund.&nbsp;The primary source of income for that fund is&nbsp;transfers from the General Fund.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: N/A</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Proposed Housing Improvement Program Policy</p>
</div>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="BAPNNM60A66F">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Apr 15, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.4 </span>ORDINANCE RENUMBERING KLAMATH FALLS CODE SECTION 5.658 AND AMENDING SECTIONS 6.010 AND 6.605</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Recommended Action</div>
<div class="rightcol">- Move to introduce Ordinance for first reading by title only.</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW934Y6FE44C"><div class="name">Goal #2 - Customer Service</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"><u style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; box-sizing: border-box; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal;">REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: MICHAEL SWANSON - CITY ATTORNEY</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"><u style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; box-sizing: border-box; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal;">ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should the Council amend the City Code in order to clarify parking rules, regulations and enforcement?</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"><u style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; box-sizing: border-box; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal;">SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;Currently, City Code Section 5.658 bars people from parking in front yards unless certain criteria are met.&nbsp;Due to its location in the Code, that section may only be enforced against the land owner.&nbsp; For example, if a tenant decides to park a vehicle in the front yard, any enforcement would be directed to the landlord.&nbsp;The car owner, unless he or she also owns the land, would not face any consequences.&nbsp;By moving this section to Chapter 6 and treating it as a parking violation, the citation could be left on the vehicle and could be enforced against the person who is responsible for the vehicle. &nbsp;</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">In addition to holding the appropriate person responsible, this change will also allow the City's parking enforcement officer to issue the citation.&nbsp;His authority is exclusive to Chapter 6 of the Code.&nbsp;Leaving this section in Chapter 5 would bar him from acting upon it.&nbsp;Only the code enforcement officers have citation authority under Chapter 5.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">The definitions were adopted almost verbatim from the Oregon State Traffic Code.&nbsp;The purpose was to create clarity.&nbsp;For example, the current definition for vehicle states, "(a)s used in this chapter, includes bicycles, skateboards and roller skates." That definition is not helpful.&nbsp;Furthermore, there is no definition for a trailer.&nbsp; By including a definition, everyone will be on notice that trailers are, in fact, vehicles for the purposes of enforcing the Code.</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"><u style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; box-sizing: border-box; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal;">COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">1) Move to approve for first reading by title only the proposed ordinance.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">2) Direct staff to modify the proposed ordinance.</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">3) Decline to approve the proposed ordinance.</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"><u style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; box-sizing: border-box; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal;">FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp;No direct financial impacts are anticipated.</p>

<p style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; display: block; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">&nbsp;</p>

<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">4.2 </span>AUTHORIZATION FOR THE CITY MANAGER TO SIGN AN INTERGOVERNMENTAL AGREEMENT WITH KLAMATH COUNTY FOR THE ALTAMONT DRIVE WATERLINE REPLACEMENT PROJECT PHASE VI</div>

<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW934Y6FE44C"><div class="name">Goal #2 - Customer Service</div></a>

<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;SCOTT SOUDERS - CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City enter into an Intergovernmental Agreement with Klamath County for the Altamont Drive Waterline Replacement Project Phase VI?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>On February 4th, 2019, City Council authorized a contract with Alex Hodge Construction for the Altamont Drive Waterline Replacement Project Phase VI. As part of that project the City collaborated with Klamath County to include pavement surface grind and inlay improvements along Altamont Drive between Barry Avenue and Anderson Avenue. All work is included within one set of construction documents with the County paving tasks being tracked separately.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The City has executed the construction services contract with Alex Hodge Construction with the agreement that Klamath County will reimburse for its respective items. The attached Intergovernmental Agreement (IGA) has been prepared to memorialize the relationship between both agencies.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Apr 01, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">5. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">5.1 </span>CONSTRUCTION SERVICES CONTRACT WITH BOB’S EXCAVATING, INC. FOR THE STEWART LENOX WATER SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS PROJECT IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $928,166</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Recommended Action</div>
<div class="rightcol">- Move to authorize staff to enter into a Construction Services Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. for the Stewart Lenox Water System Improvements Project in the not-to-exceed amount of $928,166, and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $139,225.</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW934Y6FE44C"><div class="name">Goal #2 - Customer Service</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;SCOTT SOUDERS - CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City execute a construction services contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. in the not-to-exceed amount of $928,166 for construction of the Stewart Lenox Water System Improvements Project?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The City Water Division has identified the need to improve fire flow capabilities in the Stewart Lenox area south of Highway 66, between Agate Road and Granite Street. When the area was developed, prior to being part of the City, there were no fire hydrants or adequately sized pipes installed as part of the water system infrastructure. The existing infrastructure&nbsp;consists of mostly aging 2” water mains and cannot provide adequate fire protection.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In the Fall of 2017, the City retained RH2 Engineering, Inc. to perform an Alternatives Analysis that studied water infrastructure improvement opportunities for the area. The Analysis determined the following infrastructure was needed in order to provide&nbsp;adequate fire flow and domestic water service to the area:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Construction of approximately 3000 lineal feet of new 12-inch water main beginning at the corner of Hwy 66 and Agate Street and ending along Highway 66, west of Granite Street.</li>
	<li>Construction of approximately 2700 lineal feet of 8-inch water main along the adjoining residential streets. These segments will include new fire hydrants and domestic services.</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The project was initially identified to be designed and constructed in two phases over two separate fiscal years. However, during the design of Phase 1, the design team identified a significant potential financial savings by combining the design and construction phases into a single project. In August 2018, staff requested a design services amendment where the design team was asked to proceed with combining the project. Construction documents were then completed and bid to include all improvements under a single project.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>A formal request for construction bids was publicly advertised in the Herald and News and the Daily Journal of Commerce. A non-mandatory pre-bid meeting was held on January 22, 2019 where bidders had the opportunity to discuss the project with the design team and staff. Bids were received from five companies on February 21, 2019 when they were publicly opened. Each bidder and their total bid prices are summarized below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>Estimate (Published) $1,300,000 to 1,500,000</strong></u></p>

<p>Jesse Rodriguez Construction $1,393,012.00</p>

<p>West Coast Pipeline $1,221,700.00</p>

<p>Alex Hodge Construction $1,368,982.00</p>

<p>Morello Construction, LLC $1,228,461.29</p>

<p><em><strong>Bob's Excavating, Inc. $928,166.00</strong></em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Staff reviewed all documents submitted and determined the bid from Bob’s Excavating, Inc. was acceptable. A formal Notice of Intent to Award was sent to all bidders on February 27, 2019.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. in an amount not-to-exceed $928,166 and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $139,225.</li>
	<li>Reject a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc., modify the project scope and rebid the project.</li>
	<li>Reject a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. and postpone the project.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>Design Phase and Bid Phase soft cost expenditures are anticipated to total approximately $113,700. Staff anticipates an additional soft cost allowance of $15,000 for construction inspection and materials testing during construction. The total probable project expenditure equals $1,150,611, including a 15% construction contingency allowance of $139,225 if necessary. Refer to the attached Budget Analysis Form for further detail.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Funding for the project was originally anticipated to be split between two fiscal years. The current FY18/19 budget allocates $800,000 towards Phase 1 of the Stewart Lenox Distribution project. The current Capital Improvement Program (CIP) identifies Phase 2 under the FY19/20 budget projection in the amount of $840,000. Therefore, a combined budget of $1,640,000 has been considered for this project. Funds for the balance of the project will be requested through the FY19/21 biennial budget cycle and would be available for completion of the work.</p>

<ol>
	<li>Council Option 1 will utilize funds available and projected for this project.</li>
	<li>Council Option 2 will delay the project and potentially utilize available funds.</li>
	<li>Council Option 3 will cancel the project for construction for the anticipated fiscal year.</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;<span style="line-height: normal;">Council to approve Option 1.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Bob’s Excavating, Inc.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Project Location Exhibit</li>
	<li>Budget Analysis Form</li>
	<li>Confirmation of Bid Opening</li>
	<li>Notice of Intent to Award</li>
	<li>Sample Contract</li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Recommended Action</div>
<div class="rightcol">- Move to introduce ordinance for second and final reading by title only.<br> - Move to pass ordinance.</div>

<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: MIKE SWANSON - CITY ATTORNEY</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:<strong> </strong>Whether Council should&nbsp;approve the proposed Community Development Ordinance (CDO) text amendments as modified by Council after reconsideration of the item at the March 18, 2019 Council Meeting?&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>Councilor Andres who had voted with the majority on March 4, 2019, used City Code Section 2.080 to reconsider past Council action. Because a public hearing had been closed, Council did not reopen the public hearing. After further discussion about the noticing procedure&nbsp;and the permissive nature of the word may, Council made findings that the process was initiated correctly and notice for the item was proper. Council then moved to introduce the ordinance with the following modifications from the Planning Commission's recommendation.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Council struck the more extensive definition changes recommend by the Planning Commission and simplified the change to removing the word requires and replacing it with encourages. The new definition is shown below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><em><u>Mixed-Use Zone</u>: A zone that <s>requires</s> <strong>encourages</strong> buildings to have a vertical mix of uses on a single lot, with residential dwelling units above the first floor. This can be a combination of the following uses on a single lot: Residential; Commercial Service; Commercial Trade; Public; and where appropriate, uses allowed in the Light Industrial Zone.</em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p><w:sdtpr></w:sdtpr><w:sdt docpart="C9455F5C1F2543CA8EA232ECAC5CE3B5" id="1054194499" sdttag="Requested Motion/Action" title="Requested Motion/Action"></w:sdt></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>1)&nbsp;Introduce the Ordinance for second and final reading by title; and pass the Ordinance.</p>

<p>2)&nbsp;Not introduce the Ordinance for second reading; and give staff further direction.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>There is no direct financial impact related to the proposed CDO text amendment.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Apr 01, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>EXECUTIVE SESSION - No session scheduled at the time the agenda was released.</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.1 </span>CLOSED SESSION</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Procedural</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p>The City Council may recess/adjourn to Executive Session under ORS 192.660 as follows: ORS 192.660(2):</p>

<p>(a) - Employment of Public Officers, Employees</p>

<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u><em>Public Comment</em></u> is time reserved&nbsp;for citizens to speak on a matter that is not on the scheduled of the Meeting Agenda. Each person has 3 minutes to speak and must state their name and address for the record (<em>it is preferred that you fill out a Public Comment Form and return it to the City Recorder</em>). If there are multiple people from one Group/Entity that wish to convey "one message" they can have a Group Speaker and, upon request, would be given 5-10 minutes from Council to speak.</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 18, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>LIQUOR LICENSE RECOMMENDATION FOR LIMITED ON-PREMISES SALES FOR THE YELLOW FLAMINGO BUSINESS LOCATED AT 1819 AVALON STREET</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Whether or not to recommend a limited on-premises Liquor License for the Yellow Flamingo?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The Yellow Flamingo is applying for a new outlet Liquor License to allow Limited On-Premises Sales at their new deli and video lottery establishment located at 1819 Avalon Street.&nbsp;This would allow for the sale of malt beverages, wine, beer, and cider for consumption at the licensed business.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>This new establishment is scheduled to open mid-March in the Klamath Falls Town Center.&nbsp;The business location is zoned General Commercial.&nbsp;The operation of a retail outlet is consistent with the zoning.&nbsp;The business will be open daily from 7 a.m. until 2:30 a.m. Notice of the proposed liquor license was sent to the Police Department who identified no disqualifying information. &nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The entire establishment will be restricted by age.&nbsp;As such, the criteria under the Adult Business Overlay Zone (CDO Section 12.494) must be satisfied.&nbsp;Staff's review indicates the proposal meets the criteria in-that the adult business is located more than 400 feet from any residential zone and more than 1,000 feet from any public or private school, public library, or public park which covers an area of not less than 20,000 square feet and has recreational facilities such as a playground, baseball field, football field, soccer field, tennis court, basketball court or volleyball court.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>If a licensed premise is to be located within 500 feet of a licensed child care facility or elementary or secondary school; a church, a hospital, nursing care facility or convalescent care facility; a park or children-oriented recreational facility; and alcohol and other drug treatment or rehabilitation facility; and will adversely impact the facility, OLCC may deny a license unless the applicants show good cause to overcome the proximity to facilities under Oregon Administrative Rules (OAR 845-005-0326).&nbsp; The adult business does not fall within any of these distance restrictions.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1. Move to make a recommendation to the OLCC for the allowance of Limited On-Premises Sales at the Yellow Flamingo.</p>

<p>2. Move to not recommend the allowance of Limited On-Premises Sales at the Yellow Flamingo.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;">There is no financial impact related to making a recommendation to OLCC.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="line-height: normal;">The Yellow Flamingo</span></p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 18, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.2 </span>REQUEST TO AMEND CITY'S CURRENT SURPLUS PROPERTY LIST</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Whether or not to amend the City's Surplus Property List to include an additional property under the “Substandard Undevelopable” classification.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>In order to sell City-owned property, it must typically first be included on the City’s Surplus Property List. The property in question, County Assessor Map/Tax Lot R-3809-029CC-01500-000, is located in the 300 block of Upham Street, is presently vacant and approximately 1,450 square feet, and was determined to have no City use. The property is proposed for classification as “Substandard Undevelopable” as defined within attached Resolution No. 05-18 (Property-Procedures for sale of certain classes of City-Owned Real Property) and as described below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><em>SUBSTANDARD UNDEVELOPABLE PROPERTY: These real property parcels: 1) contain no structures; 2) are generally small and irregularly shaped; 3) are not of sufficient size to be developed pursuant to the standards for the land use zones in which they are located; and 4) have minimal market value. This class of property may also include larger parcels of property that are not developable due to the existence of easements, utility lines or other restrictions that will significantly interfere with development of the property.</em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>If approved for classification by Council, the property would be solicited for sale, per the below procedures.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><em>If the City Manager determines that the property is unsuited for development or use except in conjunction with abutting property, the City Manager may, in his/her sole discretion, establish minimum terms of sale, shall offer the property to any abutting property owners that could benefit from ownership of the real property and shall sell to the highest bidder. If there is only one abutting property owner, the City Manager, in his/her sole discretion, is authorized to accept nominal value for the parcel. The purchaser shall in all cases be responsible for paying all required recording, surveying, mapping and City administrative fees incurred or imposed in connection with the sale. Upon payment of the required purchase price and verification that the property is free of liens and encumbrances, the City Manager shall execute a deed conveying title to the property to the buyer.</em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Amend the City's Surplus Property List to include County Assessor Map/Tax Lot&nbsp;R-3809-029CC-01500-000 as Substandard Undevelopable Property.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Do not Amend the City's Surplus Property List to include the&nbsp;property.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: There is no immediate financial impact from the proposed listing and would be a nominal financial impact, if sold.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: N/A</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.1 </span>ADOPTION OF KLAMATH FALLS' PARKS MASTER PLAN - 2019</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOHN BELLON - PARKS MANAGER&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the Council adopt the 2019 Parks Master Plan?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The current 1998 City Parks Master Plan is past its service capability for effective planning of contemporary and future park system needs. The Parks Division contracted with Moore Iacofano Goldtsman Inc. (MIG) as a Consultant in November 2017 to assist City staff draft a new Parks Master Plan. The Plan provides recommendations, implementation strategies and guidance for Parks projects and services potentially throughout the next ten years.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Following the 16-month process comprising&nbsp;City staff, Parks Advisory Board, City Council, Parks partners and stakeholders, and public outreach response, the draft is prepared for Council adoption as the 2019 Parks Master Plan.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>During the draft Parks Master Plan process, the City and the Consultant:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Completed an updated system-wide inventory of current Parks facilities</li>
	<li>Developed a system-wide Needs Assessment</li>
	<li>Developed a comprehensive list of system-wide Recommendations</li>
	<li>Developed an Implementation strategy for Parks projects and investments</li>
	<li>Developed a Prioritization Tool to utilize for recommended, future Parks projects and investments</li>
</ul>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Move to adopt the Parks Master Plan draft as the 2019 Parks Master Plan</li>
	<li>Move to reject the Parks Master Plan draft as the 2019 Parks Master Plan</li>
	<li>Move to recommend Staff complete additional work to the 2019 Parks Master Plan draft</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: Impacts extend only to those costs approved by City Council, as they become proposed and implemented from the 2019 Parks Master Plan.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>- Moore Iacofano Goldtsman Inc. (MIG)</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- 2019 Parks Master Plan (as attached-in final <em><strong>substantiative form</strong></em>/additional&nbsp;scrivener changes still to be made by staff/consultant).</p>

<p><em><strong>* For Purpose of&nbsp;the Agenda, the .pdf version will only be provided via email and BoardDocs.</strong></em></p>

<p>* A hard copy <em><strong>Final Version</strong></em> will be provided to Council once finalized and <em><strong>under separate cover.</strong></em>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 18, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.2 </span>AUTHORIZATION TO EXECUTE A CONTRACT WITH BOB'S EXCAVATING IN THE AMOUNT OF $41,190 FOR THE DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS LOCATED AT 6036 SUMMERS LANE ON AIRPORT PROPERTY</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp; JOHN BARSALOU - AIRPORT DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the Airport demolish buildings no longer suitable for use&nbsp;at 6036 Summers Lane?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>The buildings at 6036 Summers Lane consist of a pole&nbsp;building with administration and garage/operations&nbsp;space built in approximately 1946, plus a separate four bay pole building built in approximately 1986.&nbsp;The buildings have been vacant since July 2011 when LTM, Inc., who was using it for a concrete store, terminated their lease.&nbsp; Prior to LTM, the building had been used by the Klamath County Vector Control District.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Due to a failing septic system and rising maintenance costs due to the age of the buildings,&nbsp;the Airport has decided that the best course of action is to demolish the buildings.&nbsp; This would make the parcel more visually appealing and conducive to future development for aviation purposes.&nbsp; Quotes were solicited by Airport staff for the demolition of both buildings plus removal of building footings, foundations,&nbsp;fencing and pavement on the parcel.&nbsp; Included in the RFQ was the demolition of a small storage bunker on the airfield which is also no longer in use.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Airport sent the RFQ package to five companies and received two quotes as detailed below:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Bob's Excavating - $41,190</li>
	<li>Rocky Mountain&nbsp;Construction - $49,875</li>
	<li>Belfor Environmental - no response</li>
	<li>Bogatay Construction - no response</li>
	<li>Modoc Contracting - no response</li>
</ul>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Award contract to Bob's Excavating who supplied the low quote.</li>
	<li>Award contract to Rocky Mountain Construction who supplied a higher quote.</li>
	<li>Reject all quotes and provide staff with further direction.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp;The Airport has&nbsp;sufficient budgeted funds to cover the costs of this project.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>- Bob's Excavating</p>

<p>- Rocky Mountain Construction</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Quote Solicitation Record</p>

<p>- Contract Documents (Council Paper Packet contains Contract with selective&nbsp;Quote/Bid Pages 1; and 135-155) (*all documents are available upon request)&nbsp;</p>

<p>- Aerial Map</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 18, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.3 </span>CONSULTANT SERVICES CONTRACT WITH FREGONESE ASSOCIATES TO COMPLETE THE GREATER DOWNTOWN REVITALIZATION PLAN IN AN AMOUNT NOT TO EXCEED $49,989</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Whether or not to award a consultant services contract to Fregonese Associates to complete the Greater Downtown Revitalization Plan?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>In recognizing the importance of an updated and relevant downtown plan to provide vision,&nbsp;to guide future investment, and to build on past and continuing redevelopment efforts, $50,000 was allocated within the 2018-2019 Fiscal Budget to create an updated downtown plan through consultant assistance. The current downtown plan, while seldom referenced, was created over 30 years ago and a new plan to be created through public outreach and citizen involvement is an important guiding tool for our historic Main Street and downtown core.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>To seek professional assistance, City staff prepared and issued a Request for Qualifications (RFQ) on December 10, 2018 which has been attached to this agenda report. Five firms responded to the RFQ solicitation by the January 15, 2019 deadline and submissions were reviewed by a small group of City and Downtown Association personnel. Based on the group’s review, the following three firms were invited for in-person interviews on February 13, 2019 with all submissions attached; BDS Planning &amp; Urban Design, Cascadia Partners, and Fregonese Associates. Through the interview process, it was determined Fregonese Associates would be the best firm to engage to complete the Greater Downtown Revitalization Plan and pending Council approval. Fregonese Associates has been recommended given its project team experience, the completion of relevant prior reports for other communities, and the believed ability to best partner with and actively engage community members.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Authorize a consultant services contract with Fregonese Associates to complete the Greater Downtown Revitalization Plan in an amount not to exceed $49,989.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Further discussion and additional consideration of quotes received.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Decline to act at this time, and provide staff further direction.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>Option 1 - $50,000 for the completion of an updated downtown plan was allocated within account number 101-10-3211 during approval of the Fiscal Year 2018/2019 Budget. The contract performance period will however extend beyond the end of the present fiscal year and into the next budget period. Staff will include the appropriate funds in next year's budget. The attached consultant services contract with Fregonese Associates is in an amount not to exceed $49,989.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Scott Fregonese</p>

<p>Principal, Fregonese Associates</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Consultant Services Contract - Fregonese Associates</p>

<p>- RFQ - Greater Downtown Revitalization Plan</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 18, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.4 </span>DOWNTOWN FACADE IMPROVEMENT GRANT AWARDS AUTHORIZATION FOR FISCAL YEAR 2018/2019</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: <span style="margin: 0px;">Whether or not to authorize Downtown Façade Improvement Grant awards as recommended?</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>To improve and restore downtown building appearances and to spur publicly visible improvements, $130,000 in leveraged City grant funding was made available within the 2018/2019 budget cycle. The City previously administered a first or pilot round of façade and building improvement grants in 2016, and while the program was largely successful, process and selection improvements were made from past experiences to better ensure applicant readiness and project viability. The Klamath Falls Downtown Association (KFDA) concurrently made $15,000 in façade improvement grant funding available and the two solicitations were run concurrently with KFDA staff taking the administrative lead.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Prior to formally noticing grant availability, KFDA requested that interested parties submit brief letters of interest so response levels could be better gauged and applicants could begin readying a formal submission package. In all, 19 letters of interest were received with the majority of parties then submitting full grant applications.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Downtown Façade Improvement Grant opportunity was noticed on January 2 with applications due on January 28 through online submission on the KFDA website. To simplify processes for both the applicants and reviewing entities, only one application was needed to be considered for both City and KFDA funding. Seventeen (17) total responses were received for a combined $685,000 grant request with $145,000 available (combined City &amp; KFDA sources). A group comprised of KFDA member volunteers and City staff reviewed all application requests during three separate meetings prior to recommending the attached and proposed award listing, and after completing additional reach-out to individual applicants to better understand submitted projects and scopes. Recommended projects include exterior painting, awning replacement, and the creation of new, open, and inviting storefronts among other project categories.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Upon Council award and execution of formal grant agreements, all recipients will have one calendar year to complete the agreed-upon project improvements and no scope changes will be permitted except through prior Council and/or KFDA approval.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li><span style="margin: 0px;">Authorize Downtown Façade Improvement Grant awards per the Design Review Panel recommendations (as attached in the Award Summary).</span></li>
	<li><span style="margin: 0px;">Deny Downtown Façade Improvement Grant awards per Design Review Panel recommendations, and determine alternate award allocations.</span></li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li><span style="margin: 0px;">$130,000 in funding for Downtown Façade Improvement Grants was allocated within the 2018-2019 Fiscal Year Budget in the Economic Development/Property Fund. The recommended cumulative grant award amounts totals $130,000. Staff will include the appropriate funds in next year's fiscal budget.</span></li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Darin Rutledge</p>

<p>Executive Director, Klamath Falls Downtown Association</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Proposed Grant Award Summary</p>

<p>- Draft Grant Award Letters</p>

<p>- Facade Improvement Grant Guidelines</p>

<p>* All grant applications received are on file electronically with the City Recorder (copies available&nbsp;upon request).</p>
