<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 18, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.7 </span>Meeting Item Action: ACTING IN THE CAPACITY OF COUNCIL AND THE URBAN RENEWAL AGENCY - CONSIDERATION OF A REQUEST FOR DEVELOPER ASSISTANCE FOR A HOTEL PROPOSAL</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: NATHAN CHERPESKI - CITY MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should the City of Klamath Falls or its Urban Renewal Agency provide support to a Hotel in the Timber Mill Shores Development?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The Urban Renewal Agency recently amended the Lake Shore Urban Renewal Area Plan to include funding for developer support.&nbsp;Specifically, this support was focused on potential hotels, apartments, retail, and restaurants.&nbsp;The intent was to provide a grant that could offset most if not all the System Development Charges.&nbsp;While not setting hard categories, previous discussions allocated up to $300,000 for hotel development, anticipating two assistance grants.&nbsp;We have received the attached request for developer assistance for a new hotel.&nbsp;While some zoning issues remain, the developer is eager to see if the City has funds available to off-set the higher development costs associated with a brownfield development.&nbsp; The developer has requested $250,000.&nbsp;While there may be justification to assisting the first mover at a higher rate, it was anticipated that the $300,000 would fund two grants.&nbsp;Since staff estimates the SDCs being closer to $160,000, staff&nbsp;would recommend a lesser amount than requested.&nbsp;However, Council can fund the request at an amount desired.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1. Direct staff to prepare an agreement to provide assistance in the amount of $160,000.</p>

<p>2. Direct staff to prepare an agreement for assistance in a different amount.</p>

<p>3. Decline to act at this time, and give staff further direction.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp; The Urban Renewal Plan has $500,000 set aside for developer support.&nbsp;However, there are no funds immediately available. The fund has debt that is in front of any payments to a developer.&nbsp; If the City desires to assist a developer prior to adequate funds coming available, the City could lend the money but understand it would not be repaid for several years. Once sufficient tax increment exists to refinance all the debt, the City would be repaid the loan.&nbsp;Of note, the value of the hotel once constructed and paying property taxes is a significant increase over the current bare ground.&nbsp;The increment from the hotel will go a long way to help payoff the debt required to construct the infrastructure in the area.&nbsp; Additionally, it is anticipated that the hotel will collect approximately $40,000 per year in Transient Room Tax.&nbsp;While a portion of this tax would not be new to the City, it is arguable that a significant portion of the tax will be from stays we would not have captured without the hotel.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp; Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>- Ferguson Properties</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Request Letter</p>

<p>- Fairfield Inn Materials Sheet</p>

<p>- Fairfield Inn Site Plan</p>

<p>- Resolution #19-03</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 04, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">4. </span>CONSENT AGENDA</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">4.2 </span>CONTRACT CHANGE ORDER #2 WITH J.W. FOWLER GENERAL CONTRACTORS FOR THE PELICAN CITY BOOSTER STATION PROJECT (PHASE III) IN THE AMOUNT OF $29,473.33</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action (Consent)</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: ANDREW LAKEY - ASSOCIATE ENGINEER/PROJECTS MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City Council authorize Change Order #2 with J.W. Fowler General Contractors for the Pelican City Booster Station Project (Phase III) in the amount of $29,473.33?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>In August 2018, City Council authorized a contract with J.W. Fowler General Contractors for the Pelican City Booster Station (Phase III) Water Main Project. Construction work commenced on September 13, 2018. The major components of this project consisted of a booster pump station, watermain piping from the booster station on Lakeport Boulevard to Dan O’Brien Way, and a directional bore and casing under the railroad tracks and Hwy 97 – see attached project exhibit map.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>During the design phase of this project test bores were preformed and soil samples collected to identify anticipated soil materials through the directional bore location. Based on this information, the bore sub-contractor determined what type of equipment would be best suited to perform the directional bore. Early on, during the directional bore, the sub-contractor encountered boulders and very hard materials thought to be armoring for the railroad tracks. Based on the encountered change in condition, the sub-contractor notified the general contractor and design team and mobilized equipment designed to drill through the harder soils. Change Order #2 captures the additional time, equipment, and monitoring required by the railroad due to the change in conditions.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Following the bore operation, staff identified a potential savings that would omit the sand fill specified for the annular space between the bore casing and the waterline. Staff requested that the design engineer, RH2 Engineering, further research if the specified sand fill was required. Following research with the railroad and further evaluation of the casing, RH2 recommended omitting the sand fill. This omission resulted in a credit savings to the project that was incorporated into Change Order #2.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Authorize staff to execute Change Order #2 with J.W. Fowler General Contractors for the Pelican City Booster Station Project (Phase III) in the amount of $29,473.33.</li>
	<li>Deny staff to execute the Change Order #2 with J.W. Fowler General Contractors for the Pelican City Booster Station Project (Phase III), and advise staff how to proceed with compensation to the Contractor.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>Council awarded a Construction Services Contract with J.W. Fowler General Contractors in the amount of $1,552,923 and authorized a project contingency amount of $310,585. To date, including Change Orders #1 and #2, a total contingency amount of $36,724.41 has received support by staff. Approval of this Change Order #2 would result in a remaining contingency allowance of $273,860.59. The project is roughly 80% complete and further potential change orders should be minimal through project closeout.</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approval of Option 1 would utilize available funds allocated for the project.</li>
	<li>Approval of Option 2 would preserve funds within the budget, but not compensate the Contractor for work performed.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">- J. W. Fowler General Contractors</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Change Order Request #2</p>

<p>- PCO-03 (JWF NOC #03) – Potential Change Order Supporting Documents</p>

<p>- PCO-05 (JWF NOC #05) – Potential Change Order Supporting Documents</p>

<p>- Change Order Log</p>

<p>- Project Exhibit Map</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B9MVLQ7BB01F">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 04, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">4. </span>CONSENT AGENDA</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">4.3 </span>PURCHASE OF A JOHN DEERE 1585 TERRAINCUT WITH COMFORTCAB COMMERCIAL FRONT MOWER IN THE AMOUNT OF $39,120.28 FOR THE AIRPORT</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action (Consent)</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE GOETZ - AIRPORT OPERATIONS MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should the Airport proceed with the budgeted purchase of a John Deere 1585 TerrainCut with ComfortCab Front Mower?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>Historically, the Airport has used a 1994 Tiger Mower with a forward-facing flail attachment to mow around airfield edge lights. During the 2016 mowing season it was necessary to&nbsp;cease utilization of the Tiger Mower and begin using the 2016 Kubota F3990 for vegetation control around airfield edge lighting. This was a result of federal regulations surrounding the protection of Applegate’s Milkvetch, a federally listed endangered plant species, which prevented the Airport from using flail mowers in milkvetch areas.&nbsp; The 2016 Kubota mower is not a cabbed mower and its use on the airfield has not been satisfactory.&nbsp; Without a cab, the Kubota mower operator is exposed to a significant amount of debris, dust and heat.&nbsp; In addition, mower operators must monitor an airfield radio while mowing which is difficult to do in an uncabbed environment which increases the risk for incursions with aircraft on the airfield.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Airport budgeted $60,000 for the purchase of a new airfield mower in the department’s fiscal year 2019 budget. The Airport performed substantial research into mower requirements and took into account all staff safety factors. The Airport also reached out to peer airports across the country to inquire what equipment they used for this purpose. Numerous airports responded that they used the John Deere 1575 or 1585 mower with a “Comfort Cab” for vegetation control around their airport edge lighting.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Airport issued a Request for Quotes on January 25 for a wide decked blade mower and received three proposals by the deadline of February 14.</p>

<ul>
	<li>Pape Machinery (John Deere)&nbsp;- $39,120.28</li>
	<li>Western Turfstar (Toro) - $59,854.02</li>
	<li>RNT Equipment (Jacobsen) - $84,490.00</li>
</ul>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Award&nbsp;contract to Pape Machinery that supplied the low quote.</li>
	<li>Reject all quotes and provide staff with further direction.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp;The Airport has $60,000 in it's FY19 Capital budget for the purchase of a mower.&nbsp;The low quote is approximately $20,000 under the budget funds available.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>- Pape Machinery</p>

<p>- Western Turfstar</p>

<p>- RNT Equipment</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Quote Solicitation Record</p>

<p>- Contract</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 04, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">5. </span>LAND USE PUBLIC HEARING - LEGISLATIVE</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">5.1 </span>AN ORDINANCE AMENDING COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT ORDINANCE SECTION 10.010 (DEFINITIONS) AND THE TABLE OF CONTENTS FOR CHAPTER 12 REGARDING MIXED-USE DEVELOPMENT - First Reading</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:<strong> </strong>Whether Council should&nbsp;approve the proposed Community Development Ordinance (CDO) text amendments as recommended by Planning Commission to change portions of CDO Sections 10.010 and 12.700 – 12.720 regarding the Mixed-Use Zone?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>During the recent review and approval of land use applications 12-Design Review-18 and 3-Conditional Use Permit-18 (proposed DHS office facility), there was considerable discussion over some existing and lacking definitions within the CDO, particularly related to the ‘Mixed-Use’ zoning category, ‘Government Office’ use, and ‘Social Service’ use. With local decision-making for the referenced applications now complete, CDO corrections are proposed to prevent future ambiguity and make the CDO a more precise guide for development.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Specific to Mixed-Use, the following items were discussed in detail with clarification through text amendment now sought:</p>

<ul>
	<li>The listings for Sections 12.700 to 12.720 (Mixed-Use Zoning Standards) were retained in the Table of Contents for CDO Chapter 12 even though those sections were not included in the CDO amendments that were adopted in 2017.</li>
	<li>Likewise, the definition for Mixed-Use Zone that matched the proposed Mixed-Use Zoning Standards was retained through the 2017 CDO amendments although the standards were rejected.</li>
</ul>

<p>The present Mixed-Use Zone definition requires, “Buildings to have a vertical mix of uses on a single Lot, with residential dwelling units above the first floor.” While perhaps aspirational, staff has found this newly included definition to be inconsistent with Council’s 2000 approval and creation of the Mixed-Use Zone category, inconsistent with previous &nbsp;and continuing land use proposals within TimberMill Shores, contrary to overall feedback received during the recent CDO amendment process, and that requirement for each and every Lot to contain a vertical mix of uses may be overly restrictive and detrimental to future TimberMill Shores build-out.&nbsp;Documented support for the proposed text amendments has been provided by a&nbsp;majority of the&nbsp;affected property owners and is attached to this agenda report.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;It is also understood that the current definition was adopted in error. All the proposed supporting code that would have implemented this definition, was removed as part of the CDO review process.<span 12pt="" style="margin: 0px; line-height: 115%; font-family:;"><span style="margin: 0px;">&nbsp;</span><span style="margin: 0px;">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>To correct these noted errors within the CDO and to prevent future ambiguity for land use application review, after receiving direction from Planning Commission and City Council, staff has proposed text amendments to amend the CDO in the following ways:&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Remove existing Mixed-Use Zone definition in Section 10.010 and replace it with new definitions for Mixed-Use Development and Mixed-Use Zone.</li>
	<li>Remove the “Mixed Use Zone Standards” (Sections 12.700-12.720) from the Table of Contents for CDO Chapter 12.</li>
</ul>

<p style="margin: 0px;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">More specifically, the following and current definition for the Mixed-Use Zone is proposed to be replaced with the Mixed-Use Development and Mixed-Use Zone definitions further below and as recommended for approval by Planning Commission. </span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><em>Current definition, </em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><strong>Mixed-Use Zone:</strong> A zone that requires Buildings to have a vertical mix of uses on a single Lot, with residential dwelling units above the first floor. This can be a combination of the following uses on a single lot: Residential; Commercial Service; Commercial Trade; public; and where appropriate, uses allowed in the Light Industrial Zone.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><em>Proposed definitions, </em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><strong>Mixed-Use Development:</strong> The development of a neighborhood, tract of land, building, or structure with a variety of complementary and integrated uses, such as, but not limited to, residential, office, manufacturing, retail, public, and recreation, in a compact urban form.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><strong>Mixed-Use Zone:</strong> A zone that permits though does not require a combination of different permitted uses within a single Development.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>At their January 28, 2019 meeting, the Planning Commission held a public hearing to consider the text amendments as recommended by staff including language related to the Government Office and Social Service use categories. At that hearing, the Commission recommended the Council approve only the portions of the text amendments related to Mixed-Use. On the recommendation of the Planning Commission, only the proposed changes to CDO Sections 10.010 and 12.700 – 12.720 regarding Mixed-Use are presented here for consideration by the Council (proposed complete text amendments attached as Exhibit A to the draft Ordinance). Discussion regarding how to best correct CDO deficiencies related to Government Office and Social Service use categories is presented under a separate agenda item.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong><u>RELEVANT REVIEW CRITERIA, FACTS, AND ANALYSIS</u>:</strong></p>

<p>CDO Section 10.105 requires text amendments to be initiated by either the Planning Commission or City Council. Prior to making a motion to recommend approval, disapproval, or modification of the proposed text amendment to Council, the Commission must first move to initiate the text amendment.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>CDO Section 10.115 requires that notice of the proposed text amendment be published in the newspaper and provided to local electronic media at least 45 days prior to the hearing before the Council. Public notice of this hearing to consider the proposed text amendment was formally published in the Herald and News on January 18, 2019. &nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>CDO Sections 10.105-10.125 (Text Amendment Procedures) do not provide criteria for reviewing text amendments. However, any proposed text amendment should be reviewed against the purpose of the CDO contained in Section 10.000.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Per CDO Section 10.000, the purpose of the CDO is to set forth standards and procedures governing the development and use of land. The purpose shall also be to protect the environment of the City and promote the general health, safety and welfare of the public, by providing for:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>a. &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; A precise guide for the physical development of the City;</p>

<p>b.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Adequate opportunity for citizen involvement in the community development process;</p>

<p>c. &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; Protection of environmentally sensitive areas;</p>

<p>d.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Protection of life and property from natural disasters and hazards when and where possible;</p>

<p>e. &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; Orderly and efficient provision of public facilities and services;</p>

<p>f. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Satisfaction of recreation needs of the City and its visitors;</p>

<p>g.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Provisions of adequate numbers of housing units at price ranges and rent levels commensurate with a broad range of financial capabilities;</p>

<p>h.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Flexibility of housing location, type and density;</p>

<p>i. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Resource sustainability;</p>

<p>j. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; A safe, convenient and economic transportation system;</p>

<p>k.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; An orderly and efficient transition from rural to urban land use;</p>

<p>l. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; An efficient system of administering the procedures of these CDO;</p>

<p>m. &nbsp; &nbsp; An understandable and usable document with a complete set of definitions;</p>

<p>n.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Appropriate development of sites compatible with the neighborhood;</p>

<p>o.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; A healthful, stable, efficient and pleasant environment.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>A precise guide for the physical development of the City</strong></u></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>As noted in the summary section above, the proposed text amendments are intended to correct errors in the CDO and to clear up ambiguity in the existing definitions and permitted uses. These amendments are being brought forward to provide a more precise guide for the physical development of the City.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>FINDING:</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">The proposed text amendments will correct errors in the CDO and clear up ambiguity in the existing definitions and permitted uses resulting in a more precise guide for the physical development of the City.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><strong>Adequate opportunity for citizen involvement in the community development process</strong></u></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The City is following its procedures for text amendments found in Section 10.105 – 10.125 including the publication of required public notices in the Herald and News, an initiation of the text amendment by the Planning Commission, a hearing in front of the Planning Commission, a recommendation from the Planning Commission to the Council, a hearing in front of the City Council, and a final decision on the matter by the City Council.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>FINDING:</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">By following the procedures prescribed by the CDO, the City has provided for adequate opportunity for citizen involvement in the community development process as it relates to the proposed text amendments.</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 04, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>DIRECTION FROM COUNCIL REGARDING SOCIAL SERVICE AND GOVERNMENT OFFICE USE DEFINITIONS WITHIN THE COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT ORDINANCE (CDO)</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Discussion</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Council to give direction to staff regarding Social Service and Government Office use definitions within the Community Development Ordinance (CDO)?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>There is some existing ambiguity in the CDO regarding the Social Service and Government Office use classifications. Although a use category for Social Services was added through the 2017 CDO amendment process and to the ‘Uses Permitted by Zone’ chart, CDO Section 12.000, no definition for this use category was provided. Due at least partially to the fact that there is no definition for Social Services, it is not entirely clear whether a separately categorized use should be classified and reviewed as a social service if a social service component is performed. For example, should an office where government employees work be classified as a Government Office if the services provided by that office could be classified in another category? In wanting to add clarification to the CDO and following Planning Commission and City Council interpretations made through approval of land-use applications 12-DR-18 &amp; 3-CUP-18, staff proposed text amendments to amend the CDO regarding Mixed-Use, Social Services, and Government Office.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>While Planning Commission recommended approval of proposed text amendments related to Mixed-Use at their January 28th meeting, the Commission did not recommend the proposed text amendment language related to Social Services and Government Office and desired further consideration.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Staff now seeks Council direction for how to proceed with present CDO issues pertaining to the Social Services and Government Office use classifications.&nbsp;Because Social Services is a listed use category without definition, ambiguity remains for how to review and approve or deny related land use or business license applications. Additionally, staff recognizes the potential creation of numerous existing non-conforming uses if categorized as a Social Service and especially within the Downtown Business (DB) zone where Social Services are listed as a non-permitted use.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In seeking Council direction, staff has provided a few options or pathways below that may be considered and for additional dialogue. Council is by no means limited to any of the options presented below:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">1)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Council could assign this task back to the Planning Commission.&nbsp;Planning Commission would hold public hearings and possible work session meetings and then report back recommended definitions and allowable uses by zone category for City Council consideration.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">2)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Council could appoint a committee to review the matter.&nbsp;The previous ad-hoc committee as part of the 2017 CDO amendment process was not appointed by the City but was made up of interested individuals who attended multiple meetings to provide input.&nbsp;If Council chooses this approach, staff recommends that each Councilperson select a person to represent their ward and to provide instruction for what specific CDO sections the committee should analyze.&nbsp;This may include discussions over preferred definitions for the Social Services use category and in which zones to most appropriately site. The committee could also take public input.&nbsp;By narrowing the discussion purview, staff hopes the process can be completed more expediently than the prior multi-year CDO amendment process.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">3)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The City could hire a consultant to review the existing CDO and to make recommendations based on how other communities approach use categories and zoning allowances.</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">4)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Council could create its own definition for the Social Services and Government Office use categories or adopt those heard but not recommended by the Planning Commission.</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">5)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Some combination of the above approaches or other.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>For background and included as Exhibit 1 to the agenda report, staff has provided the CDO text amendments related to Social Services and Government Office as proposed to the Planning Commission at their January 28th meeting. To note, Planning Commission only recommended those text amendments related to Mixed-Use and included as part of a separate agenda item and action.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>1) Provide direction to staff.</p>

<p>2) Do not provide direction to staff.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>There is no direct financial impact related to providing staff direction. If a Code audit and recommendations are sought from an outside consultant, appropriate budgets will need to be identified for the project.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to&nbsp;give staff direction through Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: N/A</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Exhibit 1: CDO Text Amendments Presented by Staff, but not Recommended by Planning Commission</p>

<p>- Draft Planning Commission Meeting Minutes (January 28, 2019)</p>

<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.2 </span>ORDINANCE AMENDING KLAMATH FALLS CODE SECTIONS 8.150 AND 8.155 ADOPTING THE INTERNATIONAL PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE - First Reading</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW934Y6FE44C"><div class="name">Goal #2 - Customer Service</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW92ZV6FAC13"><div class="name">Goal #1 - Citizens feel safe and secure in their homes, work sites, and public places.</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp; MICHAEL SWANSON - CITY ATTORNEY</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp; Should the Council adopt the updated 2018 International Property Maintenance Code?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp; Since August 2013, the City has used the International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC) as a guide to assist our Code Enforcement Officers in maintaining minimum standards for structures here in the City.&nbsp;Code Section 8.150 adopted the 2012 edition of the IPMC.&nbsp;Section 8.155 amended particular sections of the IPMC in order to conform it to the City's specific needs. &nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The IPMC was updated last year.&nbsp; The proposed amendments to City Code Sections 8.150 and 8.155 will allow the Code Enforcement Officers to use the most recent version of the IPMC when enforcing minimum standards.&nbsp; Furthermore, through Section 8.155, the City will allow citizens due process in the adjudication of alleged violations.&nbsp; As it is currently written, the IPMC provides a strictly administrative process to find a person in violation of the standards. Section 8.155 allows citizens to appear in Municipal Court for a hearing to determine if they are in violation of the standards set out in the IPMC.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1) Move to introduce the proposed ordinance for first reading by title only.&nbsp;</p>

<p>2) Do not introduce the proposed ordinance, and maintain the 2012 version of the International Property Maintenance Code as the guide for Code Enforcement Officers.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: No known financial impacts.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: N/A</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>- Proposed&nbsp;Ordinance</p>

<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.1 </span>CITY COUNCIL to ADJOURN and RECONVENE AS THE URBAN RENEWAL AGENCY</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 04, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>ADJOURNMENT</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.2 </span>RESOLUTION FOR LAKEFRONT URBAN RENEWAL PLAN (MINOR AMENDMENT)</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE the Urban Renewal Agency</u>:&nbsp;Should the Urban Renewal Agency<font color="#e74c3c"> </font>approve a minor amendment to the Lakefront Urban Renewal Plan to make targeted financial support available for qualified new development in TimberMill Shores?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The Lakefront Urban Renewal Plan (Plan) was established in 2001 to spur the redevelopment of formerly industrial land along the shores of Lake Ewauna. The area, comprised largely of the TimberMill Shores subdivision, described as a 50-acre mixed-use development, has largely sat vacant with minimal investor interest for many years though base infrastructure has largely been furnished. Several factors have been cited as hindering the redevelopment of this area including real estate cycle timing and the area's sheer mass or scale. Specifically, soil and fill conditions requiring extensive excavation and/or different construction methods is an item City staff has heard from potential developers. The extra excavation and site preparation costs makes projects more difficult to complete in an economic fashion which can create project gaps. The City has received inquiries about what assistance, if any, it could provide to help projects move forward.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>At a recent Council work session meeting, staff proposed a minor amendment to the Lakefront Urban Renewal Plan to create a project category to allow for targeted developer assistance. This new category would re-allocate $500,000 from existing project categories while not increasing the Urban Renewal Plan's maximum indebtedness. Through this proposed minor amendment and implementing resolution, $500,000 would be re-allocated from the existing Plan Administration project as contained within the Estimated Project Cost and Revenue Sources of the Plan to allow the Urban Renewal Agency (Agency) to direct funds towards targeted development.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Agency may determine at its discretion how to award funding assistance to qualified private development on a case by case basis and dependent on the benefit derived from the project. For example, the $500,000 allocated to Development Assistance may be awarded to specific project types (i.e. hotel or restaurant uses), a certain number of projects at a set dollar amount each, or may be levered to encourage first-movers and those taking higher risk within the Lakefront Urban Renewal Area (Area). A sample policy for funding allocation has been attached to this agenda report for Agency consideration. Prior to the Agency borrowing and then lending and/or awarding to a specific project developer, analysis should be completed on available tax increment projections and the ability to cover any taken debt.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Lakefront Urban Renewal Plan carries a maximum indebtedness of $7,050,000 while $3,891,064 has been borrowed or utilized to date and primarily through the Streets and Utilities project category. Per the 2001 Plan, all project activities were expected to be completed by 2021 though due to the reasons indicated above, project completions are anticipated to extend beyond that time. $7,800 of the $750,000 allocation for the Plan Administration project category has been utilized to date, leaving $742,000 available and subject of the proposed re-allocation.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Per Oregon Revised Statutes (ORS) and the adopted plan, the Agency may approve a minor plan amendment if the project cost modification is less than $500,000 in 2001 dollars (the Plan adoption year). Any additional increase, raising the maximum indebtedness, or expanding Area boundaries beyond 1% would require a major Plan amendment with additional noticing and processes required. More detailed explanation of Plan amendment processes is contained within Section 900 of the Lakefront Urban Renewal Plan. It is staff's belief with renewed interest in TimberMill Shores and through the creation of a development assistance project category, that new private development may ensue to generate the tax increment needed to retire outstanding or new debt and so that the Lakefront Urban Renewal Plan may be completed in a more expedient timeframe.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>A full copy of the Lakefront Urban Renewal Plan and the proposed resolution approving a minor Plan amendment have been attached to this agenda report.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Urban Renewal Agency OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1. Approve a Minor Amendment to the Lakefront Urban Renewal Plan through the Proposed Resolution.</p>

<p>2. Decline to act at this time and give staff further direction.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>The Proposed Resolution&nbsp;is contingent on adequate funding being available in the Lakefront Urban Renewal Fund. There is no direct cost to the General Fund other than staff time.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Urban Renewal Agency&nbsp;to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: N/A</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Ordinance 01-12 - Approval of the Lakefront Urban Renewal Plan</p>

<p>- Lakefront Urban Renewal Plan - Policy for Targeted Development Assistance</p>

<p>- Proposed Resolution</p>
</div>

<div class="leftcol">Type</div>

<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>

<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;MICHAEL SWANSON&nbsp;- CITY ATTORNEY</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should the City Council have the ability to remove members from City Committees, Boards, or Commissions who are not performing their assigned duties in a professional manner?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;At a recent Council Meeting, members of the Council asked about their authority over members of Committees, Boards, and Commissions once the members were appointed.&nbsp;Currently, there are few, if any, methods for removing a member from a Committee, Board, or Commission within the City Code.&nbsp;Some of our recent amendments and newly formed Committees and Boards have attendance requirements but, for the most part, the Code is silent on the repercussions for a lack of attendance, malfeasance, misfeasance, and nonfeasance.&nbsp;Under the Oregon Revised Statutes, a member of the Planning Commission may be removed after a hearing for misconduct or nonperformance of duty.&nbsp;This proposed ordinance will codify a method for the Mayor and Council to act in the event that the removal of a Committee, Board, or Commission member becomes necessary.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>1) Move to introduce the proposed ordinance for first reading by title only.&nbsp;</p>

<p>2) Not approve the proposed ordinance and give further direction to Staff.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp;None.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp; Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>All Committee, Board, and Commission Members</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.2 </span>UPDATE TO AIRPORT'S MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR COMMERCIAL AERONAUTICAL ACTIVITIES</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;JOHN BARSALOU - AIRPORT DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should the City approve an update to the Airport's Minimum Standards for Commercial Aeronautical Activities?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>The minimum standards being addressed under this agenda item are specific to <em>commercial aeronautical</em> activities at&nbsp;the Airport.&nbsp;The minimum standards do not apply to non-commercial activities (such as the Forest Service Tanker Base) or non-aeronautical activities (such as car rentals).&nbsp;The FAA highly recommends the&nbsp;use and implementation of minimum standards as a means to minimize the potential for violations of Federal obligations at federally obligated airports. As the Crater Lake - Klamath Regional Airport accepts FAA Airport Improvement Project Program grant funds we are an obligated airport.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The FAA objective in recommending the development of minimum standards serves to promote safety in all airport activities, protect airport users from unlicensed and unauthorized products and services, maintain and enhance the availability of adequate services for all airport users, promote the orderly development of airport land, and ensure efficiency of operations.&nbsp;Such standards must be reasonable and not unjustly discriminatory.&nbsp;The Airport's minimum standards were last updated in October 1995 and, as a result of changing industry standards and terms, are in need of updating.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>No significant changes were made to the types of commercial activities covered under the updated minimum standards or to the levels of service and/or facility requirements for each commercial activity.&nbsp;The most noteworthy changes are:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Removal of references to the Airport Dock Commission;</li>
	<li>Reorganization of the minimum standards to improve readability;</li>
	<li>Greater specificity in regard to&nbsp;requirements for minimum hours of operations, vehicle and aircraft parking; and</li>
	<li>Deleted sections regarding non-commercial activities such as flying clubs, private and corporate hangars and self-fueling activities.</li>
</ol>

<p>The Airport provided notification to all tenants, commercial and non-commercial, of the proposed changes to the Airport's Minimum Standards for Commercial Aeronautical Activities and held a meeting on February 5th to discuss the updated document.&nbsp;No significants issues were raised during the meeting and the Airport received no written comments by the February 8th deadline.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the update to the Airport's Minimum Standards for Commercial Aeronautical Activities.</li>
	<li>Decline the update to the Airport's Minimum Standards for Commercial Aeronautical Activities, and direct staff to revise the document and bring it back to Council for further deliberation.</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp;There are no financial impacts associated with updating the Airport's Minimum Standards.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp; Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>- All Airport Tenants</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Updated Airport Minimum Standards for Commercial Aeronautical Activities</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Feb 19, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.3 </span>UPDATE TO THE AIRPORT'S RULES AND REGULATIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;JOHN BARSALOU - AIRPORT DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City Council approve an update to the Airport's Rules and Regulations?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>The Airport's Rules and Regulations apply to all users of&nbsp;the Airport and persons on any portion of the Airport property, owned or controlled by the City.&nbsp; The Rules and Regulations are intended to:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Protect public health, safety and security of the general public;</li>
	<li>Restrict or prevent any action or activity that interferes with safe and efficient operations of the airport; and</li>
	<li>Ensure the Airport is managed in accordance with City Council's goals and direction.</li>
</ol>

<p>The Airport's Rules and Regulations were last updated in October 2002 and are in need of updating to meet current local, state and federal regulations.&nbsp;<u>Significant updates include</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Addition of a Self-Fueling Policy and permit procedure as a result of City Ordinance 15-03 amending the City Code relating to the Airport Ordinance;</li>
	<li>Addition of private hangar inspections on an annual basis to meet requirements of FAA Policy on non-aeronautical use of airport hangars;</li>
	<li>Addition of section on free speech, religious activity and solicitation;</li>
	<li>Addition of section for special events on airport property to match City requirements;</li>
	<li>Updated language regarding service animals to meet current standards; and</li>
	<li>Addition of language regarding e-cigarettes and marijuana.</li>
</ol>

<p>The Airport provided notification to all tenants of the proposed changes to the Airport's Rules and Regulations, and held a meeting on February 5th to discuss the updated document.&nbsp;No significants issues were raised during the meeting but the Airport did make several minor edits to the draft document based on the feedback received from tenants during the meeting.&nbsp;The Airport received no additional comments by the February 8th deadline.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the update to the Airport's Rules and Regulations.</li>
	<li>Decline the update to the Airport's Rules and Regulations, and direct staff to revise the document and bring it back to Council for further deliberation.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp;There are no financial impacts associated with updating the Airport's Rules and Regulations.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp; Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>- All Airport Tenants</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B9AQ6U653097">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Feb 19, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.4 </span>RURAL OREGON AVIATION RELIEF PROGRAM GRANT APPLICATION</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;JOHN BARSALOU - AIRPORT DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should the Airport submit a Rural Oregon Aviation Relief (ROAR) Program Grant application to the Oregon Department of Aviation in the amount of $500,000 to be used for an air service revenue guarantee?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The Airport has been actively recruiting an air carrier to provide service to the community since the&nbsp;cancellation of service by PenAir in August of 2017.&nbsp; The greatest interest to date has been from SkyWest Airlines which could potentially operate as United Express to San Francisco.&nbsp;While the Airport does not have a firm commitment at this time from SkyWest, the Airport is taking the necessary steps to be prepared should SkyWest, or any other airline, make an offer to provide service.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Small communities, such as Klamath Falls,&nbsp;have been increasingly challenged in recent years to attract and maintain service in light of industry trends that include discontinuing use of aircraft under 50 seats and a stronger emphasis on utilization/profitability of aircraft in markets. Potential markets must prove to potential air carriers that they can profitably fill an aircraft on a proposed route in the long term AND that they can do so better than another market that could&nbsp;utilize the same aircraft.&nbsp;To mitigate the risk associated with establishing service in a new market, it is common to provide an air carrier with a minimum revenue guarantee in addition to other measures to help launch the service.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>While the details of a revenue guarantee would be dependent on the proposed service, in general it would be structured to&nbsp;cover the first year of operation while the new service is getting established. On September 5, 2017 the City Council&nbsp;allocated $250,000 as a match to Klamath County's commitment of $250,000 towards an air service incentive package.&nbsp;The Airport's goal is to have $1,000,000 committed towards a revenue guarantee should an airline propose starting air service in the community.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Oregon Department of Aviation's ROAR program was established to assist rural communities in the state with attracting or retaining air service.&nbsp; The Airport is seeking authorization to submit a grant application under the ROAR program for $500,000 in funds to meet the overall goal of $1,000,000 in revenue guarantee funds.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Authorize the Airport to submit a ROAR grant application.</li>
	<li>Decline to authorize the Airport to submit a ROAR grant application, and give staff further direction.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp; If the Airport is successful in getting a ROAR grant it would greatly enhance the incentive package to a potential air carrier looking to restart air service in the community.&nbsp;Without a ROAR grant the City would need to seek addition funds to offer the same incentive package or offer a smaller incentive package with the risk that our market may no longer be attractive to an air carrier.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>None</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- ROAR Grant Application</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Feb 19, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.5 </span>EXCLUSIVE NEGOTIATING AGREEMENT WITH PROJECT^ FOR THE MAIN AND ESPLANADE SITE REDEVELOPMENT</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Whether or not to enter into an Exclusive Negotiating Agreement with project^ to allow for further due diligence for redevelopment of the Main and Esplanade site?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The Main and Esplanade site, located at a prominent downtown intersection and entry-point has remained vacant for many years with its structures falling into disrepair due to disinvestment. The site, comprising a full City block, was purchased by the City of Klamath Falls in late 2015 utilizing remaining funds from the then expiring Downtown Urban Renewal Plan. Since purchasing the property, the City has completed site preparation and demolition work, furnished studies related to geotechnical, environmental, and land survey material, and will continue readying the site for property redevelopment regardless of agreement with a partner developer. While an Exclusive Negotiating Agreement (ENA) was previously entered with a partner developer to allow for project due diligence and viability assessments, final plans did not matriculate and City staff issued an additional developer Request for Qualifications (RFQ) in December 2018 seeking formation of a public-private partnership. One RFQ submission from project^ was received, and both parties, pending Council approval, desire to move forward to refine development plans and site programming during the proposed 6-month ENA period. Pending outcome of the ENA period, a Disposition and Development Agreement (DDA) may be entered, contingent on future Council approval, which would formalize sales terms, development types and timing of project delivery, and any public contribution. A copy of the draft ENA and the project^ RFQ submission have been attached to this Agenda Report.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1.&nbsp;Authorize staff to enter into discussions&nbsp;for an Exclusive Negotiating Agreement with project^.</p>

<p>2.&nbsp;Decline to act at this time and provide staff further direction.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>There is no direct financial impact to entering into an Exclusive Negotiating Agreement (ENA) with project^ with the exception of involved staff time. Through separate Council approval, the City may continue preparing the subject Main and Esplanade property for redevelopment. Pending outcome of the ENA, the financial terms for and any&nbsp;public participation levels would be formalized through entering into a Disposition and Development Agreement (DDA) for site redevelopment.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Tom Cody, project^</p>

<p>1116 NW 17th Avenue</p>

<p>Portland, OR 97209</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Draft of Exclusive Negotiating Agreement</p>

<p>- RFQ Submission - project^</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Feb 04, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>BUSINESS LICENSE APPLICATION FOR A PROPOSED LIMOUSINE SERVICE</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Whether to approve a proposed Limousine Service - Regal Limo Service - to be operated by Kurt Waldenmaier ("Applicant').</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>Per City Code Section 7.816, “Prior to initiating operation of a taxicab business, the proposed business shall be subject to Council review.” City Code Section 7.812 defines “taxicab” as “a chauffeur-driven motor vehicle for hire used for the transportation of passengers when the destination and route traveled are controlled by a passenger and which is not regulated as a passenger carrier by the State of Oregon.” Section 7.826 requires applicants to submit the proposed flat rate or meter rate to be approved by Council to keep charges uniform throughout the City.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Kurt Waldenmaier, the owner of Regal Limo Service, proposes to run his limousine service as a home occupation through his residence located within the City Limits. The Applicant has submitted documentation outlining his experience and qualifications to engage in such a business together with letters and certificates outlining his safe driver training and achievements. He proposes a flat rate of $80 per hour with a minimum of two hours, and his limousine service will be carried out in a 1999 Lincoln Town Car Stretch Limo. The Applicant’s narrative includes statements relating to his financial ability to support and conduct such a business. If Council approves the limousine service, Applicant will finalize liability insurance documents and provide a copy of the policy to the City Manager, prior to initiating operation of the business.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1.&nbsp;Move to approve the Limousine Service/Business License for Regal Limo Service.</p>

<p>2.&nbsp;Move to deny the Limousine Service/Business License for Regal Limo Service.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: There is no financial impact to the City related to approving&nbsp;the limousine service.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to&nbsp;approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Kurt Waldenmaier</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Sections 7.810-7.840 of the City Code pertaining to the operation of a taxicab</p>

<p>- Applicant’s submitted written statement</p>

<p>- Applicant&nbsp;submitted information and documentation showing experience and qualifications</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Feb 04, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.2 </span>CONSTRUCTION SERVICES CONTRACT WITH ALEX HODGE CONSTRUCTION, INC. FOR THE ALTAMONT DRIVE WATERLINE REPLACEMENT PROJECT PHASE VI IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $557,187</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW934Y6FE44C"><div class="name">Goal #2 - Customer Service</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;SCOTT SOUDERS - CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City execute a construction services contract with Alex Hodge Construction, Inc. in the not-to-exceed amount of $557,187 for construction of the Altamont Drive Waterline Replacement Project Phase VI?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>Over the past 12 years, Klamath County has widened Altamont Drive from South 6th Street to Barry Avenue. The project included widening the roadway to three lanes, lowering the roadway elevation, installing piped storm drainage, and adding curb, gutter and sidewalk. The County’s project was constructed in five phases:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Phase I - South 6th Street to Cannon Avenue (including Crosby Avenue from Washburn Way to Altamont Drive) – COMPLETE</li>
	<li>Phase II – Cannon Avenue to Hilyard Avenue – COMPLETE</li>
	<li>Phase III –Hilyard Avenue to Onyx Avenue – COMPLETE</li>
	<li>Phase IV – Onyx Avenue to Laverne Avenue – COMPLETE</li>
	<li>Phase V – Laverne Avenue to Barry Avenue – COMPLETE</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Although the planned County roadway improvements are complete, the City Water Division has identified existing water main deficiencies between Barry Avenue and Anderson Avenue that warrant further pipeline replacement. The Water Division has determined it is in the best interest of the City to continue with one more phase and replace this segment of waterline similar to the previous five phases.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The existing 6” waterline within this phase (Phase VI) will be replaced with approximately 1150 lineal feet of new 12” water mainline, fire hydrants, and domestic water meter services. As an accompanying opportunity, Klamath County collaborated on the project to include a pavement surface grind and inlay along Altamont Drive between Barry Avenue and Anderson Avenue. The City and County worked together with the design engineer to include both the waterline and pavement work as part of the same project. All work is included within one set of construction documents with the County tasks being tracked separately. The City will execute the construction contract and Klamath County will reimburse for its respective items.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>A formal request for construction bids was publicly advertised in the Herald and News and the Daily Journal of Commerce. A non-mandatory pre-bid meeting was held on December 11, 2018 where bidders had the opportunity to discuss the project with the design team and staff. Bids were received from four companies on December 20, 2018 when they were publicly opened. Each bidder and their total bid price (Bid Schedule A + B)&nbsp;are summarized below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Engineer's Estimate (Published) $565,000 to $625,000</u></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The project was broken out into two separate bid schedules,&nbsp;Bid Schedule ‘A’ being the City waterline work and Bid Schedule ‘B” being the County pavement grind and inlay. The Basis of Award for this project was determined from Bid Schedule ‘A’ and not the total Bid Price. In this instance, Alex Hodge Construction Inc. was lower than Bob’s Excavating Inc. by $2,270. Therefore, Alex Hodge Construction was declared the successful bidder.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve a Contract with Alex Hodge Construction, Inc. in an amount not-to-exceed $557,187.00 and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $55,719.</li>
	<li>Reject a Contract with Alex Hodge Construction, Inc., modify the project scope and rebid the project.</li>
	<li>Reject a Contract with Alex Hodge Construction, Inc. and postpone the project.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>Design Phase and Bid Phase soft cost expenditures are anticipated to total approximately $51,350. Staff anticipates an additional soft cost allowance of $5,750 for construction inspection and materials testing during construction. The total probable project expenditure equals $670,256, including a 10% construction contingency allowance, if necessary.</p>

<p>Refer to the attached Budget Analysis Form for further project detail.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The majority of funds for this project are available through the City’s FY 2018/19 Adopted Budget in the Water Division Capital Outlay Fund ($550,000) plus participation by Klamath County for Bid Schedule ‘B’ ($97,012).</p>

<ol>
	<li>Council Option 1 will utilize FY18/19 funds available for this project.</li>
	<li>Council Option 2 will delay the project and potentially utilize available funds.</li>
	<li>Council Option 3 will cancel the project for construction for the anticipated fiscal year.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to&nbsp;approve<span style="line-height: normal;"> Option 1.</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">- Klamath County Public Works</span></p>

<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.3 </span>CONSTRUCTION SERVICES CONTRACT WITH BOB’S EXCAVATING, INC. FOR AUBURN STREET, FULTON ALLEY, HOLABIRD AVENUE SEWER SPOT REPAIRS PROJECT IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $266,662</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW934Y6FE44C"><div class="name">Goal #2 - Customer Service</div></a>

<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;SCOTT SOUDERS - CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City execute a construction services contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. in the not-to-exceed amount of $266,662 for construction of the Auburn Street, Fulton Alley, Holabird Avenue Sewer Spot Repairs Project?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The City of Klamath Falls Engineering &amp; Water Recovery Divisions have identified the need for several miscellaneous sewer repair projects that are failing or beyond their useful life and are in need of replacement. The sewer mainline in Auburn Street from the alley east of Pacific Terrace to the end, the sewer mainline in an alley between Oregon Avenue and Sargent Avenue between Fulton Street and Delta Street, and the sewer mainline in Holabird Avenue from Van Ness to the northerly high point have been packaged together in this Sewer Replacement Project.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Sewer Spot Repair Project will include spot repairs, lateral connection repairs, sewer mainline replacement and sewer manhole replacements.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>A formal request for construction bids was publicly advertised in the Herald and News and the Daily Journal of Commerce. A non-mandatory pre-bid meeting was held on December 11, 2018 where bidders had the opportunity to discuss the project with the design team and staff. Bids were received from one company on December 20, 2018. The bidder and their price is summarized below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong><u>Engineers Estimate (Published) $ 250,000 to $300,000</u></strong></p>

<p>Bob's Excavating, Inc.&nbsp; &nbsp;$266,662</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Approve a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. in an amount not-to-exceed $266,662 and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $53,332.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Reject a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc, modify the project scope and rebid the project.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Reject a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc and postpone the project.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>Design Phase and Bid Phase expenditures are anticipated to total approximately $26,814. Staff anticipates an additional allowance of $4,250 for construction inspection and materials testing during construction. The total anticipated project expenditure equals $351,308, including a 20% construction contingency allowance if necessary. Refer to the attached Budget Analysis Form for further detail.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Funds for this project are available through the City’s FY 2018/19 Adopted Budget in the Water Recovery Division Capital Outlay Fund. A $355,000 allowance from the Wastewater Capital fund is available for the combined Auburn Street, Fulton Alley, Holabird Avenue Sewer Spot Repairs Project.</p>

<ol>
	<li>Council Option 1, will utilize FY18/19 funds available for this project.</li>
	<li>Council Option 2, will delay the project into next fiscal year and negatively impact the ability to construct during the summer of 2019.</li>
	<li>Council Option 3, will cancel the project for summer of 2019.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to&nbsp;<span style="line-height: normal;">approve&nbsp;Option 1.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">- Bob’s Excavating, Inc.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>In January of each year, or at least prior to the last year's&nbsp;audit review,&nbsp;the Council shall be asked to approve the members of the Audit Advisory Committee. The citizen members are appointed by the Mayor and the other members are the City Manager and two rotating members of City Council. The two proposed citizen members are Andrew Biggs and Kathy Poppe.</p>

<p>The&nbsp;Committee is tentatively scheduled to meet for&nbsp;last year's audit review in March of 2019&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Approve the Committee as presented.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Deny the Committee as presented and suggest changes, giving staff further direction.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: None.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approval&nbsp;Option 1.</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>

<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">9. </span>EXECUTIVE SESSION - No session scheduled at the time the agenda was released.</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">9.1 </span>CLOSED SESSION</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Procedural</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p>The City Council may recess/adjourn to Executive Session under ORS 192.660 as follows: ORS 192.660(2):</p>

<p>(a) - Employment of Public Officers, Employees</p>

<p>(b) - Discipline of Public Officers and Employees and Agents</p>

<p>(d) - Labor Negotiations</p>

<p>(e) - Real Property Transactions</p>

<p>(f) - Exempt Public Records</p>

<p>(g) - Trade Negotiations</p>

<p>(h) - Consultation with Legal Counsel</p>

<p>(i) - Performance Evaluations of Public Officers and Employees</p>

<p>(j) - Public Investments</p>
</div>

<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u><em>Public Comment</em></u> is time reserved&nbsp;for citizens to speak on a matter that is not on the scheduled of the Meeting Agenda. Each person has 3 minutes to speak and must state their name and address for the record (<em>it is preferred that you fill out a Public Comment Form and return it to the City Recorder</em>). If there are multiple people from one Group/Entity that wish to convey "one message" they can have a Group Speaker and, upon request, would be given 5-10 minutes from Council to speak.</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jan 22, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>1ST QUARTER BUDGET ANALYSIS REPORT FOR FISCAL YEAR 2018-2019</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Information</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JESSICA LINDSAY - FINANCE MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Staff presentation of FY 2018-2019 1st Quarter Budget Analysis Report.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>: Attached to this Report are an Investment Summary and an Unaudited Summary of the Revenue and Expenditures for all City funds for the quarter ending September 30, 2018. This represents 25% of transactions for the Fiscal Year. Explanations are provided for revenue and expenditures that have come in with a variance greater than 10% over/under the 25% estimated for the year, or for qualitative purposes. A debt summary page and a spreadsheet of revenues and expenditures have also been included for reference.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>: No options are presented for this Agenda Item.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: There is no fiscal impact associated with this Agenda Item.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Informational only; no action required.</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B89BHC62E258">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jan 22, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.2 </span>A RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING AN INTER-FUND CAPITAL LOAN FROM THE ESCROW RESERVE FUND TO THE SPRING STREET URBAN RENEWAL FUND</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JESSICA LINDSAY - FINANCE MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council approve an inter-fund loan between the Spring Street Urban Renewal Fund and Escrow Reserve Fund to prepare the Main Street and Esplanade Avenue site for development?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>: On November 6, 2017, Council approved the Spring Street Urban Renewal Plan ("Plan"). One of the renewal projects authorized by the Plan is a mixed-use development through a public-private partnership appropriate for the northern downtown Klamath Falls gateway and confluence of Main Street and Esplanade Avenue. In order to develop this property, the site needs to be prepared first which includes demolition of the garage and back filling of the basement, along with other site preparation. It is estimated that the cost to prepare the site for development is at least $500,000.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Under ORS 457.190, an Urban Renewal Fund may borrow money from any source, including the City of Klamath Falls, and pay off the resulting debt using the yearly tax increment revenue. There are sufficient funds in the Escrow Reserve Fund to loan this amount to the Spring Street Urban Renewal Fund. Under Oregon budget law (ORS 294.468), the maximum loan period would be ten (10) years and the interest rate must be comparable with the open market borrowing rate. Staff recommends using 3.44%, which was the tax exempt borrowing rate for a ten (10) year term loan as of 12/18/18, as the interest rate. With these loan terms, the annual payment would be $60,925.74.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>1) Approve the inter-fund loan as presented.</p>

<p>2) Decline to approve the inter-fund loan and provide staff with further direction.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1) This transaction reduces available cash by $500,000, but improves the interest earnings on these funds from the current rate of 2.75% to a fixed rate of 3.44%. Estimated interest earnings over the life of the loan totals $109,257. This represents about a $23,000 increase over current returns.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Citizen Budget Committee</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Proposed Resolution</p>
</div>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B6WPKM5D3AE4">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jan 22, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.3 </span>A RESOLUTION ESTABLISHING A BIENNIAL BUDGET PROCESS FOR THE CITY OF KLAMATH FALLS AND DIRECTING STAFF TO IMPLEMENT IT FOR THE UPCOMING BUDGET PROCESS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: NATHAN CHERPESKI - CITY MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council adopt the attached resolution authorizing and directing staff to prepare a Biennial Budget for the upcoming budget cycle?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>: Staff has studied the process and benefits&nbsp;of shifting to a Biennial Budget for several years.&nbsp;Many cities in Oregon already use this process.&nbsp;City staff reached out to several cities to better understand their process and approach.&nbsp;While the amount of work in the initial year is similar to an annual approach, staff anticipates significant staff time savings during the second fiscal year.&nbsp;The Budget Committee would only need to meet every other year with the option to convene for a brief overview at the mid-point for the budget cycle.&nbsp;This would reduce staff time needed to prepare the budget and would allow limited staff resources to focus on other projects and strategic fiscal planning.&nbsp;The attached proposed resolution establishes the desire to move to a Biennial Budget for the upcoming budget cycle and gives staff direction to prepare it as such.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1. Approve the Resolution as presented.</p>

<p>2. Amend the Resolution prior to approval.</p>

<p>3. Decline to act at this time and give staff further direction.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: Staff anticipates the savings are in <em>staff time</em> in the coming years.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Citizen Budget Committe</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Proposed Resolution</p>
</div>
