<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B82TZG6F212B">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jan 22, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.4 </span>CONTRACT WITH NORTHSIDE FORD TO PURCHASE POLICE VEHICLES - (4) FORD INTERCEPTOR SUVS TO MAINTAIN VEHICLE FLEET</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW92ZV6FAC13"><div class="name">Goal #1 - Citizens feel safe and secure in their homes, work sites, and public places.</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW934Y6FE44C"><div class="name">Goal #2 - Customer Service</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: ROB REYNOLDS - KFPD LIEUTENANT</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: <span style="margin: 0px;">Should the City purchase four new patrol vehicles to maintain an effective patrol fleet and stay in alignment with a seven-year vehicle rotation schedule?</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">For fiscal year 2018-2019, the Police Department was allocated $182,100 through budget approval for the purchase and up-fitting of three (3) patrol vehicles. </span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">Additionally, one (1) of patrol vehicles was recently totaled after being involved in a motor vehicle crash and must be replaced.&nbsp; An investigation into the crash by Oregon State Police determined the citizen that struck our officer was "at fault."&nbsp; The insurance company for the citizen involved agreed to pay for the replacement of a patrol vehicle.&nbsp; The police department received an estimate for the replacement of the patrol vehicle in the amount of $29,000.00. The department will salvage as much equipment as possible out of the totaled patrol vehicle, and the equipment will be up-fitted into one of the new patrol vehicles to off-set the price of the up-fitting. LEHR/Auto Additions quoted $8,595.60 to do the up-fitting and the insurance company for the citizen involved has agreed to also pay for the up-fitting costs.</span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">This purchase aligns with the objective to reduce fleet numbers, while at the same time keeping vehicles to a seven-year rotation schedule.</span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">Four vendors were contacted (Gresham Ford, Northside Ford, Klamath Falls Lithia Ford, and Landmark Ford) regarding the purchase of vehicles.&nbsp; Northside Ford was the low bidder at $140,621.04 for all four (4) patrol vehicles.</span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">The vehicle up-fitting costs and approval will come before Council near the estimated delivery time of the vehicles.</span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">This amount is within the Capital Outlay for the total project costs illustrated below, and will allocate $70,478.96 for the up-fitting of all four (4) vehicles.</span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">-Police Department 2018-2019 CIP Budget for Patrol Vehicles / $182,100</span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">-Vehicle Replacement from Insurance / $29,000</span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">-Purchase of four (4) Patrol Vehicles from Northside Ford / $140,621.04</span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;">-Amount of KFPD CIP for patrol vehicle up-fitting / $70,478.96</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="margin: 0px;">1) </span><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">Authorize the purchase of four (4) Ford SUVs from Northside Ford in the amount of $140,621.04.</span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="margin: 0px;">2) </span><span style="margin: 0px;">Deny purchase and give staff additional direction.</span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="margin: 0px;">The fiscal year 2018-2019 General Fund Budget was approved with $182,100 allocated for Capital Outlay for police department vehicle purchasing. Approval for this portion of this project leaves a remaining balance required for vehicle up-fitting, computer, modem, and other equipment necessary for the police vehicles. This line item will also allow for proper signage and city designations.</span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="margin: 0px;">The insurance company estimated the replacement cost for the totaled 2018 Police Ford Interceptor SUV in the amount of $29,000.00. We will salvage as much equipment possible out of this vehicle to off-set the cost of the up-fitting of the fourth new patrol vehicle. LEHR/Auto Additions quoted $8,595.60 to do this and the insurance company agreed to this quote and will cover the up-fitting of this replacement vehicle.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.&nbsp;<span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;"> </span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Northside Ford</p>

<p>Klamath Falls Lithia Ford</p>

<p>Gresham Ford</p>

<p>Landmark Ford</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p><span style="margin: 0px;">- Informal Solicitation Record for Vehicle Purchases</span></p>

<p><span style="margin: 0px;">- Vehicle Quotes</span></p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jan 22, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.5 </span>CONSULTANT SERVICES CONTRACT EXTENSION WITH JOE SLAUGHTER, AICP FOR ONGOING PLANNING SERVICES IN SUPPORT OF THE CITY'S DEVELOPMENT SERVICES DIVISION</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City retain the services of Joe Slaughter, AICP, through June 30, 2019 to support the ongoing planning needs of the Development Services Division?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>In late 2017 the City’s then Planning Manager vacated his position and there became an immediate need for additional Planning support within the Development Services Division. Joe Wall, the previous Management Assistant to the City Manager, filled the role as Planning Manager though additional support was needed due to&nbsp;an increase in planning activity and Mr. Wall’s ongoing duties from his prior position.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>To support Mr. Wall during his first year as Planning Manager, Staff identified an opportunity to retain the services of private sector planning consultant, Joe Slaughter. Mr. Slaughter was previously employed by the City of Klamath Falls as a Senior Planner for seven years. In 2013, Mr. Slaughter relocated to the Rogue Valley where he has gained further experience working with other local Governments in Southern Oregon as well as private sector clients. He is currently self-employed, offering his land use planning and development services to both private developers and public agencies.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Staff negotiated and Council approved at their February 20, 2018 meeting an agreement with Mr. Slaughter to provide ongoing planning assistance for a flat rate fee of $6,067 per month for 87 hours of service. Joe Slaughter’s current contract is for a twelve-month period which ends on February 22, 2019.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>As the Development Services Division still has need for additional Planning support, Staff asked Joe Slaughter whether he would remain in his contract role for an additional four-month period, ending June 30, 2019 (end of Fiscal year), and at the same terms as the original contract period.&nbsp; Given the current increase in planning activity and the need to focus on bringing City and County rules closer together, it is likely we will need an additional staff person in the near future.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>During the remainder of Joe Slaughter’s contract term and extension, pending approval, a recruitment for an in-house planner position will be completed for long-term needs and contingent on Budget Committee/City Council authorization.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1. Approve a Contract Extension with Joe Slaughter, AICP, to provide professional planning consultant services through June 30, 2019 at a fixed fee amount of $6,067 per month for 87 hours of service. Services beyond the fixed basis to be provided per the terms of the attached Contract Extension Proposal.</p>

<p>2. Reject a Contract Extension with Joe Slaughter, AICP, and advise staff how to proceed with providing planning services.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>The impact of this contract is limited as it will be funded from the unused funds from currently&nbsp;approved positions in the Development Services Division that are unfilled. During the Contract extension period, if approved, City staff will analyze the most cost-effective way to provide these services in the future.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Joe Slaughter, AICP</p>

<p>280 Stanford Avenue</p>

<p>Medford, OR 97504</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Contract Extension Proposal</p>

<p>- Current Contract for Services</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jan 07, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>

<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING A DOWNTOWN RESIDENTIAL PARKING PERMIT, ALLOWING THE CITY MANAGER TO SET THE RATES FOR PARKING FEES, AND IMPOSING DOWNTOWN PARKING FEES BY THE CALENDAR YEAR - 1st Reading - Continued from 12/17/18 Meeting</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: CHRIS&nbsp;RHODE - MANAGEMENT FELLOW</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: <span style="line-height: normal;">Should the City Council establish a Downtown Residential Parking Permit, per&nbsp;section 1.075 set parking fees via the City Manager Fee Schedule, and impose downtown parking fees by the calendar year?</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">This Agenda Item is continued from the City Council Meeting on December 17, 2018.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">The Parking District was created, at the request of downtown business owners, to provide parking for buildings that did not have adequate parking for the use.&nbsp; Many of our older buildings were not built with onsite parking and publicly owned lots allowed them to have higher intensity uses than they could accommodate without the parking.&nbsp; The district is an attempt to get the users or those who directly benefit to pay for the service.&nbsp; With increased discussion around residential uses in the downtown, it seems appropriate to share some of hte costs of maintaining the parking with those who would use the parking.&nbsp; The ordinance makes several changes to streamline permitting and establishes a residential permit for those desiring to park overnight in a City owned parking lot.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">The attached&nbsp;ordinance is comprised of three different sections, each of which makes a different amendment to Chapter 7 of City code pertaining to the Downtown Parking District and the Parking Fund. These sections are as follows:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>1.&nbsp; Establishing a Downtown Residential Parking Permit (Amending Section 7.187)</p>

<p>- The permit is for those desiring to park overnight in a City owned parking lot.&nbsp;This is not a fee assessed to building&nbsp;owners.&nbsp; It is a fee to the owner of the vehicle who will park in a city owned lot.&nbsp; The permit is a monthly permit but may be purchased in other increments up to a year.&nbsp; The fee proposed by the Downtown Parking Advisory Committee is $25 per month.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>2.&nbsp; Allowing&nbsp;per&nbsp;section 1.075 setting the parking fees via the City Manager Fee Schedule (7.160, 7.165, and 7.188)</p>

<p>- The City has been shifting many of these types of similar fees to the Fee Schedule as it is update more regularly.&nbsp; This action does not set a fee, but establishes the process for how the fee is to be periodically adjusted.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>3. Imposing Downtown Parking Permit Fees by the calendar year (7.145)</p>

<p>- The current language sets the permit year to fiscal year of July 1 to June 30.&nbsp; The proposed language would make that the Calendar year.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">At the City Council Meeting on December 17, 2018, further clarification was requested from City Council on Section 1 of this ordinance. This item is not changed in substance, though language pertaining to it has been altered to clarify that the residential permit is being proposed at $25 per month and may be purchased on a month-to-month basis. The $25 per month fee was is the amount suggested by the Downtown Parking Committee, Council is not bound by that suggestion.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Approve amending sections 7.145, 7.160, 7.165(2), 7.187, and 7.188 of City Code.&nbsp; Provide direction to the City Manager on the initial fee that should be charged.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Reject amendments to City Code</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Approve amending sections 7.145, 7.160, 7.165(2), 7.187, and 7.188 of City Code with alternative amendments established by City Council.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Based on current residential parking usage, it is estimated that establishing a residential permit for the Downtown Parking District at a price of $25/month would increase the fund’s revenues by approximately $7500 annually.&nbsp; The City General Fund has been subsidizing the Parking Fund in recent years.&nbsp; Prior to the General Fund subsidy, the Downtown Urban Renewal Area covered many expenses for the district.&nbsp; In order to keep the parking fund from running a deficit, the City will need to drastically increase the subsidy.&nbsp; Current subsidies have been between $15,000 to $20,000.&nbsp; The primary cost driver, aside from enforcement personnel, is maintenance for City owned parking lots.&nbsp; If we maintained the lots at a reasonable level, the subsidy is closer to $50,000 per year.&nbsp; The additional $7,500 reduces the subsidy from the general tax payer by charging it to a user of the service.&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to&nbsp;approve<span style="line-height: normal;"> Option 1.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Members of the Downtown Parking Committee</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Whether<span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"> for Council to recommend a License for Full On-Premises Liquor Sales at David’s Breakfast and Steak House?</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0px 0px 13.33px; -ms-layout-grid-mode: char;">Lucio Cabrera, in conjunction with David’s Breakfast and Steak House is applying for a new outlet Liquor License to allow Full On-Premises sales at their restaurant establishment located at 2065 Oregon Avenue.&nbsp; This would allow the sale of distilled spirits, malt beverages, wine, and cider for consumption at the licensed business.<span style="margin: 0px;">&nbsp; </span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px 0px 13.33px; -ms-layout-grid-mode: char;">This new restaurant opened in November, 2018 at the former Waffle Hut restaurant location.<span style="margin: 0px;"> Waffle Hut previously operated with a Limited On-Premises Sales License. </span>The business location is zoned Neighborhood Commercial and the operation of a retail outlet is consistent with the zoning.<span style="margin: 0px;">&nbsp;</span>The business will be open daily from 7 a.m. until 9 p.m.</p>

<p style="margin: 0px 0px 13.33px; -ms-layout-grid-mode: char;">Notice was sent on December 19, 2018 to adjacent property owners within a 100-foot radius of the business location and no responses have been received. The Police Department notified Planning Staff there were no license disqualifying items.&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1. Move to recommend to OLCC the approval of Full On-Premises liquor sales for David's Breakfast and Steak House.</p>

<p>2.&nbsp;Move to not recommend the allowance of Full On-Premises liquor sales for David's Breakfast and Steak House.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;">There is no financial impact related to making a recommendation to OLCC.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Move to approve Option 1.</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jan 07, 2019 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LAND USE PUBLIC HEARING - QUASI JUDICIAL</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.1 </span>CONSIDERATION OF LAND USE APPLICATIONS 12-DESIGN REVIEW-18 AND 3-CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT-18</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Whether to approve Land Use Applications 12-Design Review-18 and 3-Conditional Use Permit-18 and allow for the construction of a government office building within the Timbermill Shores subdivision.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>Appellants, Sky Lakes Medical Center, Inc. and Klamath Works, Inc. are appealing a Planning Commission decision to approve an approximately 92,000 sq. ft. three-story office building with the Oregon Department of Human Services (DHS) as primary tenant (Klamath Falls Holdings, LLC, applicant). The subject site is presently undeveloped and comprises Lots 10, 12, and 13 of Tract 1430 - TimberMill Shores. The site can be found on Klamath County Tax Assessor Map R-3809-032AC Tax Lots 10500, 10600 and 10700. The facility is to be accessed from three commercial driveways along Timbermill Drive, Sydney Way, and S. 4th Street with primary building frontage oriented towards Timbermill Drive. New pedestrian pathways are to be constructed adjacent to the northerly boundaries of Lots 12 &amp; 13 and adjacent to the easterly boundary of Lot 13 within the existing pedestrian access easements as identified on Tract 1430-TimberMill Shores. A 242-space surface parking lot is proposed to serve office employees, clients, and visitors. Landscaping is to be provided throughout the 3.94-acre property along lot perimeters, street frontages, and within parking areas. Government office uses are conditionally permitted within Mixed-Use zoning with the proposed project to be reviewed according to Conditional Use Permit application criteria. The development of the site must also be reviewed under the criteria for a Design Review.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Design Review and Conditional Use Permit applications are typically reviewed at an administrative level; however, Community Development Ordinance (CDO) Section 10.805 gives the Director authority to initiate a hearing in front of the Planning Commission if he determines that persons other than the applicant can be expected to question the compliance of the application with relevant zone requirements and site standard requirements. Given the amount of public interest in the proposed use, the Director chose to schedule these applications for a hearing in front of the Planning Commission rather than rendering an administrative decision.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Planning Commission held a public hearing on October 8, 2018 to consider the applications. At that meeting the Commission heard a presentation from staff and took testimony regarding the applications. On the request of opponents and the Applicant, the Commission closed the public&nbsp;hearing, left the written record open, and scheduled deliberations and decision of the Commission for November 7, 2018. &nbsp;At the November 7th meeting, the Commission passed a motion to approve the applications and a final order approving Design Review 12-DR-18 and Conditional Use Permit 3-CUP-18 was signed and mailed on November 8, 2018.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Per Community Development Ordinance (CDO) Section 10.405(2), the decision of the Commission shall be final unless a notice of appeal to the Council is filed within 12 business days of the date of mailing of the Commission’s final decision. A notice of appeal was received from Ellen Grover with the law firm Karnopp Peterson, LLP on behalf of Sky Lakes Medical Center, Inc. on November 26, 2018, within the appeal period. A second notice of appeal was received from attorney Michael Spencer on behalf of Klamath Works Inc. on November 27, 2018, within the appeal period.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>RELEVANT REVIEW CRITERIA, FACTS, AND ANALYSIS</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">Upon receiving an appeal of a Planning Commission decision, the Council shall conduct a public hearing on the appeal. The review of the decision of the Planning Commission shall be de novo, trying the matter anew, and shall include:</span></p>

<ul>
	<li>All materials, pleadings, memoranda, stipulations and motions submitted by any party to the proceeding and received or considered by the Planning Commission;</li>
	<li>All materials submitted by the Planning Staff with respect to the Application;</li>
	<li>The minutes of the hearing before the Planning Commission; and</li>
	<li>The findings and action of the Planning Commission and the notice of appeal. (CDO Sections 10.430 &amp; 10.435)</li>
</ul>

<p>All required materials are included in this agenda packet as Exhibits 2-15 and 17-20 (see below).&nbsp;In addition to the required materials, the Findings and Final Decision recommended by staff is attached as Exhibit 1 and a summary of substantive changes to staff's original proposed findings included in the Applicant’s Findings and Final Decision (received October 29, 2018) is attached as Exhibit 16.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The relevant review criteria, facts, and analysis relative to the applications are provided within the Findings and Final Decision recommended by staff (Exhibit 1). The Findings and Final Decision recommended by staff have been adapted from the Applicant’s proposed Findings and Final Decision, submitted on October 29, 2018 which are attached as Exhibit 15. Having been submitted after the October 8, 2018 Planning Commission hearing and after all opponent testimony and Applicant rebuttal, the Applicant’s findings are a more complete set of findings than staff’s original findings which were drafted prior to the October 8th hearing. Because the Applicant’s findings incorporate much of staff’s findings but are more complete, staff recommends the Applicant’s findings as adopted in the Findings and Final Decision (Exhibit 1) be used should the Council choose to approve the applications.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>Hold a public hearing and take testimony; and do one of the options listed below:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>1. Approve with modified Applicant’s findings:</p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p>Motion to accept the Findings and Final Decision recommended by staff (Exhibit 1) and approve Design Review 12-DR-18 and Conditional Use Permit 3-CUP-18 to construct an approximately 92,000 square foot three-story office building with the Oregon Department of Human Services (DHS) as primary tenant on Lots 10, 12 and 13 of Tract 1430-TimberMill Shores, subject to the conditions listed within the Findings and Final Decision document (Exhibit 1).</p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p>2. Approve with modified findings:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Motion to approve modified findings and/or conditions of approval as defined by Council (list modifications).</li>
	<li>Based on the approved findings; Motion to approve Design Review 12-DR-18 and Conditional Use Permit 3-CUP-18 to construct an approximately 92,000 square foot three-story office building with the Oregon Department of Human Services (DHS) as primary tenant on Lots 10, 12 and 13 of Tract 1430-Timbermill Shores,&nbsp;subject to the conditions listed within the Findings and Final Decision document (Exhibit 1).</li>
</ul>

<p>3. Option to Deny:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Motion to direct staff to modify findings to support denial of Design Review 12-DR-18 and Conditional Use Permit 3-CUP-18 based on direction from the Council.</li>
	<li>Motion to deny Design Review 12-DR-18 and Conditional Use Permit 3-CUP-18 to construct an approximately 92,000 square foot three-story office building with the Oregon Department of Human Services (DHS) as primary tenant on Lots 10, 12 and 13 of Tract 1430-TimberMill Shores, based on the modified findings.</li>
</ul>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: No known direct financial impact.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to&nbsp;approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Klamath Falls Holdings, LLC</p>

<p>2870 Nansen Drive</p>

<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u><em>Public Comment</em></u> is time reserved&nbsp;for citizens to speak on a matter that is not on the scheduled of the Meeting Agenda. Each person has 3 minutes to speak and must state their name and address for the record (<em>it is preferred that you fill out a Public Comment Form and return it to the City Recorder</em>). If there are multiple people from one Group/Entity that wish to convey "one message" they can have a Group Speaker and, upon request, would be given 5-10 minutes from Council to speak.</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B793VU03F586">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Dec 17, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">5. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">5.1 </span>AN ORDINANCE AMENDING KLAMATH FALLS CITY CODE SECTIONS 7.145, 7.160, 7.165(2), 1.187 AND 7.188 ESTABLISHING A DOWNTOWN RESIDENTIAL PARKING PERMIT, INCORPORATING PARKING PERMIT FEES INTO THE CITY MANAGER’S FEE SCHEDULE, AND IMPOSING FEES BY THE CALENDAR YEAR - FIRST READING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT</u><u> GIVEN BY</u>: CHRISTOPHER RHODE - MANAGEMENT FELLOW</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: <span style="line-height: normal;">Should&nbsp;City Council establish a Downtown Residential Parking Permit, and set&nbsp;the rates for parking fees </span>pursuant to Section 1.075&nbsp;to set <span style="line-height: normal;">via the fee schedule, and impose downtown parking fees by the calendar year?</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">This Ordinance is comprised of three different sections, each of which makes a different amendment to Chapter 7 of City Code pertaining to the Downtown Parking District and the Parking Fund.</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Establishing a Downtown Residential Parking Permit (Amending Section 7.187)</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The Downtown Parking District has operated with part-time employee, full-time employee, and reserved parking permits;<font style="background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"> </font><font style="background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">h</font>owever, no residential permit has been established. Establishing a downtown residential parking permit is a stated goal of the Downtown Parking Fund. On November 14, 2018, the Downtown Parking Committee unanimously recommended establishing a downtown residential parking permit with an annual fee of $300.</p>

<ol start="2">
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Allow parking fees to be amended pursuant to Section 1.075.</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Currently fees are changed by City Council after a public hearing. The fees for parking have not kept up with the cost of providing parking. We have only raised the fees a few times since they were introduced. Rates were last increased in 2004. If fees for fulltime employee had kept up with inflation they would be more than $85 per year and not $65. Utilizing section 1.075 would allow the fees to be adjusted more regularly. Under that process Council would still have the ability to bring the fees to Council for hearing if desired.</p>

<ol start="3">
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Imposing Downtown Parking Permit Fees by the calendar year (7.145)</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align: justify;">City Code currently specifies that employee parking permits be assessed from a period of July 1 through June 30. However, it has been the practice of City staff to assess downtown employee parking permits with the renewal of business licenses, which utilize the period of January 1 to December 31. These revisions will align current practice with City Code.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Hold a Public Hearing; and introduce Proposed Ordinance for first reading by title only.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Approve amending sections 7.145, 7.160, 7.165(2), 7.187, and 7.188 of City Code; with alternative amendments established by Council.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Reject amendments to City Code.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">The Downtown Parking District Fund currently has annual expenses that exceed revenues by approximately $20,000. It is estimated that establishing a residential permit for the Downtown Parking District at a price of $300/year would increase the fund’s revenues by approximately $7,500 annually. </span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to&nbsp;<span style="line-height: normal;">approve Option 1.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Members of the Downtown Parking Committee</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Proposed Ordinance</span></p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Dec 17, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">5. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">5.2 </span>AN ORDINANCE ADDING SECTION 5.250 TO THE CITY OF KLAMATH FALLS CODE AND AMENDING SECTION 5.290 RELATING TO ESTABLISHING ENHANCED LAW ENFORCEMENT AREAS AND THE CRIMINAL OFFENSE OF PERSISTENT VIOLATION - FIRST READING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW92ZV6FAC13"><div class="name">Goal #1 - Citizens feel safe and secure in their homes, work sites, and public places.</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: DAVE HENSLEE - CHIEF OF POLICE</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: <span style="margin: 0px;">Should the City of Klamath Falls adopt an ordinance to allow Council the ability to create Enhanced Law Enforcement Areas and provide the City of Klamath Falls Municipal Court Judge with the authority to exclude habitual offenders from those areas?</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">City Police Officers and community citizens have observed there is an ongoing problem in certain, specific areas of the City with persons who are persistent and repetitive violators of various state criminal laws and City Code provisions that are intended to improve the livability of our community. This </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(17, 17, 17);">unlawful </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(36, 36, 36);">activity can become an attraction for more </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(54, 54, 54);">such activ</span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(17, 17, 17);">ity, </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(36, 36, 36);">including attracting other violators </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(17, 17, 17);">to </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(36, 36, 36);">these areas because of opportunities to </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(54, 54, 54);">engage </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(17, 17, 17);">in, </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(36, 36, 36);">or </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(17, 17, 17);">to </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(36, 36, 36);">contact others to </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(54, 54, 54);">engage </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(17, 17, 17);">in, unla</span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(54, 54, 54);">wfu</span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(17, 17, 17);">l </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(36, 36, 36);">activity.</span></span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; text-align: justify;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="margin: 0px;">Enhanced penalties for persistent violators may persuade the violators to modify their behavior and excluding such violators from a designated “Enhanced Law Enforcement Area” is likely to improve community livability within the exclusion area. The purpose of Enhanced Law Enforcement and Exclusion Areas is to pursue chronic offenders in specific, designated areas in an effort to modify their behavior and through exclusion of the chronic offender, improve and enhance community livability.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0px 0px 0px 48px; line-height: normal; text-indent: -0.5in;">1)<span style="margin: 0px;">&nbsp;&nbsp;Hold a Public Hearing; Move to </span><span style="margin: 0px;">introduce Ordinance for first reading by title only.&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt 0.5in; text-indent: -0.5in;"><span style="margin: 0px;">2)&nbsp; Reject the&nbsp;Ordinance and provide Staff with additional direction. </span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">The City of Klamath Falls will experience future costs to lodge Persistent Violation Offenders at the Klamath County Jail.<span style="margin: 0px;"> </span>Those additional costs are unknown at this time.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;<span style="margin: 0px; padding: 0in; border: 1pt windowtext; border-image: none;">Council to approve&nbsp;Option 1.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: N/A</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED:</u></p>

<p>&nbsp;- Proposed Ordinance</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B6WRJG63F856">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Dec 17, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>AGATE STREET ACCEPTANCE OF DEEDS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;MICHAEL SWANSON - CITY ATTORNEY</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Shall City Council authorize the City Manager to accept the deeds conveying to the City a right-of-way,as&nbsp;set&nbsp;forth in the attached documents?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>: Earlier this year, while preparing for the development of a parcel of land abutting Agate Street, a surveying error was discovered.&nbsp; Due to the various land transfers and deeds that had been recorded over the years, it was unclear who owned that strip of land.&nbsp;In order to clarify the ownership of that parcel, the City sought and received multiple Bargain and Sale Deeds from all parties who may have had a claim of ownership. Those deeds were fully executed and recorded, transferring to the city any and all interest that the parties had in the land in question.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>ORS 93.808 requires that any instrument which conveys to a city in this state either title or an interest in real property must include an approval and acceptance of the conveyance by the political subdivision receiving the interest.&nbsp; The recorded deeds do not contain such language.&nbsp; By authorizing the City Manager to accept the deeds referenced in the attached document, the Council will cure this defect.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>1)&nbsp; Authorize the City Manager to execute the&nbsp;Acceptance of Deeds&nbsp;on behalf of the City.&nbsp;</p>

<p>2)&nbsp; Do Not authorize the City Manager to accept the deeds and further advise staff.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: N/A</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>5 Star OR, LLC</p>

<p>Ruben Perez and Lola Perez</p>

<p>Freddie L. Donahue</p>

<p>John M. Harrison and Laura L. Harrison</p>

<p>Christine L. Eddy</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Proposed Acceptance of Deeds</p>
</div>

<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u><em>Public Comment</em></u> is time reserved&nbsp;for citizens to speak on a matter that is not on the scheduled of the Meeting Agenda. Each person has 3 minutes to speak and must state their name and address for the record (<em>it is preferred that you fill out a Public Comment Form and return it to the City Recorder</em>). If there are multiple people from one Group/Entity that wish to convey "one message" they can have a Group Speaker and, upon request, would be given 5-10 minutes from Council to speak.</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B6XU8E69E6AD">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Dec 03, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">5. </span>CONSENT AGENDA</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">5.2 </span>RATIFYING THE SELECTION OF THE KLAMATH COUNTY ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION AS THE ENTERPRISE ZONE MANAGER FOR THE KLAMATH FALLS/KLAMATH COUNTY ENTERPRISE ZONE</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: NATHAN CHERPESKI - CITY MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council ratify the selection of Klamath County Economic Development Association ("KCEDA") as the local Enterprise Zone Manager?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>As part of the current fiscal year budgeting, KCEDA proposed to manage the local enterprise zone for no additional funding beyond their current contracted support.&nbsp;The Budget Committee recommended a budget assuming KCEDA&nbsp;would manage the enterprise zone.&nbsp;As a Co-Sponsor the City has to agree with any change to the local manager.&nbsp;In conversations with the County Liaison for economic development, it appears that they are ready and willing to make such an appointment and would like us to support and ratify this change.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Authorize the Mayor to send a letter to the State noticing the change of local enterprise zone manager.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Decline to act at this time and give staff further direction.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>We used to pay approximately $3,000 per year ($6,000 split 50/50 with the County).&nbsp;This would save the $3,000 per year, but we also support KCEDA at a much higher amount than that in years past.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>KCEDA</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>: None.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
</div>
<div filetype="public" parentid="B6XU8E69E6AD" class="bothcols ui-helper-clearfix"></div>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B6WP895B6629">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Dec 03, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>ORDINANCE AMENDING KLAMATH FALLS CODE SECTIONS 7.202, 7.205, 7.210, 7.225, 7.227 AND7.235 REGARDING RECREATIONAL MARIJUANA TAXES ON SALES AND ADDING SECTIONS 7.236 AND 2.470 THROUGH 2.474 ESTABLISHING AN ALTERNATIVE METHOD OF COLLECTING THE SALES TAX AND CREATING AN ADVISORY COMMITTEE CONCERNING THE REGULATION OF THE MARIJUANA INDUSTRY</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: MICHAEL SWANSON - CITY ATTORNEY</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: What structure does the Council want to have&nbsp;for the Advisory Committee in relation to&nbsp;implementation of Measure 18-112 which goes into effect on February 1, 2019?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;A majority of the citizens of the City voted in favor of Measure 18-112 which repealed the ban on recreational marijuana in Klamath Falls, set a tax rate on the sales of recreational marijuana, and created an advisory committee to assist the Council in creating regulations to control how, when and where marijuana facilities may operate.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Previously, the Council adopted interim rules for the regulation of marijuana facilities which amended those currently in place pertaining to medical marijuana facilities.&nbsp; During a recent work session, staff provided drafts of amendments to the Code to address the remaining components of Measure 18-112, namely the tax and committee prongs of Measure 18-112.&nbsp; Staff prepared four drafts for Council consideration based upon feedback during that work session.&nbsp; The tax sections (Sections 1 and 2) proposed in each draft are identical.&nbsp; The advisory committee section (Section 3) differs only in the composition of the committee.&nbsp; Drafts 1A and 1B limit committee participation to City residents.&nbsp; Drafts 2A and 2B require a minimum of four members of the committee to be citizens. Drafts 1B and 2B include a requirement that one member of the committee must be selected from the Planning Commission. This proposal arose from a suggestion at a recent work session with the Planning Commission.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1) Hold a public hearing.</p>

<p>2) Move to&nbsp;introduce the Ordinance selected by Council for&nbsp;first reading by title only.</p>

<p>3) Choose none of the versions and instruct staff on how to redraft.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: There is no financial impact anticipated other than the collection of the tax.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to hold a Public Hearing,&nbsp;and&nbsp;introduce the Ordinance selected by Council for&nbsp;first reading by title only.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: N/A</p>

<p>Posted as part of the Agenda and notice to any Interested Parties</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Proposed Ordinance (Versions: 1A; 1B; 2A; and 2B)</p>
</div>
<div filetype="public" parentid="B6WP895B6629" class="bothcols ui-helper-clearfix">



<a class="public-file" target="_blank" order="00001" unique="B6Y6S71648DB" href="/or/cokf/Board.nsf/files/B6Y6S71648DB/$file/Ordinance%20MJ%20Committee%20Setup-Draft%201A.pdf">Ordinance MJ Committee Setup-Draft 1A.pdf (181 KB)</a><a class="public-file" target="_blank" order="00002" unique="B6Y6U2168EDC" href="/or/cokf/Board.nsf/files/B6Y6U2168EDC/$file/Ordinance%20MJ%20Committee%20Setup-Draft%201B.pdf">Ordinance MJ Committee Setup-Draft 1B.pdf (181 KB)</a><a class="public-file" target="_blank" order="00003" unique="B6Y6VL16C87F" href="/or/cokf/Board.nsf/files/B6Y6VL16C87F/$file/Ordinance%20MJ%20Committee%20Setup-Draft%202A.pdf">Ordinance MJ Committee Setup-Draft 2A.pdf (181 KB)</a><a class="public-file" target="_blank" order="00004" unique="B6Y6Z2174A70" href="/or/cokf/Board.nsf/files/B6Y6Z2174A70/$file/Ordinance%20MJ%20Committee%20Setup-Draft%202B.pdf">Ordinance MJ Committee Setup-Draft 2B.pdf (182 KB)</a></div>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B6W6QH11D3FB">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Dec 03, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.1 </span>AUTHORIZE CONSULTANT SERVICES CONTRACT WITH CIVICPLUS, INC. FOR CITY WEBSITE DESIGN AND HOSTING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW934Y6FE44C"><div class="name">Goal #2 - Customer Service</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JEREMY PRINSEN - HUMAN RESOURCES AND TECHNOLOGY SERVICES MANAGER, SUPPORT SERVICES DEPARTMENT</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council designate CivicPlus, Inc. as Consultant for the City of Klamath Falls' website redesign and hosting <span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">in an amount not to exceed $29,970 and an annual subscription fee for three Fiscal Years</span>?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The Technology Services Division has identified the need to improve the capabilities and performance of the current City website. The current website was implemented many years ago when there was significantly less emphasis placed on web presence, ease of customer use, and citizen self-service. Since that time, technologies have significantly shifted to "responsive" web design that includes mobile phones and tablets. There is also an increased focus on ease of use and accessibility. The City has reached the point where the current website and host platform no longer meet the needs of our citizens and staff.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>For Fiscal Year 2018-19, the City budgeted $30,000 to upgrade the existing website, including the following:</p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p>$ 4,850 annual license/support</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>$25,120 project management, consulting, design, implementation, and training</p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p>The City received proposals from CivicPlus, Inc., CivicLive, Municode, OrNsoft, and OPIN Software. A Review Committee comprised of City Manager Nathan Cherpeski, Support Services Director Brooke Marshall, Information Systems Administrator Andy Shadley, Public Information Administrative Assistant Kristina Buckley, and me, ranked each of the proposals using an objective scoring criteria and determined that the features, functionality and overall cost from CivicPlus, Inc. is the best fit for the City. Designing and implementing a new City website with CivicPlus, Inc. will yield the following benefits:</p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p>A beautiful, modern, and fully responsive web presence for the City of Klamath Falls</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Fully responsive web design the works equally well on mobile devices</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>A finished website that meets Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) accessibility requirements</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Clean, simple, and intuitive navigation</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Less reliance on the host provider for making content changes</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>A powerful and robust content management platform for third-party self-service integration</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Inclusion of all other City websites (<a href="http://www.kfpd.us/">www.kfpd.us</a>, <a href="http://www.flykfalls.com/">www.flykfalls.com</a>, www.ellaredkeypool.com)</p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p>Entering into an agreement with CivicPlus, Inc. requires a one-year contract containing implementation fees and an annual subscription fee. The annual subscription fee will continue in the following years and may increase at a rate of up to 5% each year beginning with the third Fiscal Year, necessitating that the subscription amount is included in the annual budgeting process. The City has been paying, on average, about $4,140-$4,500 per year to Wrinkledog for the City's website, Ella Redkey Pool website, Police Department website, and Airport website. The amount of $4,140 is paid if there are no changes to the website during the year.&nbsp; Changes are billed for in addition to the regular fee.</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Nov 19, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>INTERIM RULES FOR RECREATIONAL MARIJUANA - ORDINANCE AMENDING KLAMATH FALLS CODE SECTIONS 7.250 TO 7.255, 7.270, AND 5.237 REGARDING MARIJUANA FACILITIES AND SALES</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: MICHAEL SWANSON - CITY ATTORNEY</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City Council adopt interim rules for recreational marijuana businesses until an advisory committee can be formed to provide recommendations?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>While measure 18-112 recently passed, it doesn't go into effect until February 1, 2019.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Specifically, the proposed ordinance does the following:</p>

<p>(1) Klamath Falls City Ordinance 15-14, passed by the City of Klamath Falls on the 21<sup>st</sup><sup>&nbsp;</sup>day of September 2015, shall be repealed.</p>

<p>(2) A three percent City tax will be imposed on marijuana retail sales in the City of Klamath Falls.</p>

<p>(3) A cannabis advisory committee shall be established for the purpose of advising and making recommendations to Klamath Falls City Council regarding state policies and regulations concerning the marijuana industry and how it impacts the community. A majority of the committee members are persons who are Oregon license holders, license applicants, or otherwise knowledgeable persons of the cannabis industry.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The City currently has rules that govern Medical Marijuana businesses.&nbsp;In order to achieve consistency in how the City regulates marijuana sales, staff proposes adopting interim regulations that control businesses that sell recreational marijuana. While the committee discussed above is to advise on "state policies and regulations concerning the marijuana industry," staff assumes it was the intent to also play an advisory role on any local regulation.&nbsp;In order to allow for an orderly adoption of rules and regulations as advised by the committee,&nbsp;some interim rules should be adopted.&nbsp;These rules would govern until such time as the advisory committee can report out proposed guidelines and rules to the City Council.&nbsp; For simplicity at this time, and to keep medical and recreational businesses on a similar footing, staff proposes to either amend or mirror the existing medical marijuana rules and apply those in a like manner to recreational marijuana businesses.&nbsp;Since these rules&nbsp;are temporary in nature, staff is not proposing any changes to the current buffer areas or restrictions.&nbsp; Any adjustments would rightly fall to the advisory committee to propose to the City Council.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The proposed ordinance in front of Council relating to this agenda item is&nbsp;speci﻿fically to set&nbsp;interim rules. Staff will return with another ordinance based on Council direction for the make up of the advisory committee.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1) Introduce the attached ordinance as presented; and read it by title only.</p>

<p>2) Amend the ordinance; and introduce the ordinance as amended by title only.</p>

<p>3) Decline to act at this time and provide staff further direction.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: There are no immediate fiscal impacts for the interim rules.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: N/A</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Proposed Ordinance</p>

<a class="public-file" target="_blank" order="00001" unique="B6JSQJ6A32D4" href="/or/cokf/Board.nsf/files/B6JSQJ6A32D4/$file/MJ%20Ordinance%20Rev%2011-15-18.pdf">MJ Ordinance Rev 11-15-18.pdf (90 KB)</a></div>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B6A42W7B5614">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Nov 19, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.1 </span>DESIGN SERVICES CONTRACT WITH JUB ENGINEERS, INC. FOR THE 4TH STREET TO 7TH STREET GEOTHERMAL PIPELINE REPLACEMENT PROJECT IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $53,700</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW934Y6FE44C"><div class="name">Goal #2 - Customer Service</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;SCOTT SOUDERS - CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City execute a consultant services contract with JUB Engineers in the not-to-exceed amount of $53,700 to prepare construction documents and assist with construction administration services for the 4th Street to 7th Street Geothermal Pipeline Replacement Project?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>: The City Geothermal Division has identified the need to replace approximately 1,200 lineal feet of existing 6” and 8” geothermal distribution pipeline within the alleyway between Walnut Street and Klamath Avenue from S. 7th Street to S. 4th Street, and in S. 4th Street from said alleyway to its connection with existing pipeline in Klamath Avenue. See attached Figure 1 illustrating the project limits.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In recent years, the existing distribution pipeline has experienced numerous failures and leaks that have led to multiple emergency repairs. The pipeline has been found to be severely decayed and in need of replacement. Replacing this pipeline will both decrease maintenance costs while also increase system reliability and capacity allowing full development of the heating system within the Timbermill Shores Development. Due to limited funds, the project will be evaluated for phasing opportunities during the design process.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Staff sought a design firm with specific experience in designing geothermal systems. Headquartered in Boise, ID, JUB Engineers has ten years of experience working with the City of Boise’s geothermal system. Projects range from hydraulic modeling and master planning, to piping and valve research, to final design and specifications for system improvements. JUB has further completed dozens of miles of new and rehabilitated geothermal pipeline work for multiple cities and service districts around the Boise area.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Following a site tour of the Klamath Falls geothermal system, JUB prepared the attached services proposal for the 4th Street to 7th Street Geothermal Pipeline Replacement Project. The proposal under consideration is for construction document preparation of the entire project limits. During preliminary design, the project will be evaluated to determine if phasing opportunities are warranted and, if so, the project will be divided into separate bid packages in order to construct over multiple fiscal budget years. The City anticipates construction of the first phase to occur during the summer of 2019.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the Design Services Proposal with JUB Engineers, Inc. in the not-to-exceed amount of $53,700.</li>
	<li>Deny the Design Services Proposal with JUB Engineers, Inc.; revise the scope and request a new proposal.</li>
	<li>Deny the Design Services Proposal with JUB Engineers, Inc.; and cancel project to a future date.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>The FY2018-2019 Adopted Budget identifies a Geothermal Division capital outlay allocation of $250,000 for Geothermal Distribution Pipeline Upgrade/Replacement.</p>

<ol>
	<li>Council Option 1 will utilize funds available for this project.</li>
	<li>Council Option 2 may utilize funds available for this project.</li>
	<li>Council Option 3 would not utilize funds available for this project.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to&nbsp;approve&nbsp;Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Nov 19, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.2 </span>DESIGN SERVICES CONTRACT WITH ADKINS ENGINEERING FOR THE DAYTON-FRIEDA-DERBY WATERLINE PROJECT IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $99,800</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW934Y6FE44C"><div class="name">Goal #2 - Customer Service</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: SCOTT SOUDERS - CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City execute a consultant services contract with Adkins Engineering in the not-to-exceed amount of $99,800 to prepare construction documents and assist with construction administration for the Dayton-Frieda-Derby Waterline Project?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The City Water Division has identified an ongoing need to replace aging and undersized 2” water mains within the water system. Leak repair on the existing steel mains is a major operational expense. Replacement of these pipelines will reduce unaccounted water loss and maintenance costs as well as provide for adequate fire flow requirements within the respective residential areas.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Replacement of the waterlines within Dayton Street, Frieda Avenue, and Derby Street were originally planned as three separate projects spanning three fiscal years: FY18/19; FY19/20; and FY20/21 respectively. Due to their proximity to one another, staff has determined that there would be a cost savings in both design and construction by combining these three projects into a single construction package.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Adkins Engineering was approached by staff to prepare a proposal for design services of the Dayton, Frieda and Derby Water Main Replacement Project. Their proposal and a project location exhibit can be found in the attached documents. The City anticipates bidding the project in January of 2020 with construction between the months of March and October of 2020.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S):</u></p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the Design Services Proposal from Adkins Engineering in the amount of $99,800.</li>
	<li>Deny the Design Services Proposal from Adkins Engineering and formally advertise the project.</li>
	<li>Deny the Design Services Proposal from Adkins Engineering, revise the scope and request a new proposal.</li>
	<li>Deny the Design Services Proposal from Adkins Engineering and delay the project to a future date.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>The FY 2018-2019 adopted budget identifies a Water Division capital outlay allocation of $350,000 for the Dayton Street Main Replacement and $75,000 for design of the Frieda Avenue Main Replacement. Further, the current CIP projects additional allocations for design and construction of both the Frieda and Derby water main replacements in FY19/20 and FY20/21.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The revised packaging of all three projects is intended to reduce overall costs through design service efficiencies and by encouraging additional contractor interest in a larger project, thereby resulting in more competitive bidding. The revised approach will delay the construction start date into FY19/20 but should result in a completion date ahead of the original projection of summer 2021. Construction budget dollars will be reallocated into the FY19/20 and FY20/21 budget cycles.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>- <u>Council Option 1</u> will utilize budgeted funds available for this project.</p>

<p>- <u>Council Options 2 &amp; 3</u> may utilize funds available for this project.</p>

<p>- <u>Council Option 4</u> would not utilize funds available for this project.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;- Adkins Engineering (Jon Moritz)</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;- Consultant Scope &amp; Fee Proposal</p>

<p>&nbsp;- Project Site Exhibit Map (Figure 1)</p>

<p>&nbsp;- Consultant Services Contract with Exhibit A</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Nov 19, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.4 </span>PURCHASE AND UP-FITTING OF FOUR (4) POLICE FORD INTERCEPTOR SUVS FOR THE POLICE DEPARTMENT</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: ROB REYNOLDS - LIEUTENANT KFPD</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City purchase four new patrol vehicles to maintain an effective patrol fleet and to stay in alignment with a seven-year vehicle rotation schedule?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>For fiscal year 2018-2019, the Police Department was allocated $182,100 through budget approval for the purchase and up-fitting of three vehicles.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Additionally, one of our new patrol vehicles was recently totaled after being involved in a motor vehicle crash and will need to be replaced.&nbsp; The collision was a result of a citizen not yielding to an emergency vehicle and Oregon State Police determined the KFPD member was not at fault.&nbsp; We received an estimate for the "replacement value" of the 2018 patrol interceptor from the insurance company in the amount of $29,000.00. We are salvaging as much equipment as possible out of the totaled patrol vehicle, and it will be up-fitted into one of the new patrol vehicles to off-set the price of the up-fitting. LEHR/Auto Additions quoted $8,595.60 to do this and the insurance company agreed to this quote and will cover the up-fitting of this replacement vehicle.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>This purchase aligns with the objective to reduce fleet numbers, while at the same time keeping vehicles to a seven-year rotation.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Four vendors were contacted (Gresham Ford, Northside Ford, Klamath Falls Lithia Ford, and Landmark Ford) regarding the purchase of vehicles. Northside Ford was the low bidder at $133,452.72.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Four vendors were contacted (LEHR/Auto Additions, SVS, ERS, and Wire Works) regarding the up-fitting. LEHR/Auto Additions was the low bidder at $51,115.24.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>This amount is allocated within the Capital Outlay Budget for the total project costs, as illustrated below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Police Department Budget -&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $182,100.00</p>

<p>Insurance Replacement Value (plus) $29,000.00</p>

<p>Purchase (Northside Ford) -&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$133,452.72</p>

<p>Up-Fitting (LHR/Auto Additions) - &nbsp;&nbsp;<u>&nbsp; $51,115.24</u></p>

<p>Total Funds Remaining -&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $26,532.04</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Purchase vehicles through Northside Ford and up-fitting through LEHR/Auto Additions.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Deny purchase and up-fitting and give staff further&nbsp;direction.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>The fiscal year 2018-2019 General Fund Budget was approved with $182,100 allocated for Capital Outlay for police department vehicle purchasing and up-fitting. Approval for this portion of this project leaves a remaining balance required for computer, modem, and other equipment necessary for the police vehicles. This line item will also allow for proper signage and city designations.&nbsp; The insurance company estimated the replacement cost for the totaled 2018 Police Ford Interceptor SUV in the amount of $29,000.00. We will salvage as much equipment possible out of this vehicle to off-set the cost of the upf-itting of the fourth new patrol vehicle. LEHR/Auto Additions quoted $8,595.60 to do this and the insurance company agreed to this quote and will cover the up-fitting of this replacement vehicle.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Failure to replace the vehicles would overtime negatively impact the departments ability to respond.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to&nbsp;approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Purchase</strong></p>

<p>- Northside Ford*</p>

<p>- Gresham Ford</p>

<p>- Klamath Falls Lithia Ford</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Up-fitting</strong></p>

<p>- Auto Additions (LEHR)*</p>

<p>- Day Wireless</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Informal Solicitation Records for Vehicle Purchases</p>

<p>- Informal Solicitation Records for Vehicle Up-Fitting</p>

<p>- Draft General Services Contract</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Nov 05, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">3. </span>PRESENTATIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">3.2 </span>NATIONAL HUNGER AND HOMELESS AWARENESS WEEK (November 10-18) - Mayoral Report</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Information</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: Mayor Westfall</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In support of the needs of our community, the City of Klamath Falls conducts a food drive in the month of November every year in cooperation with the Klamath County Food Bank. We will be continuing that tradition this year. Food barrels will be delivered from the Klamath County Food Bank on November 1st to City Hall located at 226 S 5th Street, City Annex located at 500 Klamath Avenue and City Finance/Utility Billing located at 222 S 6th Street. These Buildings are generally open Monday - Friday (8am-5pm, excluding noon to 1pm at 500 Klamath Avenue). There will be Public Service Announcements throughout the month posted internally and externally to our community encouraging everyone to donate.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The City’s Food Drive runs the entire month of November and&nbsp;is a registered event on the website of&nbsp;National Hunger &amp; Homelessness Awareness Week - <a href="http://www.hhweek.org/">http://www.hhweek.org/</a>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Please join the Employees of the City and donate during this Food Drive, thank you!</p>
</div>

<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u><em>Public Comment</em></u> is time reserved&nbsp;for citizens to speak on a matter that is not on the scheduled of the Meeting Agenda. Each person has 3 minutes to speak and must state their name and address for the record (<em>it is preferred that you fill out a Public Comment Form and return it to the City Recorder</em>). If there are multiple people from one Group/Entity that wish to convey "one message" they can have a Group Speaker and, upon request, would be given 5-10 minutes from Council to speak.</p>

<div class="rightcol">Nov 05, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>

<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>FULL ON-PREMISES SALES LIQUOR LICENSE REQUEST FOR ASI ES MI TIERRA LOCATED AT 1038 EAST MAIN STREET</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should Asi Es Mi Tierra, LLC, be permitted to sell distilled spirits, malt beverages, wine, and cider for consumption in their business?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>Asi Es Mi Tierra, LLC, is applying for a New Outlet Liquor License to allow Full On-Premises Sales at their restaurant establishment located at 1038 East Main Street.&nbsp;This would allow the sale of distilled spirits, malt beverages, wine, and cider for consumption at the licensed business.&nbsp; This business has been operating at this location since early 2017.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The business location is zoned Neighborhood Commercial.&nbsp;The operation of a restaurant is consistent with the zoning.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The business will not restrict entrance to the business by age, so the Adult Business Overlay Zone (CDO 12.490-12.496) does not come into effect.</p>

<p>Notice was sent on October 11, 2018, to adjacent property owners within a 100-foot radius of the business location.&nbsp; No response has been received to date.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Police Department also reviewed the request, and their comments are included below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1. Recommend APPROVAL to OLCC for full on-premises sales for Asi Es Mi Tierra, LLC.</p>

<p>2. Recommend DENIAL to OLCC for full on-premises sales for Asi Es Mi Tierra, LLC.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>There is no financial impact related to making a recommendation to OLCC.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
