<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Sep 17, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.2 </span>CONTRACT WITH BASIN SEAL RIGHT TO CRACK SEAL ALMOST 20,000 LINEAL FEET OF DESIGNATED CITY ROADWAYS IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $46,675.60</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;CHUCK COX - STREETS AND EQUIPMENT MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: <span style="font-size: 11px;"><span style="line-height: 115%;"><span new="" roman="" times="">Should the City&nbsp;enter into a contract with Basin Sealright to perform roadway crack seal services&nbsp;identified in the FY 2018/2023 Capital Improvements Program and the Adopted Budget for FY 2018/2019?</span></span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p><span style="line-height: normal;">The City has a number of roadways that are identified in the FY 2018/2018 Capital Improvements Program as&nbsp; needing crack seal maintenance. These streets are also scheduled for micro surface treatment in the Spring of 2019. To meet the schedule for micro surfacing these streets, the City will need to complete the crack seal project this Fall.</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">An informal quote solicitation was sent to four contractors, three local and one out of town. The work consists of crack sealing 19,960 lineal feet (3.78 miles) of roadway, which includes the following street sections: 6<sup>th</sup> Street from Broad Street to Main Street; 5<sup>th</sup> Street from Pine Street to Broad Street; Main Street from Crater Lake Parkway to Center Street; Klamath Avenue from Center Street to 12<sup>th</sup> Street; 2<sup>nd</sup> Street, 3<sup>rd</sup> Street, 4<sup>th</sup> Street, 7<sup>th</sup> Street, and 8<sup>th</sup> Street from Pine Street to Klamath Avenue; 9<sup>th</sup> Street from Main to Klamath Avenue; 10<sup>th</sup> Street from Pine Street to Main Street; 11<sup>th</sup> Street from Pine Street to Klamath Avenue; Center Street from the ODOT right-of-way to Klamath Avenue; and 12<sup>th</sup> Street from Main Street to Klamath Avenue.</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">The Streets Division estimated the cost to be $93,000 and has agreed to supply the materials (Crafco, Roadsaver Sealant 221) for the project. The results of the informal quotes are:</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Webb Asphalt Paving - No Response</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Basin Sealright - $46,675.60</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Rocky Mountain Construction - $73,731</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">C.R. Contracting (Bend) - $123,106</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Authorize the City Manager to enter into a contract with Basin Sealright <span style="text-align: justify; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">in the not-to-exceed amount of $46,675.60 </span>to crack seal almost 20,000 lineal feet of designated City roadways.<b> </b></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Not authorize the crack seal project with Basin Sealright.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11px;"><span style="line-height: 115%;"><span new="" roman="" times="">Direct Staff to go out for additional quotes&nbsp;resulting in delaying the project.</span></span></span></li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p><span style="line-height: normal;">Funds for this project are available through the City’s FY 2018/19 adopted Streets &amp; Equipment Capital Improvement program budget.</span></p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Council Option 1 will utilize available FY 18/19 funds identified for this project in a “not-to-exceed” amount of $46,675.60.</span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Council Option 2 will delay or cancel this project for at least a year.</span></li>
	<li style="text-align: justify; margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Council Option 3 will delay this project until the project scope can be redefined and sent back out to bid.</span></li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;<span style="line-height: normal;">Council to approve&nbsp;Option 1.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Ore-Cal Land Development ,LLC DBA: Basin Sealright</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">5721 Bartlett Avenue, Klamath Falls, OR 97632</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">4815 Tingly Lane #A, Klamath Falls, OR 97603</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">C.R. Contracting, LLC</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">62980 Boyd Acres Road, Bend, OR 97708</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Sep 17, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.3 </span>CONTRACT WITH MEAD &amp; HUNT, INC. FOR TAXIWAY G REHABILITATION PROJECT DESIGN IN THE AMOUNT OF $538,307</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;JOHN BARSALOU - AIRPORT DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should the City execute a contract with Mead &amp; Hunt, Inc. to design the Taxiway G Rehabilitation Project in the amount of $538,307?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>On May 21, 2018 Council approved the selection of Mead &amp; Hunt for Airport engineering and planning services related to FAA Airport Improvement Program (AIP) projects for the period of June 2018 through May 2023.&nbsp; The FAA has programed an AIP grant for the rehabilitation of Taxiway G in Federal fiscal year 2019.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Airport and the FAA identified Taxiway G, the primary parallel taxiway to Runway 14-32, for a full length rehabilitation due to a majority of the taxiway having a Pavement Condition Rating (PCR)&nbsp;of "Very Poor."&nbsp; The rehabilitation of Taxiway G will include a new asphalt surface, replacement of 10' asphalt millings shoulders, construction of under drains, replacement of edge lighting cable, LED edge lights, and LED airfield guidance signs.&nbsp; Mead &amp; Hunt's scope of work includes pavement investigative work to determine the method of rehabilitation, design and preparation of bid documents.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Mead &amp; Hunt provided a scope of work with an associated fee of $538,307.&nbsp; Per FAA regulations, the Airport submitted the scope of work to an another engineering firm to perform an Independent Fee Estimate (IFE).&nbsp; Century West Engineering, the firm performing the IFE, proposed a fee of $616,882.45 which was $78,575.45 or 14.5% higher than Mead &amp; Hunt's fee.&nbsp; The Airport provided the FAA&nbsp;with the results of the IFE and&nbsp;received the&nbsp;FAA's&nbsp;approval to proceed with the proposed contract with Mead &amp; Hunt for the sum of $538,307.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve a contract with Mead &amp; Hunt, Inc. to design the Taxiway G Rehabilitation Project in the amount of $538,307.</li>
	<li>Reject the proposed contract with Mead &amp; Hunt, Inc., direct staff to seek a modification to the Scope of Work from the FAA and renegotiate a contract with Mead &amp; Hunt.</li>
	<li>Reject a contract with Mead &amp; Hunt, INc. and request a postponement of the Taxiway G Rehabilitation Project from the FAA.</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: The FAA is providing an AIP&nbsp;Grant which will fund 93.75% of the contract or $504,662.&nbsp; The remaining 6.25% or $33,645 will come from budgeted Airport funds.&nbsp;The construction phase of the rehabilitation project is estimated at $6,000,000 and, as with the design, will be funded by a FAA AIP grant at the same ratio.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp; Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Mead &amp; Hunt, Inc.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Contract with Exhibit A - Scope of Work/Executive Summary</p>

<p>- FAA Letter of Approval for Proposed Mead &amp; Hunt Contract</p>

<p>- Project Design Aerial Map</p>
</div>

<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Sep 17, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>

<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.4 </span>APPROVAL OF A 3-YEAR GOODS AND SERVICES CONTRACT WITH ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS RESEARCH INSTITUTE (ESRI), INC. FOR GIS UPGRADES, IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $67,910</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW934Y6FE44C"><div class="name">Goal #2 - Customer Service</div></a>

<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;<span lang="EN" style="font-size: 8.5pt;"><span style="color: black;"><span style="line-height: 115%;"><span style="font-family:;" verdana="">JEREMY PRINSEN – TECHNOLOGY SERVICES &amp; HUMAN RESOURCES MANAGER&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City execute a 3-year goods and services contract with Esri, Inc. in the not-to-exceed amount of $67,910 to upgrade the City's current GIS environment to Esri’s Small Municipal and County Government Enterprise license model?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The City Development Services Division, in conjunction with the Technology Services Division, has identified the need to improve the capabilities and performance of our current Geographic Information Systems (GIS) environment. The current environment was implemented nearly 7 years ago when there was significantly less emphasis placed on digital maps of our assets. Since that time, the City has heavily incorporated GIS into our operations and matured to the point where our current license model no longer meets our needs.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>For Fiscal Year 2018/19, the City budgeted $34,650 to update our existing GIS environment, which included the following:</p>

<ul>
	<li>$ 7,650 annual license/support</li>
	<li>$25,000 Esri server upgrades and onsite consulting</li>
	<li>$ 1,500 additional ArcGIS Desktop Basic license</li>
	<li>$ 500 ArcGIS online Business Analyst</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Further analysis and discussions with Esri, Inc. prompted us to change our focus from updating our current environment to recommending the Division upgrade to a different license model. The Small Municipal and County Government Enterprise license will provide the City with a number of benefits over the current Workgroup Basic license, including:</p>

<ul>
	<li>A lower cost per unit for licensed software</li>
	<li>Unlimited ArcGIS Desktop licenses</li>
	<li>Substantially reduced administrative and procurement expenses</li>
	<li>Maintenance on all Esri software deployed under this agreement</li>
	<li>Complete flexibility to deploy software products when and where needed</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Upgrading from our current Workgroup Basic license to the Small Municipal and County Government Enterprise license will require entering into a 3-year agreement with Esri. Annual costs will be as follows:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the 3-year goods and services contract with Esri, Inc. in the amount of $67,910.</li>
	<li>Reject the 3-year goods and services contract with Esri, Inc., revise the scope and request new proposals to fulfill City GIS needs.</li>
	<li>Reject the 3-year goods and services contract with Esri, Inc., and proceed with updating our existing Workgroup Basic GIS environment.</li>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

This money was initially intended to fund updates to the current GIS environment but did not encompass license upgrades. By authorizing this goods and services request, the project will be fully installed, configured, and deployed within FY 18/19.</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Sep 17, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.5 </span>SUBMISSION OF A COMPETITIVE GRANT APPLICATION THROUGH THE SAFE ROUTES TO SCHOOL (SRTS) PROGRAM FOR CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS ON DELTA STREET</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT</u><u> GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;MARK WILLRETT - PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should Council authorize staff to submit a competitive grant through the Safe Routes to School Program?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp; Council approved the Safe Routes To School&nbsp; (SRTS) master plan and priority projects via resolution at the August 20th, 2018 Council meeting.&nbsp; Applications for grant dollars are now being accepted with the initial application period closing October 15th.&nbsp; After discussing priorities with the local SRTS&nbsp;coordinator, staff would like to submit project CO-2, which would construct sidewalk on the south side of Delta Street from Oregon Avenue to California Avenue.&nbsp; Not only would this project provide a safe walking corridor for students living close to Delta Street, but it would also provide a path for students walking from the area near the now closed Fairview school.&nbsp;Completion of this project will also make connections with sidewalks on Oregon Avenue and the newly constructed cycle track.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The project is estimated to cost $350,000&nbsp;with the City needing to come up with a 20% match or $70,000. Matching funds could come from the Street Division or another source such as COGEN&nbsp;funds. Staff would recommend using funds from the sale of effluent to the COGEN&nbsp;Facility.&nbsp;Sufficient funding exists provide the match if the City is successful.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>If Council authorizes staff to submit the grant, staff is also asking for Council's permission to accept the grant should the City be successful.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>1.&nbsp; Authorize staff to submit a grant to the SRTS&nbsp;program for sidewalks on the south side of Delta Street, from Oregon Avenue to California Avenue, and, if successful, authorize staff to accept the grant.</p>

<p>2.&nbsp; Do not authorize staff to submit a grant to the SRTS program.</p>

<p>3.&nbsp; Direct staff to submit a different grant project to the SRTS program and if successful, accept the grant.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>1.&nbsp; If the $70,000 came from Street Division funds, this would reduce the amount of pavement related work the City could do.&nbsp;Staff&nbsp;recommends using funds from the sale of effluent to the COGEN&nbsp;Facility.&nbsp;Sufficient funding exists provide the match if the City is successful.&nbsp;</p>

<p>2.&nbsp; There would be no financial impact if no project is submitted.</p>

<p>3.&nbsp; There would be a 20% match on any project Council selects.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: N/A</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Sep 04, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">5. </span>CONSENT AGENDA</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">5.2 </span>AUTHORIZE A CONTRACT WITH DUNKIN &amp; BUSH, INC. IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $46,435 FOR PAINTING THE WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action (Consent)</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: RAY BUSCH - WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;<span style="line-height: normal;">Should the City authorize maintenance painting of selected areas of the Wastewater Treatment Plant?</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Maintenance painting of the wastewater treatment plant facility is in this year’s fiscal budget. The amount budgeted for this year is $40,000. Quotes for the selected work came in considerably higher than anticipated. The project scope was reduced through negotiations with the low bidder and about 29% of the work was removed. This current project cost exceeds the budgeted amount by $6,435, however, there are other savings that will take place in this year’s budget that will cover the additional costs. The scope of this project includes three buildings and miscellaneous piping. Some of the selected areas have not been painted since the 1970's. All of the selected areas will not be impacted by the upcoming Wastewater Treatment Plant improvement project.</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><u>Three quotes obtained for the painting were</u>:</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Dunkin and Bush $46,435 (originally $64,665.00)</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">PetroChem $91,100</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">F.D. Thomas $98,749</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Authorize the City Manager to execute a contract with Dunkin &amp; Bush, Inc. in the not to exceed amount of $46,435 for maintenance painting of selected areas of the Wastewater Treatment Plant.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Direct staff to obtain additional quotes, or formal bids for maintenance painting.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Deny authorizing the painting, at this time, and defer the needed maintenance.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">There is sufficient funding within Water Recovery’s Budget to cover the contract cost, including the <span style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; text-align: justify; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">$6,435</span> shortfall, and, as noted above, most of the cost was&nbsp;budgeted within this fiscal year.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Staff had a difficult time getting three quotes, but staff could formally advertise this project. It is unclear what additional quotes/bids might look like.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">The money would be saved, but eventually the work will need to be done or the infrastructure will be compromised.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council move to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="line-height: normal;">Pete Weese </span></p>

<p><span style="line-height: normal;">c/o Dunkin and Bush, Inc.</span></p>

<p><span style="line-height: normal;">1205 N. Burgard Road </span></p>

<p><span style="line-height: normal;">Portland, Oregon 97203</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="line-height: normal;">- Informal Solicitation Record and Quotes from: </span></span>Dunkin and Bush, Inc.; Petrochem; and F.D. Thomas</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Sep 04, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>APPOINTMENT OF ATTORNEY DIANE BETTLES AS MUNICIPAL COURT PRO TEM JUDGE</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>

<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: NICKOLE BARRINGTON - CITY RECORDER/MUNICIPAL COURT MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council appoint Diane Bettles as a Municipal Court Pro Tem Judge?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>Municipal Court Judge Nathan Ratliff requested that attorney&nbsp;Diane Bettles&nbsp;be appointed as a Pro Tem&nbsp;Judge for Municipal Court.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Ms. Bettles owns her own law practice in Klamath Falls.&nbsp;After graduating from the Northwestern School of Law at Lewis &amp; Clark, in June of 2013 Diana was employed as an associate attorney with the Law Office of Rebecca Whitney-Smith.&nbsp;Diana holds a Bachelor of Science Degree in Criminal Justice from Southern Oregon University.&nbsp;She is a local resident from Klamath County and was raised in Chiloquin, Oregon.&nbsp;Prior to Law School, Diana worked for the Klamath Tribes as the Court Administrator for the Tribal Courts.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>While working as the Court Administrator, Diana advocated for upholding tribal member rights and worked with the Chief Justice and the Tribes’ Judicial Commission to develop Tribal Codes and build programs in order to provide a broader range of services to the Tribal Community.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1. Move to Appoint Diana Bettles as&nbsp;Pro Tem Judge for Municipal Court.&nbsp;</p>

<p>2. Deny Appointment.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: None. The use of Pro Tem Judges is already a practice and they are utilized as needed. The use of Pro Tem Judges is based upon a rotation schedule and court sessions help are based upon&nbsp;availability.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council move to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Diane Bettles, Attorney at Law</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B42R555B4F56">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Sep 04, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.2 </span>AUTHORIZE A CONTRACT WITH KLAMATH LAKE REGIONAL HOUSING COMMITTEE TO MANAGE FUNDS FOR THE MITIGATION OF BLIGHTED PROPERTIES</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;NATHAN CHERPESKI - CITY MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City enter into a contract with Klamath Lake Regional Housing Committee ("KLRHC") to manage funds for the mitigation of blighted properties?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>At&nbsp;the August 6th meeting, Council approved <em>in concept</em> contracting with a non-profit entity to manage funds dedicated to the mitigation of blighted properties within the City.&nbsp;Several years ago, a&nbsp;group of private citizens, using a mix of public and private funding, removed four blighted properties in and around the City of Klamath Falls.&nbsp;The effort was deemed successful as it addressed two properties with long-term code issues.&nbsp;Recently, the&nbsp;group, operating under the name&nbsp;Klamath Excellence, approached the County to assist them in mitigating blighted properties.&nbsp;The County has dedicated $50,000 to the effort and contracted&nbsp;with Klamath Lake Regional Housing Committee, an entity managed by South Central Oregon Economic Development District, to manage those County funds.&nbsp;The City is being asked&nbsp;to match the effort for blighted properties within City limits.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Staff recommended, and Council agreed, to provide up to $25,000 in this fiscal year to assist in this community effort, with the provision that the City would evaluate the effectiveness of the program and may provide an additional&nbsp;$25,000 in next year's fiscal budget. At the August 6th meeting, it was still unclear who the parties to the agreement would be.&nbsp;Since that time, KLRHC has agreed to manage the funds for mitigation of blighted properties and entered into a contract with the County.&nbsp;Staff has modified that contract to fit the needs of the&nbsp;City and a copy is attached to this report.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1.&nbsp; Approve the contract with KLRHC for $25,000.</p>

<p>2.&nbsp; Approve the contract with KLRHC with amendments.</p>

<p>3.&nbsp; Decline to act at this time, and give staff further direction.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: The City set aside&nbsp;$50,000 in the current fiscal year's budget to address workforce housing, and housing quality.&nbsp;This project will address housing quality issues.</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Sep 04, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.3 </span>DETERMINATION ON REQUEST OF KLAMATH VIEW ESTATES FOR EXTENSION OF COMPLIANCE DEADLINE</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: NATHAN CHERPESKI - CITY MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the Council affirm the decision of the Planning Commission from 2013 requiring compliance by November 1, 2018 or determine to extend the compliance deadline for Klamath View Estates?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">Klamath View Estates is a Manufactured Home Park ("Park") located at or near 1663 Greensprings Dr.&nbsp;In 2009, it appears that the City and County had both ceased processing requests for placement of new units because there was not a recorded map for the area.&nbsp; Based on the files, it appears&nbsp;there were no records with the County or State authorizing the Park and no map on file showing the layout of the Park.&nbsp; Because it did not appear to meet State law or local regulations, City staff requested that the owners submit a map of the Park.&nbsp;City zoning required them to obtain a Conditional Use Permit ("CUP") for a manufactured home park in the medium-density residential zone.&nbsp;An RV Park is prohibited in that zone.&nbsp;The City issued a conditional use permit in April 2010 which required compliance with the CDO by November 1, 2013.&nbsp;The CUP was appealed and then City Manager, Rick Whitlock,&nbsp;amended it to allow some additional usage of the old area and offered the Eddys the opportunity to request an extension from the Planning Commission, if sufficient progress was being made.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">In 2013, I was approached about allowing additional spaces to stay in continued use and to extend the deadline.&nbsp;I agreed to allow the lots to be used if they had addressed the sewer and electrical issues.&nbsp; I did not feel that I had authority to change the deadline, so I referred them to the Planning Commission.&nbsp;The Planning Commission heard their request and granted them an additional 5 years, until November 1, 2018, to come into compliance.&nbsp; </span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;"><u>Planning Commission made the following findings regarding the owner's compliance with the imposed requirements</u>:</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">1. The installation of maps/sign at the entrances to the park showing the space numbering and streets, per state code.</span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;"><i><u>Finding</u>: The applicant has completed this condition.</i></span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">2.&nbsp;The paving of all parking areas I driveways for recently placed homes within the new section.</span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;"><i><u>Finding</u>: The applicant has completed this condition.</i></span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">3. Any and all manufactured homes used for storage shall be removed from the property by November 1, 2011.</span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;"><i><u>Finding</u>: No manufactured homes or RVs are being used as storage units at this time; however, the one unit in the old section previously used for storage as recently as this year, still remains.</i></span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">4. All vehicles parked or stored on unpaved surfaces or on unoccupied lots within the new section shall be removed immediately. The old section cannot be used for storage of vehicles, trailers, RVs or manufactured homes.</span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;"><i><u>Finding</u>: Not completed. On September 30, 2013, there were two cars and one RV parked on space 25. Space 25 is an undeveloped space within the new section. All of the driveways within the sections are paved. The old section also appears to be used for storage or rental of RVs, campers, trailers and vehicles on occasion. </i></span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">5. Prior to the placement of any home on lots 53-61, a site obscuring planting, fence or wall not less than 6' or more than 7' in height shall be placed along the outside perimeter of the future portions of the park.</span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;"><i><u>Finding</u>: Not completed. Spaces 53-61 have not been developed. None of the required improvements has been constructed. However, this area is not being used. The applicant did get bids to install the required fence.</i></span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">6. Either the future recreation room shown on space 63 or the future playground shown on space 37 shall be fully developed prior to placing a home on spaces 53 - 61 in the new section.</span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;"><i><u>Finding</u>: Not completed. Neither the recreation room nor the playground has been completed. The applicant started to grade the playground area. This area is not being used at this time.</i></span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">Recently, the Eddys&nbsp;have made repeated requests of staff for additional time to gain compliance.&nbsp;The Planning Commission's Order was a Final Order and staff does not have authority to extend the deadline.&nbsp;Based on my touring of the location, the Eddys still have numerous items to complete to come into compliance.&nbsp;In the older section, no work is apparent on improving the roads.&nbsp; Staff believes eight years has been sufficient&nbsp;to allow compliance.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;"><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">1.&nbsp; Affirm the Planning Commission's Final Order of October 28, 2013, leaving the compliance deadline as November 1, 2018.</span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">2.&nbsp; Amend the deadline, setting a date certain for the property to come into compliance.</span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">3.&nbsp; Do nothing, and in essence this will let the Planning Commission's Final Order stand.</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;"><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">There are no direct impacts for these decisions.&nbsp;If compliance is not reached voluntarily, the City will need to initiate code enforcement actions.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;"><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: <span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">Council to approve Option 1.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;"><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</span></span></p>

<p>Klamath View Estates</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">c/o Cynthia Eddy and Daniel Eddy</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;"><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">- Eddy's Case Documents</span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">- PC Final Order 11/6/13</span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">- Klamath View Estates Map</span></span></p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Sep 04, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.4 </span>AMENDMENT OF CITY CODE REGARDING PUBLIC NUISANCE PROPERTIES SECTIONS 5.470-5.472</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW92ZV6FAC13"><div class="name">Goal #1 - Citizens feel safe and secure in their homes, work sites, and public places.</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: DAVE HENSLEE - CHIEF OF POLICE</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;<span style="margin: 0px;">Should the City&nbsp;amend </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: black;">the Public Nuisance Property Code as a mechanism to empower the Police Department, landlords and City residents to positively impact community livability</span><span style="margin: 0px;">?</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0px; border: currentColor; border-image: none;"><span style="margin: 0px; color: black;">Sections 5.470-5.472 of the City Code of the City of Klamath Falls (the “Public Nuisance Property Code”), which was enacted in 1996, authorized the City Council to close down a property for a period of 12 months when occupants, residents, patrons or employees engage in a "pattern of illegal behavior" at the property by committing three or more specified criminal offenses within any 6-month period.</span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; border: currentColor; border-image: none;"><span style="margin: 0px; color: black;">&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; border: currentColor; border-image: none;"><span style="margin: 0px; color: black;">The City&nbsp;Police Department has utilized this City Code in the past three years to force owners and occupants to mitigate criminal behavior occurring on specific properties.<span style="margin: 0px;">&nbsp;</span>The Police Department believes the provisions of the current code could be enhanced and modified to become a more effective tool to combat crime in neighborhoods plagued by persistent criminal activity.</span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; border: currentColor; border-image: none;"><span style="margin: 0px; color: black;">&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; border: currentColor; border-image: none;"><span style="margin: 0px; color: black;">There are several benefits to the proposed changes.<span style="margin: 0px;">&nbsp;</span>First, modifying the Public Nuisance Property Code by expanding the list of qualifying crimes, will allow the Police Department to more broadly utilize the code to combat patterns of illegal and persistent criminal behavior.<span style="margin: 0px;">&nbsp;</span>Second, improving the enforcement and abatement procedures by referring proposed abatements to the Municipal Court Judge (rather than the City Council), will ensure the validity of the proposed abatement and protect the rights of property owners and tenants.<span style="margin: 0px;">&nbsp;</span>Last, selectively utilizing the provisions of the proposed code will better empower the Police Department, Landlords, and City residents to positively impact community livability. </span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; border: currentColor; border-image: none;"><span style="margin: 0px; color: black;">&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style="margin: 0px; border: currentColor; border-image: none;"><span style="margin: 0px; color: black;">Klamath Falls Rental Owners Association, which represents the interests of landlords within the community, supports enactment of the proposed changes to the Public Nuisance Property Code and has embraced the opportunity to work with the Police Department and neighbors to improve community livability.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt 0.5in; text-indent: -0.5in;">1)&nbsp; Approve the proposed amendments to <span style="margin: 0px; color: black;">City Code Sections 5.470–5.472; and introduce the Ordinance by title for first reading.&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt; border-image: none; word-spacing: 0px; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">2)<span style="margin: 0px;">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span>Deny the requested to amend <span style="margin: 0px; color: black;">Sections 5.470–5.472 of the City Code, and leave the current provisions of the Code in effect</span>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: None.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: <span style="margin: 0px; padding: 0in; border: 1pt windowtext; border-image: none;">Council to approve&nbsp;Option 1.</span></p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Klamath Falls Rental Owners Association</p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt; border-image: none; word-spacing: 0px; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Attachment #1: City of Klamath Falls Code 5.470-5.472 with proposed changes</p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Attachment #2: Proposed Ordinance</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Sep 04, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.5 </span>AN ORDINANCE ADDING SECTION 5.344 TO THE CITY OF KLAMATH FALLS CODE AND AMENDING SECTION 5.390(1) RELATING TO UNLAWFUL DISPOSAL OF HUMAN WASTE</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action, Procedural</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW92ZV6FAC13"><div class="name">Goal #1 - Citizens feel safe and secure in their homes, work sites, and public places.</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JACK DANIEL - POLICE LIEUTENANT</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: <span style="margin: 0px;">Should the City of Klamath Falls adopt a City Code provision making it illegal to deposit human biological waste in public places, </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: black;">as a mechanism to positively enhance </span><span style="margin: 0px; color: black;">community livability and to address a public health hazard?</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>Police officers and community members have observed a persistent problem in the City with persons choosing to defecate and/or urinate in public places and in places visible to other citizens.&nbsp; Depositing human biological waste, including feces and urine, in public areas poses a public health hazard and the commission of these acts is significantly detrimental to the livability of our community.&nbsp; Currently, City of Klamath Falls Code does not specifically address the issue of defecation or urination in public places or in places visible to other citizens.&nbsp; Community members desire to enhance community livability and to address the public health hazard by adopting a law prohibiting the intentional deposit or discharge of human waste in public places and in places exposed to public view.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt 0.5in; text-indent: -0.5in;">1)&nbsp; Move to introduce the proposed ordinance&nbsp;for first reading by title only.</p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt 0.5in; text-indent: -0.5in;">2)<span style="margin: 0px;">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style="margin: 0px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">Decline to act, and leave the Code silent on the unlawful deposit if human biological waste.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: None.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Co<span style="margin: 0px; padding: 0in; border: 1pt windowtext; border-image: none;">uncil to approve&nbsp;Option 1.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Klamath Falls Downtown Association</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">Attachment #1: Proposed Ordinance</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Aug 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>CLEAN WATER STATE REVOLVING FUND LOAN CONSOLIDATION</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;RAY BUSCH - WATER RECOVERY SERVICES MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should the City Council authorize the City Manager to sign A Loan Agreement (Amendment #2) with the Oregon Department of Environmental Quality ('DEQ')?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The purpose of the amendment is to consolidate existing Loans R52603 and R52604 into Loan R52602 for a total loan amount of $22,634,802 at 2.12% interest. These loans were initially incurred to provide preliminary, startup funding for the Spring Street Sewage Treatment Plant Progressive Design/Build Project. The Project is intended to update the Plant to meet upcoming permit limits and it includes designing a new headworks/influent station, repurposing the existing digesters and decommissioning primary clarifiers, and expanding the aeration basins. This proposed loan amendment, once executed, will cancel Loans R52603 and R52604. The 2.12% interest rate is the lowest interest of the three existing loans. The other two loans have interest rates of 3.32% for a 1-million dollar loan and 2.45% for a 7-million dollar loan.&nbsp;The first amendment to this agreement corrected the loan interest rate to the rate in effect when the Loan was originally signed. Signing of this second agreement will essentially void the first amendment.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Date of Original Agreement: 5/02/2011</p>

<p>Effective Date of Amendment No. 1: 5/25/2011</p>

<p>Effective Date of Amendment No. 2: 7/19/2018</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>If Council approves this amendment, staff will utilize these funds to complete project design, including the necessary bid documents, to enter into a progressive design/build contract for a guaranteed maximum price to construct the improvements. Staff has already submitted a new loan application to complete construction.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
	<li>Authorize the City Manager to sign the Clean Water State Revolving Fund Loan Agreement (Amendment #2).</li>
	<li>Do not authorize the signing of the loan agreement and retain the three existing loans.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>The City will see savings with the lower interest rate. There are no additional fees or other costs to consolidate these loans.</li>
	<li>The City would pay more in interest by not signing the amendment and consolidating the loans.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;Staff recommends Council approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Kathy Estes, Loan Specialist</p>

<p>Clean Water State Revolving Fund</p>

<p>Oregon Department of Environmental Quality</p>

<p>700 NE Multnomah Street, Suite 600</p>

<p>Portland OR 97232</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>- Clean Water State Revolving Fund Loan Agreement (Amendment #2)</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Aug 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.2 </span>CONSULTANT SERVICE CONTRACT WITH TETRA TECH, INC. FOR SERVICES NECESSARY TO COMPLETE THE 2018 WATER MASTER PLAN UPDATE PROJECT</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;RANDY TRAVIS - WATER MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council authorize staff to enter into a Consultant Service Contract with Tetra Tech, Inc. in the not-to-exceed amount of $99,973 to complete the 2018 Klamath Falls Water System Master Plan Update Project?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The City of Klamath Falls owns and operates the public water system which provides potable drinking water to approximately 41,000 residents throughout the Urban Growth Boundary. The public water system consists of 13 groundwater wells, 22 water storage reservoirs or tanks, 23 booster stations and approximately 270 miles of water main pipeline, which includes nearly 1,200 fire hydrants and approximately 16,000 metered water service connections.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Owning and operating a public water system, the City has always understood the importance of not only operating and maintaining the water production, storage and delivery infrastructure, but also planning for water system improvements in developing areas and water system upgrades to ensure adequate water system capacity for existing and future water customers. One of the tools used by the Public Works Department and Water Division to identify, plan and construct water system infrastructure improvements is the Water Master Plan.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In 2010, using a licensed professional engineering consultant, the Water Division completed a comprehensive water master plan. This document has proven an invaluable guidance tool for identifying existing system deficiencies, areas of planned and anticipated growth and the necessary improvements needed to meet existing and future customer needs. Numerous water system improvement projects identified within this document have been completed in the last eight years, including pipeline, pump station, source protection and reservoir projects. These improvements have provided water supply reliability for use during emergencies such as power outages and improved transmission capabilities to meet peak demand periods and fire flow demands. Since the&nbsp;2010 master plan&nbsp;timeframe only addresses suggested system improvements&nbsp;until approximately 2020, the Water Division proposes to undertake a water master plan update project. The purpose of this project is to accurately&nbsp;determine current levels of development and which will enable City staff to respond more effectively to new water system demands.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Oregon Administrative Rules require every community water system with 300 or more service connections to have a current master plan which is prepared by a professional engineer registered in Oregon. These rules also set forth very specific criteria and areas of required study to be included as part of a water master plan. Industry standards suggest updating the required master plan once every 5-10 years or more frequently if major land use or other changes occur.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In response to Public Works Department Water Division request, Tetra Tech, Inc. submitted a proposal for updating the current City of Klamath Falls Water Master Plan. This proposal, which is based on detailed pre-defined criteria, was thoroughly reviewed by staff and has been found to meet all state administrative rule requirements. The study area for this plan update encompasses all land within the Urban Growth Boundary. The proposal is for a “not to exceed” budget based on a defined scope of work. Tetra Tech, Inc. proposes to provide the necessary services to complete this project and provide the City with a comprehensive final water master plan, which will come back to the Council for approval.&nbsp; The project manager for Tetra Tech, Inc. managed the recently completed water system vulnerability assessment.&nbsp; The information from the report will be rolled into the master plan.&nbsp; Although it is sometimes necessary to solicit engineering consultant services through a formal, Request For Qualifications (RFQ) process, ORS 279C.110 (8) and the City's Public Contracting Rules [Sec. 8.B.(4)] allow the City to directly appoint engineering consultant services if the estimated cost does not exceed $100,000.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>If a contract is approved, a standard consultant services contract will be drafted and executed by staff with the scope of work and proposal marked as Exhibit A.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Authorize staff to enter into a contract agreement with Tetra Tech, Inc. for consultant services to undertake a comprehensive Water Master Plan Update in an amount not-to- exceed $99,973.</li>
	<li>Deny staff to enter into a contract agreement with Tetra Tech, Inc. for consultant services to undertake a comprehensive Water Master Plan Update.</li>
	<li>Direct staff to modify the project scope and&nbsp;seek new proposals based on the redefined scope of work.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>Funds for this project are available through the City’s FY 2018/19 Adopted Budget in the Water Division's Materials and Services Professional Services Contract Fund.</p>

<ol>
	<li>Council Option 1; will utilize available FY 18/19 funds identified for this project in a “not-to-exceed” amount of $99,973.</li>
	<li>Council Option 2; will delay or cancel this project.</li>
	<li>Council Option 3; will delay this project until the project scope can be redefined and new proposals requested, reviewed and approved by staff and Council.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve&nbsp;Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Brian Murphy, Project Manager - Tetra Tech, Inc.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Scope of Work</p>

<p>- Price Proposal</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Aug 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.3 </span>USE OF CHIP SEAL SERVICES PROVIDED BY THE KLAMATH COUNTY PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: CHUCK COX - STREETS AND EQUIPMENT MANAGER&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should Council allow the Klamath County Public Works Division&nbsp;to perform Chip Seal services for the Klamath Falls Streets Division in the not-to-exceed amount of $150,000 to complete&nbsp;project work designated in the 2018-2023 CIP and the&nbsp;FY 2018/2019 Adopted Budget?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The Streets Division has requested Chip Seal services from the Klamath County Public Works Department to chip seal approximately 3.64 miles of City streets, including California Avenue (from Nevada Street to the end), Front Street (from California Avenue to the end), Harbor Isles Boulevard (from Front Street to Harvard Avenue), Harvard Avenue (from Harbor Isles Boulevard to Hanks Street), Hanks Street (from Harvard Avenue to Lakeport Boulevard), and Lakeport Boulevard (from City limits to Biehn Street). The estimate for this Project is $150,000, which also includes the fog seal.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Authorize Klamath County Public Works Department to perform Chip Seal services for the Klamath Falls Streets Division in the not-to-exceed amount of $150,000 to complete City project work designated in the 2018-2023 CIP and the FY 2018/2019 Adopted Budget.</li>
	<li>Not authorize the Chip Seal project with the Klamath County Public Works Department and defer the budgeted&nbsp;Chip Seal project.</li>

<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.5 </span>PLANNING SERVICES CONTRACT WITH WINTERBROOK PLANNING FOR PHASE 3 OF THE CITY/COUNTY JOINT URBAN AREA PLANNING PROJECT IN THE LUMP SUM AMOUNT OF $42,500</div>

<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>On October 12, 2017, City Council and the Board of County Commissioners (BOCC) held a joint work session where they reviewed a proposal from Winterbrook Planning to provide a joint study of the City and County comprehensive plans within the Urban Growth Boundary (UGB). Both Council and the BOCC agreed to jointly proceed with the initial steps of the comprehensive plan study by engaging Winterbrook Planning to prepare an evaluation of existing documents and provide recommendations toward a joint urban area comprehensive plan.</p>

<p>On April 11, 2018, Greg Winterowd of Winterbrook Planning joined City and County Planning Staff to present the findings of the Phase 1 Planning Evaluation and Reorganization Program Memo to City Council and the BOCC. The Phase 1 effort resulted in a recommendation to proceed with draft updates and proposed reorganization of both the City and County comprehensive plan documents. The expected deliverables include:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Prepare a draft consolidated Urban Area Plan;</li>
	<li>Prepare a draft Urban Area Public Facilities Plan;</li>
	<li>Prepare new Rezoning Criteria for use in rezoning proposals; and</li>
	<li>Provide technical and organizational support for public work sessions and community outreach.</li>
</ol>

<p>Both Council and the BOCC requested that staff request a&nbsp;proposal identifying the next steps and costs for the joint urban area planning project. As a result, Winterbrook Planning prepared the attached, proposed Phase 3 work program in the total amount of $85,000. Staff is seeking support from Council to engage in a contract with Winterbrook Planning with the City paying for 50% <span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">($42,500)</span> of the total costs of the Phase 3 Project. The BOCC has expressed support for the project and has agreed to contract and pay for their half of the proposal.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>If contract is approved, a standard consultant services contract with the approved proposal (marked as Exhibit A) will be drafted by staff.</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the Phase 3 Planning Services Contract with Winterbrook Planning in the amount of $42,500.</li>
	<li>Deny the Planning Services Contract with Winterbrook Planning, revise the scope and request a new proposal.</li>
	<li>Deny the Planning Services Contract with Winterbrook Planning and postpone the project to a later date.</li>
	<li>Deny the Planning Services Contract with Winterbrook Planning and cancel the project indefinitely.</li>
</ol>

The total fee proposal for Phase 3 = $85,000. The City and County will each separately be contracting for 50% of the service fees with Winterbrook Planning. Therefore, the City would be responsible for $42,500.</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Aug 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.6 </span>CONSIDERATION OF STREETS FOR ALL PEOPLE POLICY</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Whether to adopt and utilize the Streets for All People Policy?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>In an effort to improve street connectivity and create a healthier more vibrant community, the Streets for All People Policy has been drafted. The proposed policy embraces and brings together various standards already found in many different documents, such as the Community Development Ordinance, the Klamath Falls Urban Growth Boundary Transportation System Plan, and the Klamath Falls Engineering Standards, bringing all of the elements found in these individual documents into one more concise document. The proposed policy will better enable City staff to clearly and effectively communicate the City’s expectation for the ongoing development of a multi-modal transportation system to developers, property owners, and other parties.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Streets for All People Policy introduces a concept of Street Connectivity and creates a standard network connectivity index rating of at least 1.4 for all new development. Examples of Street Connectivity index ratings for a few existing residential areas are: Gatewood Subdivision = 1.28; Ferndale Subdivision = .9; and Pacific Terrace = 1.57. It appears on average residential subdivisions would need to limit the number of cul-de-sacs to 10% - 15% of road totals to meet the Street Connectivity Standards of 1.4 with further index rating background contained within the Policy.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>At their April 10, 2017 meeting, the Planning Commission considered and unanimously recommended approval of the Policy with one condition. The recommended condition was to include language to allow for a reduction in the street connectivity index for properties with topographical constraints. In response to the Planning Commission recommended condition, the sentence “The minimum connectivity index rating may be reduced if topography of a subject property makes meeting a connectivity rating of 1.4 unattainable.” has been added to the Policy’s Exceptions and Network Connectivity Sections.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>On May 1, 2017, City Council considered&nbsp;the Streets for all People Policy and recommended the item be continued until Klamath County moved forward with Policy adoption. A copy of the associated City Council meeting minutes have&nbsp;been attached to the Agenda Report.&nbsp;On May 30, 2018, the Klamath County Board of Commissioners unanimously voted to adopt the Streets for All People Policy&nbsp;inclusive of consideration for topographical constraints. Additional&nbsp;clarification was added to the County-approved Policy while&nbsp;not materially changing&nbsp;the document's intent.&nbsp;All additions&nbsp;to the attached Streets for All People Policy as approved by Klamath County have been noted in bold.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the Streets for All People Policy as modified by Planning Commission.</li>
	<li>Approve the Streets for All People Policy with additional modifications as made and adopted by&nbsp;Klamath County.</li>
	<li>Remand the Streets for All People Policy back to Planning Commission for additional consideration.</li>
	<li>Reject the Streets for All People Policy and give staff further direction.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp;There is no immediate Financial Impact for Policy Approval or Rejection. If approved, specific improvements related to Public Works projects will need to be considered on a case by case basis with funding identified.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council to approve Option 2.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>- City Planning Commission</p>

<p>- County Commissioners</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Aug 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>

<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.7 </span>REQUEST TO WAIVE CITY CODE SECTION 5.438 AND ALLOW THE PUBLIC CONSUMPTION OF ALCOHOL WITHIN A DESIGNATED AREA DURING TWO SPECIAL EVENTS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should Council waive the restrictions of City Code Section 5.438 prohibiting public drinking and allow the consumption of alcohol within a section of the N. 6th Street right-of-way between Pine and Main Street during two future "Ride the Rim - Block Party" events?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>City Code Section 5.438 states, "No person shall drink any alcoholic liquor or possess on his/her person any bottle, can, or other receptacle containing any alcoholic liquor, which has been opened, or a seal broken, or the contents of which have been partially removed, inside the City limits while upon any street, City park, cemetery, sidewalk, alley or premises open to the general public for the use of motor vehicles. Provided, however, nothing in this Section shall apply to the drinking of any alcoholic liquor at any activity for which a permit authorizing such drinking or possession has been obtained from the City."</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Representatives from Discover Klamath, the region’s tourism promotion entity, have requested a Council waiver from the restrictions of City Code Section 5.438 to allow the operation of a temporary beer garden within the N. 6th Street right-of-way during two upcoming Ride the Rim Block Party events on September 8 and September 15, 2018, from 3 p.m. to 10 p.m. The Block Party events will be open to the general-public without charge and are to include food, drink, vendors, live music, and interactive games. Discover Klamath submitted a Special Event Application for both event dates which was reviewed and approved by City&nbsp;Parks and Development Services Division staff. Discover Klamath proposed and is organizing the two events to coincide with the annual Ride the Rim cycling event around Crater Lake and to bring additional overnight visitors and dollars into the Klamath Basin. A letter from Discover Klamath better describing the Ride the Rim event, its estimated economic impacts, and the group’s request of Council has been attached to the Agenda Report.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The applicant has proposed siting an approximately 50'x40' (2,000 sq. ft.) beer garden, if approved, which is to be separated from the surrounding right-of-way using rented 6’ chain link fencing. Klamath Basin Brewing Company is to provide beer and wine sales on September 8th while Mia and&nbsp;Pia's&nbsp;Pizzeria and Brewhouse is to provide those beer garden services on September 15th. Cowboy Security is to provide beer garden security and ID checks with greater operation details for both event dates contained within the attached Alcohol Control Plan.&nbsp; According to the attached plan, the sale, service and patron consumption of alcohol in the beer garden will only be allowed between the hours of 4 p.m. and 9 p.m. on both dates. Notice of the Temporary Oregon Liquor Control Commission (OLCC) Sales License Request was sent to the Klamath Falls Police Department and no concerns were identified.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
	<li>Waive City Code Section 5.438 to allow the temporary consumption of alcohol within the N. 6th Street right-of-way as requested and conditioned on OLCC approval of a Temporary Liquor License.</li>
	<li>Waive City Code Section 5.438 to allow the temporary consumption of alcohol within the N. 6th Street right-of-way with additional conditions and conditioned on OLCC approval of a Temporary Liquor License.</li>
	<li>Deny the request to waive the City Code and operate a temporary beer garden.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp;There is no financial impact related to waiving City Code Section 5.438 and making an approval recommendation to the OLCC.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>- Raena&nbsp;Rodgers, Marketing Manager - Discover Klamath</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Aug 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.8 </span>A RESOLUTION ADOPTING THE JUNE 2018 SAFE ROUTES TO SCHOOL MASTER PLAN FOR KLAMATH FALLS CITY SCHOOLS AND APPROVING THE LIST OF PRIORITY PROJECTS IDENTIFIED FOR EACH SCHOOL</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW92ZV6FAC13"><div class="name">Goal #1 - Citizens feel safe and secure in their homes, work sites, and public places.</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;MARK WILLRETT - PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should&nbsp;Council adopt the June 2018 Safe Routes to School Master Plan?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The safe routes to school (SRTS) concept began in the 1970's in Odense, Denmark, rooted in concern for the safety of children walking and bicycling to school.&nbsp;The SRTS concept spread internationally and the first program in the United States started in the Bronx, a borough of New York City in 1997.&nbsp;In August of 2000, Congress funded two SRTS pilot projects through the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.&nbsp;Congress then created the Federal-Aid Safe Routes to School Program in 2005 through comprehensive transportation legislation.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Although funding had previously been&nbsp;earmarked at the Federal and State level, the money available was more&nbsp;for education and outreach as opposed to funding for construction.&nbsp;With the passage of House Bill 2017, approximately $10 million per year will be made available for construction projects&nbsp;State-wide through a competitive grant program.&nbsp;In fact, the applications are currently out and staff intends to attend a workshop in August on completing and submitting applications to this grant program.&nbsp;The SRTS&nbsp;Master Plan prioritizes projects within a mile around both the City and County schools and provides estimates for construction.&nbsp; Adopting this plan by resolution assists in the funding application process as we are asked to list the plan and the date it was adopted or completed.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>1.&nbsp; Move to introduce the Resolution and read by title only; and move to&nbsp;approve the Resolution.</p>

<p>2.&nbsp; Do not approve the proposed resolution.</p>

<p>3.&nbsp; Direct staff to return to Council with a revised resolution per Council's recommendations.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp; There are no financial impacts for any of the three options above.&nbsp;However, if staff is successful in obtaining a grant for construction there is a 20% match. Staff would bring the grant to Council for approval with funding options for the match.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:&nbsp;N/A</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>- Proposed Resolution</p>

<p>- Master Plan&nbsp;(provided to Council under separate cover)</p>
</div>
