<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B2YTW26624EB">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Aug 06, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LAND USE PUBLIC HEARING - QUASI JUDICIAL</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>REQUEST TO REPLAT A PORTION OF THE RAILROAD ADDITION SUPPLEMENTAL PLAT TO INCORPORATE A FORMER RAILROAD SPUR PROPERTY INTO EXISTING LOTS ABUTTING SPRING STREET</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council approve the proposed subdivision replat to incorporate a former railroad spur property into existing lots abutting Spring Street?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The applicant proposes to replat a portion of a current subdivision within the Railroad Addition. The subject area is roughly bounded by existing and developed lots fronting South Spring Street to the east, existing and developed lots fronting Market Street to the west, Oak Avenue to the north, and Elm Avenue to the south.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>To the immediate west of the subject parcels fronting Spring Street is a strip of land that appears to be a mid-block alley and which currently functions as if it were City right-of-way. This area is, however, owned by the Union Pacific Railroad, successor of the Southern Pacific Railroad. This strip of land previously provided rail spur access to the rear side of businesses in the Railroad Addition, but is no longer in use.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The adjacent owners of the subject tax lots (listed below) have collectively decided to purchase the area owned by Union Pacific Railroad (R-3809-033BC-01500-000) abutting and behind each of their individual parcels to enlarge each of their lots. The adjacent property owners have all authorized Matt Bogatay to act on their behalf regarding this application.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Subject Parcels</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>R-3809-033BB-09900-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, Lots 5A and 5B; 600 Spring Street – Owner.</li>
	<li>R-3809-033BC-01400-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, Lots 7A, 7B, 8A and 8B; James L Robinson – Owner.</li>
	<li>R-3809-033BC-01300-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, Lots 9A, 9B, 10A and 10B; Mickey D &amp; Esther J Cummings – Owner.</li>
	<li>R-3809-033BC-01200-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, Lots 11A, 11B, 12A, 12B and 13A; Mickey D &amp; Esther J Cummings – Owner.</li>
	<li>R-3809-033BC-01100-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, Lots 13B, 14A, 14B and 15A; 600 Spring Street – Owner.</li>
	<li>R-3809-033BC-01000-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, Lots 15B and 16A; Linda Michele Darrah Bogatay – Owner.</li>
	<li>R-3809-033BC-01500-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, railroad spur; Union Pacific Railroad Co. – Owner.</li>
</ol>

<p>Primary access to all lots will remain as currently existing from the South Spring Street frontage, and each lot has access to and is served by all requisite utilities. While following subdivision land use application processes was necessary because of the number of lots proposed for replat, many of the design standards and criteria typically considered for new subdivision creation were not applicable to this replat application.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>On April 23, 2018, the Planning Commission held a public hearing and reviewed the Tentative Subdivision Plan Review Criteria listed below and proposed staff findings. Planning Commission modified staff’s findings to remove the proposed condition of approval of Criterion G, which is identified in this report as Criterion (7). Staff’s proposed condition was based on comment provided by the Klamath County Building Department requesting inclusion of a “no-build” setback area for fire protection purposes. Planning Commission did not find it within their purview to dictate or enforce state building codes through their approval recommendation, but rather to follow Community Development Ordinance standards which allow zero-foot building setbacks within Light Industrial zoning. A full version of the April 23, 2018 Planning Commission meeting minutes are attached to this Agenda Report.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>RELEVANT REVIEW CRITERIA, FACTS AND ANALYSIS</u></p>

<p>This proposal is being reviewed according to the provisions of the Klamath Falls Community Development Ordinance (Chapters 10-14), specifically Sections 11.800-11.825 regarding Tentative Subdivision Plans. Prior to making a recommendation on the proposed subdivision, the Council is required to analyze the following “Review Criteria” found in CDO 11.815. On recommendation of the Interim City Attorney, Staff has slightly modified the findings as approved by the Planning Commission to provide additional clarity concerning various criteria and to add an analysis of Criterion (8).</p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p><strong>Criterion (1): No tentative plat shall be approved which bears a name using a word which is the same as, similar to, or pronounced the same as a word in the name of any other subdivision in Klamath County, except the words “town,” “city,” “place,” “court,” “addition,” or similar words.</strong></p>

	<p><u>Staff’s Analysis</u>: The applicants have not proposed a name for this subdivision but rather the subdivision will only be identified by its tract number: Tract 1541. Per review of the City Surveyor this is an acceptable title for the proposed subdivision.</p>

	<p><u>Proposed Finding</u>: No tentative plat shall be approved which bears a name using a word which is the same as, similar to, or pronounced the same as a word in the name of any other subdivision in Klamath County, except the words “town,” “city,” “place,” “court,” “addition,” or similar words. The proposed subdivision has a unique tract number assigned by the Klamath County Surveyor. <strong>This criterion is met.</strong></p>
	</li>
</ul>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p><strong>Criterion (2): The streets and roads are laid out so as to conform to the plats of subdivisions and maps of partitions already approved for adjoining property as to width, general direction and all other respects unless the Commission determines it is in the public interest to modify the street or road pattern.</strong></p>

	<p><u>Staff’s Analysis</u>: This subdivision is a replat of several existing Lots. The newly created (revised) Lots will continue to access from Spring Street. Lot 5 will also have access to Elm Avenue. All streets in the vicinity are existing and there will be no change to the existing street layout with the subdivision as proposed. This criterion is not applicable.</p>

	<p><u>Proposed Finding</u>: <strong>This criterion is not applicable. </strong></p>
	</li>
</ul>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p><strong>Criterion (3): Streets for public use are dedicated without any reservation or restriction.</strong></p>

	<p><u>Proposed Finding</u>: This subdivision is a replat of several existing Lots within an existing subdivision. The newly created (revised) Lots will continue to access from Spring Street. Lot 5 will also have access to Elm Avenue. All streets in the vicinity are existing and there will be no change to the existing street layout or new street dedications with the subdivision as proposed. This criterion is not applicable.</p>

	<p><u>Proposed Finding</u>: <strong>This criterion is not applicable.</strong></p>
	</li>
</ul>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p><strong>Criterion (4): Streets held for private uses are clearly indicated on the tentative plan and all reservations or restrictions relating to such private streets are set forth thereon.</strong></p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><u>Staff Analysis</u>: No streets are being held for private use; therefore, this criterion is not applicable.</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><u>Proposed Finding</u>: <strong>This criterion is not applicable.&nbsp;</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p><strong>Criterion (5): Streets held for private use as indicated on the tentative plan of such subdivision are approvable by the Public Works Department.</strong></p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><u>Staff Analysis</u>: No streets are being held for private use; therefore, this criterion is not applicable.</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><u>Proposed Finding</u>: <strong>This criterion is not applicable.</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p><strong>Criterion (6): The plan contains provisions for the donation to the City of all common improvements, including but not limited to streets, parks, sewage disposal, water and geothermal supply systems, the donation of which may be made a condition of the approval of the tentative plan.</strong></p>

	<p><u>Staff’s Analysis</u>: This subdivision is a replat of several existing Lots. All required improvements are in place with the exception of the new private driveway which will be required as a condition for vehicle access to Lot 5 from Elm Avenue. Because the private driveway will require construction of a standard driveway approach in the City right-of-way, these improvements must be donated to the City. No additional common improvements are being proposed.</p>

	<p><u>Proposed Finding for approval</u>: <strong>This criterion is conditionally met. Proposed condition: The proposed replat shows the south 312 feet of the former railroad spur property being attached to Lots 15B and 16A to create the new Lot 5. Prior to its use for vehicular access, this portion of the former railroad spur must be improved to driveway standards, including pavement. A standard driveway approach, meeting the City of Klamath Fall Public Works Engineering Standards, must also be installed on Elm Avenue prior to this location being used for vehicular access. The Driveway approach will include new curb, driveway apron, sidewalk through the driveway, and an additional sidewalk panel on either side of the driveway to establish future sidewalk location.</strong></p>
	</li>
</ul>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p><strong>Criterion (7): The tentative plan complies with the Comprehensive Plan and Chapter 10 to 14 and all other applicable local and state regulations.</strong></p>

	<p><u>Staff’s Analysis</u>: The applicant through the submitted documents and tentative subdivision plan has shown the proposed subdivision complies with the Comprehensive Plan, the Community Development Ordinance, and other applicable local and state regulations.</p>

	<p><u>Proposed Finding</u>: <strong>This criterion is met. </strong></p>
	</li>
</ul>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p><strong>Criterion (8): Emergency vehicle access is adequately addressed and complies with the Uniform Fire Code, as stated in Section 8.600 of the City Code.</strong></p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><u>Staff’s Analysis</u>: This subdivision is a replat of several existing Lots within an existing subdivision. Emergency vehicle access will not be changed or adversely affected by the proposed replat. This criterion is not applicable.</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><u>Proposed Finding</u>: <strong>This criterion is not applicable.</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>At its April 23, 2018 meeting, Planning Commission unanimously approved a modification of staff's finding for Criterion G [identified as Criterion (7) in this report] striking the proposed condition of approval entirely. The proposed finding as presented to Planning Commission is shown below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Proposed Finding for approval</u>: <strong>This criterion is conditionally met. Proposed condition: The applicants shall insure that minimum fire separation distances as required in Oregon Structural Specialty Code (OSSC) Table 602 will be provided between any new development on the subject Lots and existing development on the properties abutting Market Street to the west. This may be accomplished by dedicating a “no build” easement on the plat, by recording a restrictive covenant prohibiting building along the west property boundary, or by some other method proposed by the applicant and deemed acceptable by staff. The “no build” area width and location along with easement/covenant language must assure that minimum fire separation distances will be provided. The easement and/or restrictive covenant will be reviewed by both City Development Services staff and Klamath County Building Division staff once submitted by the applicant to verify that this condition is met.</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Notice of both the City Council and prior Planning Commission public hearing was sent to surrounding property owners within 500’ of the affected area. Notice of the City Council and Planning Commission public hearings was also published in the Herald and News on July 22, 2018 and April 8, 2018. No formal comments were received from property owners within the noticing area although neighbor testimony was provided during the April 23, 2018 Planning Commission meeting which has been included in the attached meeting minutes.<strong> </strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p><strong>Decision 1</strong> - Findings as approved by Planning Commission and modified by Staff:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Accept the proposed findings.</li>
	<li>Modify the proposed findings to mitigate any concern identified during the public hearing to approve the application.</li>
	<li>Modify the proposed findings to deny the application.</li>
</ol>

<p><strong>Decision 2</strong> - Decision on proposed Tentative Subdivision replat</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the Tentative Subdivision replat with the proposed conditions from the Planning Commission.</li>
	<li>Approve the Tentative Subdivision replat with additional or modified conditions as desired.</li>
	<li>Deny the Tentative Subdivision replat application.</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: There is no negative fiscal impact to the City.</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Aug 06, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.1 </span>MARIJUANA INITIATIVE PETITION IP-2018-01-24-NB</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: NICKOLE BARRINGTON - CITY RECORDER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Consideration of state-mandated formal action regarding Initiative Petition #IP-2018-01-24-NB, which will allow recreational marijuana production and sales and impose a 3% tax on retail sales, based on receipt of the Klamath County Clerk's notice verifying collection of 1,864 signatures, which is more than the number required to place the initiative petition in front of City voters.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>On February 8, 2018 Chief Petitioners for Initiative Petition #IP-2018-01-24-NB, Edward Medina and Marianne Yong, filed paperwork with the City Recorder to start the state-regulated Initiative Petition ("IP") process. The IP has a Ballot Title Caption of: <em>Allows recreational marijuana production and sales and a 3% tax on retail sales</em>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><em><u>Summary of the filing process includes</u></em>: after the initial filing on January 4, 2018 petitioners re-filed the Petition with the proposed ordinance language on January 18, 2018; the City Recorder then reviewed and accepted the completed filing;&nbsp;the Ballot Title was written by the City Attorney and published in the Herald and News on January 30, 2018; no formal objection&nbsp;was&nbsp;received by Circuit Court from any Klamath Falls Citizen, so the ballot title stood approved; the City Recorder then approved the signature collection cover sheet and signature sheets on February 8, 2018 and signature collection began; and on&nbsp;July 11, 2018 the County Clerk verified receipt of signatures from 1,864 registered voters, which was more than the required 15% (1,783) of registered voters' signatures as required&nbsp;by state law. The final step in the Initiative Petition process is to present the information to City&nbsp;Council for consideration of three formal options for action as mandated by state law.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>According to State Rules pertaining to the Initiative Petition Process the Council must either Accept, Reject, or Do Nothing with the Initiative Petition, and the later two options (Reject or Do Nothing) will cause the same result: the matter will be referred to the City voters in November 2018. Staff also notes that due to the <em>proposed</em> imposition of a 3% tax on retail sales of recreational marijuana, the City Charter requires this matter to be submitted to City voters, so there is no option with this Initiative Petition to simply <em>accept</em> the IP and enact the proposed ordinance into law.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The above-referenced filing process, to the&nbsp;best knowledge of&nbsp;City and County staff, has been followed according to state regulation. Multiple complaints were made during the signature collection process and were investigated locally and found to be unverifiable.&nbsp;Immediate notifications and acknowledgments were made at the time of the complaints by City and County staff and contact&nbsp;was made to and by the Chief Petitioners at that time. On July 30, 2018 another anonymous compliant was made regarding the signature collection process and has been&nbsp;referred to the State Elections office for further investigatory action. Following formal Council action at the&nbsp;August 6th Council Meeting,&nbsp;the City Recorder will file the appropriate&nbsp;state forms with the County Clerk on August 7th.&nbsp;Staff recommends that Council affirm&nbsp;receipt of the required number of signatures received from the County Clerk's Office&nbsp;and refer the IP&nbsp;to City voters at the General Election in November 2018.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Affirm receipt of notice dated July 11, 2018 from the Klamath County Clerk verifying collection of 1,864 valid signatures and to refer Initiative Petition #IP-2018-01-24-NB, a<span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">l</span><span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">lowing recreational marijuana production and sales and </span><span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">imposing a 3% tax on retail sales,</span> to City voters for consideration at the November 6, 2018 General Election.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reject the Initiative Petition, or Do Nothing, both of which will also&nbsp;refer the IP to City voters.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>The financial impact would be&nbsp;the same for Options 1&nbsp;and 2; if approved by City voters, the IP would generate sales tax revenues for the City of Klamath Falls, but staff is not able to provide any revenue projections.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:</p>

<p>Staff recommends Council Approval of Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>- Chief Petitioners (Edward Medina and Marianne Yong)</p>

<p>- Klamath County Clerk</p>

<p>- OLCC&nbsp;Representative</p>

<p><br>
<u>DOCUMENTS ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Initiative Petition Filing (IP-2018-01-24-NB) with Proposed Ordinance</p>

<p>- Ballot Title Publication (dated January 30, 2018)</p>

<p>- Petition Cover Sheet with Approved Signature Collection Sheet</p>

<p>- Notice from Klamath&nbsp;County Clerk (dated July 11, 2018)</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Aug 06, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.2 </span>DESIGN SERVICES CONTRACT AMENDMENT WITH RH2 ENGINEERING, INC. FOR THE STEWART LENNOX WATER SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS PROJECT IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $23,401</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action (Consent)</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: CITY ENGINEER - SCOTT SOUDERS</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City execute a design services contract amendment with RH2 Engineering in the not-to-exceed amount&nbsp;of $23,401&nbsp;to combine Stewart Lennox Water System Improvement Project's&nbsp;&nbsp;Phase 1 and Phase 2 construction documents into a single construction package?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The City Water Division has identified the need to improve fire flow capabilities in the Stewart Lenox area south of Highway 66, between Agate Street and Granite Street. The existing infrastructure, consisting of mostly 2” water lines, cannot provide adequate fire protection to the area. When the area was developed, prior to being part of the City, there were no fire hydrants or adequately sized pipes installed as part of the water system infrastructure.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In the Fall of 2017, the City retained RH2 Engineering, Inc. to perform an Alternatives Analysis studying water infrastructure improvement opportunities for the area. The study identified a two-phase project to be completed as follows:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Phase I – Construction of approximately 3000 lineal feet of new 12-inch water transmission main beginning at the corner of Hwy 66 and Agate Street and ending near the intersection of Highway 66 and Granite Street.</li>
	<li>Phase II – Construction of approximately 3900 lineal feet of 8-inch water distribution main along the adjoining residential streets. These segments will include new fire hydrants and domestic services.</li>
</ul>

<p>RH2 was previously awarded a design services contract in the amount of $73,155 to complete Phase 1 of this project. During Phase 1 design, <u><em>the team identified a significant potential financial savings by combining the design and construction phases into a single project</em></u>. RH2 was asked to provide a quote to combine the project design and produce one bid package for construction. The amendment proposal and fee schedule is attached for reference. This proposal further explains the cost savings potential that should be realized by combining the two project phases into a single construction project.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the Design Services Amendment Proposal for RH2 Engineering, Inc. in the amount of $23,401.</li>
	<li>Deny the Design Services Amendment Proposal for RH2 Engineering, Inc., revise the scope and request a new amendment proposal.</li>
	<li>Deny the Design Services Amendment Proposal for RH2 Engineering, Inc. and proceed with Phase I and contract design services for Phase II at a later date.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>The FY2018-2019 adopted budget identifies a Water Division capital outlay allocation of $800,000 for the Stewart Lennox Distribution Improvements. This money was initially intended to fund construction of Phase 1. By authorizing this design services amendment request, the project will be fully designed (Phases 1 &amp; 2) within FY18/19 and a construction start date will be pushed back to spring of 2019. The project will be constructed over two fiscal budget years.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>All three Council options will utilize funds allocated for this project.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Staff recommends approving Council Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>RH2 Engineering, Inc.</li>
</ul>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Consultant Services Contract Amendment</li>
	<li>Consultant Scope &amp; Fee Amendment Proposal</li>
	<li>Project Site Exhibit Map</li>
</ul>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Aug 06, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.3 </span>REQUEST TO INCREASE THE AUTHORIZED CONSTRUCTION CONTINGENCY FOR THE NORTH ELDORADO AVENUE IMPROVEMENT PROJECT BY $33,000</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: SCOTT SOUDERS&nbsp;- CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City Council increase the authorized construction contingency for the North Eldorado Avenue Improvements Project by $33,000?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>On March 19, 2018, City Council authorized staff to execute a contract with Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC for the North Eldorado Improvement Project in the not-to-exceed amount of $962,000. Additionally, Council also authorized a construction contingency allowance of $96,200 – 10% of the anticipated construction costs.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>At the time of Council authorization, staff believed a 10% contingency would be adequate to account for potential unforeseen conditions and/or changes in scope that may would likely be encountered during construction. However, to date there have been five change orders comprising 12 separate items that have accounted for roughly $64,500 in additional cost. The attached “Project Change Order Log” summarizes each change order.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The project is nearly 75% complete and the remaining contingency does not appear to be adequate to complete the project. The contingency allowance was initially projected to primarily be available during the final task of grinding and paving operations. These tasks typically carry the greatest unknowns due to the variability in existing condition surface grades and potential subgrade soft spots that may need repair. However, unanticipated existing conditions drove the need for additional work during early phase sidewalk and curb construction operations.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>As with all contingency allocations, the revised request is an allowance projection based on information currently available. Our team has spent significant time attempting to identify any further unforeseen conditions that may require additional expenditures. We have broken these estimates into three categories: 1) asphalt pre-level allowance; 2) soft spot repair; and 3) additional quantities for curb/sidewalk and asphalt.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The additional request will bring the overall contingency to 13%, which is well within typical construction contingencies for this type project.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve contingency increase of $33,000, bringing the total authorized contingency to $129,200.</li>
	<li>Deny the contingency increase request and direct staff how to proceed in the event the original $96,200 contingency is reached.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>The FY2018-2019 Adopted Budget identifies a Streets Division capital outlay allocation of $3,159,500 for infrastructure improvements, of which $707,500 is allocated for the North Eldorado Improvements Project. Since this project crosses two fiscal budgets, it is difficult to determine the fiscal calendar accounting split at this point in time. However, given the overall capital budget and the time of year, there is adequate budget to cover the requested contingency increase.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Staff recommends Council approval of Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: N/A</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Project Change Order Log</li>
</ul>

<div class="rightcol">Aug 06, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.4 </span>CONSTRUCTION SERVICES CONTRACT WITH JAMES W. FOWLER COMPANY FOR THE PELICAN BOOSTER PHASE 3 WATERLINE AND BOOSTER STATION PROJECT IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $1,552,923</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: SCOTT SOUDERS - CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City execute a construction services contract with James W Fowler Company in the not-to-exceed amount of $1,552,923, plus&nbsp;an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $310,585, for construction of the Pelican Booster Phase 3 Waterline and Booster Station Project?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The City’s 2010 Water Master Plan identifies the need for additional water supply from the Conger Well Field to the areas surrounding the hospital. The Pelican City Booster Station Project is a multi-phased project comprised of new water transmission mains and a new booster pump station. Phase I of this project, constructed during the summer of 2016, included installation of approximately 3,600 lineal feet of new water transmission main along Montelius Street between Nevada Avenue and Gage Road and along Gage Road between Montelius Street and Alma Alley. Phase II of this project, constructed during the summer of 2017, included installation of approximately 3,000 lineal feet of new 16” water main along Lakeport Boulevard between Hanks Street and City property across the street from Thomas Lumber Company to the north. Phase 3, to be constructed during fall/winter of 2018, will consist of a water booster pump station and the final connection to existing pipe infrastructure near the Highway 97 intersection at Dan Obrien Way.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>RH2 Engineering was hired to aide in the preparation of the plans and technical specifications for this project. A formal request for construction bids was publicly advertised in the Herald and News and the Daily Journal of Commerce. A non-mandatory pre-bid meeting was held on May 22, 2018 where bidders had the opportunity to discuss the project with the design team and staff. Bids were received from only one company on June 1, 2018.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Engineer’s Estimate for this project was published between $1.35 million and $1.40 million. James W Fowler Company (JWF) initially submitted their bid in the amount of $1,642,923. Considering the City only received one bid, and that bid exceeded the Engineer’s Estimate, staff worked with JWF to explore Value Engineering ("VE") opportunities as allowed under state public contracting regulations. JWF was successful in identifying six (6) items that resulted in a potential savings of $89,569 (see attached JWF VE Letter). Staff and RH2 reviewed the proposal and accepted all proposed VE items, resulting in a new proposed cost of $1,552,923.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Although still above the original Engineer’s Estimate, considering the bidding environment and recent material cost increases, staff and RH2 believe it is in the best interest of the City to proceed with the project based on the new proposed cost. A construction services contract will be drafted by staff,&nbsp;approved by the City Attorney, and executed by both parties prior to the&nbsp;work commencing.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve a contract with James W Fowler Company in an amount not-to-exceed $1,552,923 and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $310,585.</li>
	<li>Reject a Contract with James W Fowler Company, modify the project scope and rebid the project.</li>
	<li>Reject a Contract with James W Fowler Company and postpone the project.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>Design Phase and Bid Phase soft cost expenditures are anticipated to total approximately $152,926. Staff anticipates an additional soft cost allowance of $74,400 for construction inspection and materials testing during construction. The total probable project expenditure equals $2,090,834, including a 20% construction contingency allowance if necessary. Refer to the attached Budget Analysis Form for further detail.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Funds for this project are available through the City’s FY 2018/19 Adopted Budget in the Water Division Capital Outlay Fund. Specifically, $1.4 million has been allocated to construction of this project. An additional $540,000 is available from the Stewart Lennox Water System Improvements Project due to its construction postponement to accommodate a single-phase project. An additional $152,000 was expended under FY 2017/18 budget for design services.</p>

<ol>
	<li>Council Option 1 will utilize FY18/19 funds available for this project.</li>
	<li>Council Option 2 will delay the project into next fiscal year.</li>
	<li>Council Option 3 will cancel the project for construction this fall/winter and delay the ability for the City Water Division to utilize significant infrastructure already installed under phases 1 and 2 of this project.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Staff recommends approval of&nbsp;Council Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>James W. Fowler Company</li>
</ul>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Project Location Exhibit</li>
	<li>Budget Analysis Form</li>
	<li>Confirmation of Bid Opening</li>
	<li>JWF VE Letter</li>
	<li>Notice of Intent to Award</li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.5 </span>PURCHASE OF PLAYGROUND EQUIPMENT AND INSTALLATION SERVICES FROM PLAYCRAFT SYSTEMS FOR MILLS PARK IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $81,415</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>

<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOHN BELLON - PARKS MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should City Parks purchase a playground system and installation services from PlayCraft Systems in&nbsp;the not-to-exceed amount of $81,415 under National Inter-governmental Purchasing Alliance ("NIPA") pricing?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Mills Park has one basketball court and one 6-bay swing set. There is currently no additional playground equipment. The wooden&nbsp;play equipment was removed from the Park in 2002 due to failure to meet public playground safety guidelines. </span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">In the fall of 2017, Cascade Health Alliance awarded a $50,000 grant to City Parks to go toward the purchase of new a play system for Mills Park. City staff proposed an additional $50,000 in the 2018-2019 CIP for purchase and installation of a projected $100,000 playground system. In June of 2018, Ford Family Foundation awarded an additional $25,000 to go toward the purchase of the new system. Park staff intend to provide site excavation and finish work following installation of the playground equipment by PlayCraft&nbsp;Systems. Cascade Health Alliance employees are volunteering to join Park staff on September 27, 2018 to complete the playground and celebrate the grand opening. </span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">The Parks Advisory Board has approved this purchase and project at its June 14, 2018 meeting and recommends Council approval.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>1)&nbsp;Approve purchase and installation of new playground system from PlayCraft Systems through NIPA in the not-to-exceed amount of $81,415.&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
</ol>

<p>2) Deny the purchase and installation.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="line-height: normal;">The FY2018-2019&nbsp;Adopted Budget identifies a Parks Division Capital Outlay of $100,000 for a Mills Park Playground Structure. The CIP identifies the $100,000 allowance as a&nbsp;$50,000 grant received from Cascade Health Alliance plus $50,000 allocated as City operational revenue.&nbsp; Subsequent to preparation of the CIP and City Budget, the Parks Division received an additional $25,000 grant from the Ford Family Foundation for the Mills playground project.&nbsp;Therefore, a total of $125,000 is available for this project.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="line-height: normal;">The estimated total project expenditure, with a 15% contingency, is $101,792 (see attached Budget Analysis). Purchase and installation of the playground structure by PlayCraft Systems is $81,415. Park staff allowance for materials and equipment is estimated to be an additional $7,100.</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">1) Council approval of this request will utilize funds available for the&nbsp;project.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">2) Council denial&nbsp;of the project may&nbsp;result in the loss of the $50,000 grant from&nbsp;Cascade Health Alliance and of the $25,000 grant from&nbsp;Ford Family Foundation.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;<span style="line-height: normal;">Staff recommends Council approve&nbsp;Option 1.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: PlayCraft&nbsp;Systems</p>

<p>Quote from PlayCraft&nbsp;System</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Aug 06, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.6 </span>BLIGHT AND HOUSING STOCK QUALITY</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW92ZV6FAC13"><div class="name">Goal #1 - Citizens feel safe and secure in their homes, work sites, and public places.</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: NATHAN CHERPESKI - CITY MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp; Should City Council authorize up to $50,000 budgeted in the current fiscal year to match the County's funds to support efforts to address blighted properties within the community?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>Several weeks ago, City staff members were invited to a work session with the County Commissioners and a citizens group anxious to tackle removing blighted properties in the community.&nbsp; The group has already removed several blighted properties.&nbsp; These unoccupied buildings were eyesores and uninhabitable.&nbsp; Working with the owners, a group of private citizens organized the demolition of each property.&nbsp; The City contributed funds to cover the dumpsters from Waste Management for those buildings within city limits.&nbsp; The group would like to expand their efforts with support from the City and County.&nbsp; While still under discussion, the funds would likely go to an existing non-profit agency to manage.&nbsp; The proposed non-profit suggested at the meeting with the Commissioners was the Klamath-Lake Regional Housing Center managed by SCOEDD.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>One of the tools the City adopted to remove blight is the option for receivership.&nbsp; One issue holding us back on using this tool is finding qualified receivers.&nbsp; SCOEDD, utilizing an existing non-profit entity, has expressed an interest in being a receiver of these blighted properties.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The County has agreed to provide them $50,000 to start the ball rolling.&nbsp; The City included $50,000 in the budget for use as seed money to improve housing stock in the community. Council could direct some of these funds to this effort.&nbsp; Staff would recommend retaining some funds for the primary purpose of encouraging new workforce housing.&nbsp; Staff would recommend making&nbsp;$25,000 available this fiscal year, and an additional $25,000 in next year's budget<span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"> for</span><span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"> Council and Budget Committee consideration</span>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>1. Authorize $50,000 to support a non-profit dedicated to blight removal.</p>

<p>2. Authorize&nbsp;a grant&nbsp;of $25,000 to a non-profit entity dedicated to blight removal in this fiscal year, and direct staff to include an additional $25,000 in next year's&nbsp;Budget for Council and Budget Committee's consideration.</p>

<p>3. Decline to act at this time and give staff further direction.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>The recent Budget included $50,000 to provide seed money to improve housing stock.&nbsp; KCEDA has assembled a group looking at getting more housing built.&nbsp; These funds were to help in that effort.&nbsp; While not directly related, this would address some of the issues.</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Staff recommends Council approve Option 2.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Klamath County Commissioners</p>

<p>SCOEDD</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>: N/A</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Aug 06, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.7 </span>AUTHORIZE EXECUTION OF COLLECTIVE BARGAINING AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE CITY AND TEAMSTERS LOCAL 223</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: BROKE MARSHALL - SUPPORT SERVICES DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should City Council authorize&nbsp;execution of&nbsp;a three-year Collective Bargaining Agreement with Teamsters Local Union Number 223&nbsp;for the period of July 1, 2018 through June 30, 2021.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>The City and Teamsters have a collective bargaining agreement covering approximately 35&nbsp;represented employees.&nbsp;These employees work in the Police Department and include sworn and non-sworn personnel.&nbsp;The contract with Teamsters expired on June 30, 2018.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The City and Teamsters began negotiating a new agreement in April 2018.&nbsp;On July&nbsp; 10, 2018, the parties tentatively agreed to a new three-year contract and the employees in Teamsters Union notified the City they ratified the attached three-year contract on July 20, 2018.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Significant provisions of the agreement include the following</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>The contract is effective for the period of July 1, 2018 to June 30, 2021;&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Salaries are increased by three (3%) of the base salary for Year One; four (4%) of the base salary for Year Two; and two (2%) of the base for Year Three;</li>
	<li>Providing a hiring incentive for continuous service; and</li>
	<li>Elimination of clauses as a result of the recent US Supreme Court case, <u>Janus v. AFSCME</u></li>
</ul>

<p>There are additional changes relating to vacation scheduling, work schedule, canine handlers, incentive pay, working out of classification, and sidearms and ammunition.&nbsp; Additionally, a previously executed Memorandum of Understanding was incorporated into the new contract.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The full cost of the July 1, 2018 salary increase of three percent (3%) and related pension and payroll taxes is $108,000.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Option 1: Move to authorize execution of the collective bargaining agreement between the City of Klamath Falls and Teamsters Local 223.</p>

<p>Option 2: Decline to authorize execution and direct staff to renegotiate with Teamsters Local 223.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The financial impacts for the first year of the contract are described in the Summary and Background section.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Staff recommends Council approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Brent Jensen, Teamsters Representative</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Proposed Teamsters Contract (w/track-changes)</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Aug 06, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.8 </span>SALARY INCREASE DISCUSSION AND AUTHORIZATION FOR CITY MANAGER AND MUNICIPAL COURT JUDGE</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: BROOKE MARSHALL - SUPPORT SERVICES DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE(S) BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Issue One</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;Should Council increase the City Manager's salary in the same percentage amount determined for other non-represented employees in the category of "above 50% within the salary range," which is an amount of two and one-half percent&nbsp;(2.5%)&nbsp;of base salary?</p>

<p><u>Issue Two</u>:&nbsp; Should Council increase the Municipal Judges's contract amount by a one-time bonus in an amount to be determined by Council?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p><u>Issue One</u>: The annual performance management salary increases for management and non-represented employees for Fiscal Year 2017-18 receiving&nbsp;a "satisfactory" on their 2017-18 performance evaluations are as follows:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>0%-24% of salary range =&nbsp;&nbsp; between 3.5% and 5% increase to base salary</li>
	<li>25%-49% of salary range = 3.25% increase to base salary</li>
	<li>50%-100% of salary range = 2.5% increase to base salary</li>
</ul>

<p>City Manager Nathan Cherpeski received a satisfactory&nbsp;performance evaluation by Council during an executive session on April 5, 2018.&nbsp;Mr. Cherpeski is currently at 64% within his salary range. A 2.5 % increase to the City Manager's current salary would be $3,694.60.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Issue Two</u>: Municipal Court Judge, Nathan Ratliff received a satisfactory performance evaluation during an executive session with Council on April 5, 2018.&nbsp;Judge Ratliff is a contract employee for the City.&nbsp; During fiscal year 2016-17, Council approved Judge Ratliff to receive a one-time bonus of $2,500 for his work as Municipal Court Judge for the City.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>Option 1A: Move to authorize salary increase for the City Manager in the amount of 2.5% of base salary.</p>

<p>Option 1B:&nbsp;Move to authorize a one-time contract bonus for Municipal Court Judge in an amount determined by Council.</p>

<p>Option 2A: Decline to authorize salary increase for the City Manager in the amount of 2.5% of base salary and give direction to staff.</p>

<p>Option&nbsp;2B:&nbsp;Decline&nbsp;to authorize a one-time contract bonus for the Municipal Court Judge and&nbsp;give direction to&nbsp;staff.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>Salary increase to City Manager base salary in the amount of two and one-half percent (2.5%). One-time bonus to Municipal Court Judge in an amount determined by Council.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Staff recommends Council&nbsp;authorize Option 1A and Option 1B.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Municipal Court Judge</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u><em>Public Comment</em></u> is time reserved&nbsp;for citizens to speak on a matter that is not on the scheduled of the Meeting Agenda. Each person has 3 minutes to speak and must state their name and address for the record (<em>it is preferred that you fill out a Public Comment Form and return it to the City Recorder</em>). If there are multiple people from one Group/Entity that wish to convey "one message" they can have a Group Speaker and, upon request, would be given 5-10 minutes from Council to speak.</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="AZGRL8552812">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jul 16, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>CONSIDERATION TO CHANGE A PORTION OF N. ALAMEDA AVENUE TO A ONE-WAY TRAFFIC FLOW DIRECTION</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>R<u>EPORT</u> GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;MARK WILLRETT - PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should the Council authorize a portion of N. Alameda Avenue to be changed from two-way to one-way traffic flow?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;The Klamath Falls City School District (KFCS) is proposing to reconfigure parking at Klamath Union High School (KU).&nbsp; In conjunction with the parking changes, KFCS is also proposing to change the traffic flow on North and South Alameda between the Monclaire&nbsp;intersections to one-way traffic.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In December of last year, ZCS Engineering, on behalf of the KFCS, submitted the concept of changing the direction of traffic flow.&nbsp; Discussion also took place regarding&nbsp;parking counts, bus loading/unloading and emergency services access.&nbsp; After discussion, the plan was updated and&nbsp;reviewed by KFCS and Klamath County Fire District 1, and both entities supported the proposal.&nbsp; This concept proposed is to convert North and South Alameda to one-way in a counter-clockwise direction when looking&nbsp;at the school from the Wall Street Intersection.&nbsp; This was presented to the Traffic Control Board (TCB) on June 12 for a recommendation.&nbsp; In the end, members of the TCB had concerns with bus loading and unloading and recommended to the City Manager that a revised plan be brought back.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The revised plan before Council tonight would change the direction of traffic on North and South Alameda to a clockwise&nbsp;direction when looking at the school from Wall Street.&nbsp; This change will allow bus loading and unloading to occur curb-side, adjacent to the school, which is considerably safer than the original proposal. The attached revised plan (Option B) that the District has provided has been reviewed and recommended for approval&nbsp;by the&nbsp;TCB and the City Manager.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Section 6.015(2)(a) authorizes the City Council to designate the direction of traffic flow.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>1.&nbsp; Approve the change in traffic flow on N. Alameda Avenue between the Monclaire&nbsp;intersections from two-way to one-way.</p>

<p>2.&nbsp; Deny the request to change the direction of traffic flow and keep the direction status quo.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1.&nbsp; There is no financial impact to the City in approving this recommendation.&nbsp; The School District is paying for new signage and striping.</p>

<p>2.&nbsp; There would be no financial impact to the City for this option either.&nbsp;This decision would keep the same unsafe parking configuration that currently exists.&nbsp;There could be financial impacts to residents as vehicles are damaged.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp; Council to approve Option 1: Move to a<span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">pprove the change in traffic flow on N. Alameda Avenue&nbsp;between the </span>Monclaire<span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">&nbsp;intersections from two</span><span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">-</span><span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">way to one</span><span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">-</span><span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">way in a clockwise direction</span>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Klamath Falls City School District</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>- Plan Sheet prepared by ZCS showing KU's&nbsp;proposed traffic modifications (Option B)</p>
</div>

<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.2 </span>CONTRACT FOR SERVICES WITH THE KLAMATH FALLS DOWNTOWN ASSOCIATION IN THE AMOUNT OF $50,000 FOR FISCAL YEAR 2018/2019</div>

<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: NATHAN CHERPESKI - CITY MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council authorize <span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">the City Manager to enter into </span>a contract for services with the Downtown Association in the amount of $50,000?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp; The City has provided varying levels of support to the Klamath Falls Downtown Association over the years.&nbsp; Last year, Council and the budget committee approved $50,000 to support Downtown efforts.&nbsp; This year, the budget committee approved the same funding level based on a written request.&nbsp; City staff proposes to use a contract for services to memorialize how the funds are to be spent and to what purposes.&nbsp; We used a similar contract last year, and find that a contract helps clarify how the funds are to be spent and allows for greater accountability.&nbsp; The proposed scope of work is attached.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1.&nbsp; Authorize the City Manager to enter into a contract for services with the Klamath Falls Downtown Association in the amount of $50,000 for services listed in the scope of work.</p>

<p>2.&nbsp; Amend the scope of services and authorize the City Manager to negotiate with the Klamath Falls Downtown Association based on the change(s).</p>

<p>3.&nbsp; Decline to act and give staff further direction.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>- $50,000 was approved&nbsp;in the Budget for these services.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council approve Option 1; authorizing the City Manager to enter into a contract for services with the Klamath Falls Downtown Association in the amount of $50,000 for services listed in the proposed scope of work.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Klamath Falls Downtown Association</p>

<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.3 </span>CONTRACT FOR SERVICES WITH KLAMATH COUNTY ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION IN THE AMOUNT OF $50,000 FOR FISCAL YEAR 2018/2019</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: NATHAN CHERPESKI - CITY MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the Council authorize the City Manager to enter into a contract for economic development services with the Klamath County Economic Development Association?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp; The City has provided varying levels of support to KCEDA&nbsp;for many&nbsp;years.&nbsp; For the last several years, Council and the Budget Committee approved $50,000 to support renewed economic development efforts.&nbsp; This year, the Budget Committee approved the same funding level based on a written request.&nbsp;City staff proposes to use a contract for services to memorialize how the funds are to be spent and&nbsp;for what purposes.&nbsp;We used a similar contract last year and found that a contract helps clarify how the funds are to be spent and allows for greater accountability.&nbsp;The proposed scope of work is attached.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1.&nbsp;Authorize the City Manager to enter into a contract for services with the Klamath County Economic Development&nbsp;Association in the amount of $50,000 for services listed in the contract scope of work.</p>

<p>2. Amend the scope of services and authorize the City Manager to negotiate with the Klamath County Economic Development&nbsp;Association based on the change(s).</p>

<p>3.&nbsp;Decline to act and give staff further direction</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1.&nbsp;$50,000 was approved&nbsp;in the Budget for these services.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council approve Option 1.</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jul 16, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.4 </span>SET LEGISLATIVE PRIORITIES FOR 2019 LEAGUE OF OREGON CITIES</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: NATHAN CHERPESKI&nbsp;- CITY MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Does Council wish to recommend to the Oregon League of Cities, the City's top four legislative priorities as well as the four items the City views as least important?&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp; The League has traditionally requested that cities submit a survey stating the areas of most importance to that city.&nbsp; We have participated in several fashions over the years.&nbsp; With some new direction and more time afforded the City, I am asking the Council to weigh in on what items we should recommend as the most important.&nbsp; Additionally, the League is also asking us to identify those areas of least interest to the City, if we are inclined to do so.&nbsp; Since it is the League of Cities, it&nbsp;seems those items regarding local control should be a priority while those that are state actions should be of less interest to the League.&nbsp; However, the list provided was created by multiple committees formed with member volunteers.&nbsp; The votes of all cities will be tabulated and a recommendation sent to the full League Board for a final selection.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>While Council is welcome to change this list, staff recommends consideration of the&nbsp;following as most important to the City of Klamath Falls</u>:</p>

<p>Annexation Flexibility&nbsp;</p>

<p>City Comparability for Compensation</p>

<p>PERS Reform</p>

<p>Qualification Based Selection</p>

<p>Right-of-Way and Franchise Fee Authority</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>: After discussion,&nbsp;</p>

<p>1. Select the top four priorities and direct the City Manager to submit those on behalf of the City.&nbsp; Additionally, the City could select those that are of least interest to Klamath Falls.</p>

<p>2. Direct the City Manager to submit the four priorities listed above.</p>

<p>3. Decline to participate in the League Survey.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>There are no financial impacts to participate.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to&nbsp;approve&nbsp;Option 1.</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="B2ESZ471EE80">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jul 16, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.5 </span>REJECTION OF ALL BIDS FOR THE AIRPORT MAINTENANCE HANGAR PROJECT</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOHN BARSALOU - AIRPORT DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should&nbsp;the City reject all bids for the Airport Maintenance Hangar Project based on unexpected requirements and new project expenses that exceed the Airport's funding sources?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The Airport received a $2.8 million grant from the State under the <em>Connect</em>Oregon VI program in January 2017 to build an aircraft hangar and associated infrastructure on the eastside of the Airport.&nbsp;The objective was to initiate development on the eastside of the Airport, taking advantage of the soon to be constructed Taxiway B which would improve access to several parcels of land.&nbsp;A contract with Mead &amp; Hunt for architectural/engineering services to design and provide construction administration of the facility was approved by Council in April 2017.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In January 2017 the Airport issued a Request for Statement of Interest and Qualifications for potential lessees of the new aircraft hangar and EAL Leasing, Inc. was selected as the intended lessee.&nbsp; EAL Leasing, Inc. dba Century Aviation Services and Emergency Airlift is an existing tenant&nbsp;at the Airport providing Fixed Base Operator (FBO) services to the general public as well as to their own fleet of aircraft.&nbsp;They desired additional space&nbsp;to expand their business and in November 2017 Council approved a Lease with EAL Leasing, Inc. for the to-be-constructed&nbsp;<em>Connect</em>Oregon aircraft hangar.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In April 2018 the Airport issued an Invitation for Bids to construct a 27,000 square foot metal aircraft hangar and a 26,550 square feet associated parking lot along with necessary infrastructure (utilities, roadway, etc.).&nbsp;The bid deadline was May 24, 2018 and the following five bids (amount represents Base Bid plus thirteen Alternate Bid Items) were received:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">Kinsman Construction&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $5,189,857.00</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">Modoc Contracting&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $5,756,646.00</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">Diversified Contractors&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $5,927,790.00</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">Ordell Construction&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$6,329,500.00</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">Adroit Construction&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$6,337,767.00</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p>Mead &amp; Hunt has reviewed the bids for cost and reasonableness and recommends awarding the contract to Kinsman Construction for the Base Bid plus Alternate Bid Items 01, 03, 05, 06, 08 and 11 for a total contract price of $5,176,170.00 which was contingent upon successful negotiation and identification of additional funding.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>At the time of bid opening, the Airport had secured $4,750,000 in funding for the project consisting of the <em>Connect</em>Oregon grant ($2,800,000), a City economic development grant ($400,000), a City 10-year inter-fund loan ($1,150,000), and Airport funds ($400,000).&nbsp; Of the $4.75 million approximately $655,000 was already committed to architectural, engineering, and construction administration services plus permit fees and an allowance for contingency.&nbsp;To cover the shortfall in funding available to award the bid as recommended, the Airport staff thought to replace the City inter-fund loan with a $2.25 million, 30-year loan from Business Oregon.&nbsp; In addition, the Airport was negotiating&nbsp;with EAL Leasing, Inc. for an increase in their Building Area Lease Rate from $4.50/sq ft/yr to $5.50/sq ft/yr to provide the necessary revenue for&nbsp;the loan payback.&nbsp; On July 9th, EAL Leasing, Inc. notified the Airport&nbsp;that they are <u>not</u> able to move forward with the project due to the increased cost.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Increased project costs are likely attributable to the following items: 1) time to obtain approval for the ConnectOregon grant, 2) higher than expected concrete costs, 3) the pre-engineered metal building (due to recent tariffs on steel) costs, 4) the fire suppression (foam) system costs, and 5) site (earthwork) costs as outlined in the attached letter from Mead &amp; Hunt.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Award&nbsp;bid and execute a contract with Kinsman Construction contingent upon receiving funds through a Business Oregon loan and attempt to find a replacement&nbsp;tenant.</li>
	<li>Reject all submitted bids for the Aircraft Maintenance Hangar and instruct staff to explore revising&nbsp;the scope of the&nbsp;project to align with the available funds. This would constitute&nbsp;rebidding the project - this option requires approval of <em>Connect</em>Oregon.</li>
	<li>Reject all submitted bids for the Aircraft Maintenance Hangar and abandon current plans to construct a hangar.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>The City no longer&nbsp;has a potential tenant and the increased cost to complete the project exceeds the ability&nbsp;to cover the higher construction costs; therefore, staff recommends against proceeding with the project.&nbsp;Some funds were received from <em>Connect</em>Oregon and they&nbsp;will be returned and the grant closed out per the grant documents assuming no further options exist.&nbsp;From the time of grant approval through the bidding process, approximately, $400,000 was spent on architectural/engineering services to design and bid the project&nbsp;in accordance with the approved Mead &amp; Hunt Contract.&nbsp;Airport Funds will be used to cover those expenditures and financing in the form of the inter-city loan and the economic development grant will be reversed. The City will retain the plans as drawn for any future projects.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp; Council to approve Option 3;&nbsp;r<span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; cursor: text; orphans: 2; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">ejectin</span><span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; cursor: text; orphans: 2; background-color: transparent; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">g all submitted bids for the Aircraft Maintenance Hangar and abandoning the&nbsp;current plans to construct a hangar</span>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Adroit Construction</p>

<p>Diversified Contractors</p>

<p>Kinsman Construction</p>

<p>Modoc Contracting</p>

<p>Ordell Construction</p>

<p>Mead &amp; Hunt, Inc.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Mead &amp; Hunt Recommendation of Award Letter</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jun 18, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">5. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">5.1 </span>RESOLUTION FOR THE STATE REVENUE SHARING FOR FISCAL YEAR 2018-2019</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;FINANCE MANAGER&nbsp;- JESSICA LINDSAY</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City elect to receive State Revenue Sharing Funds for Fiscal Year 2018-2019, as approved by the City’s Budget Committee?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>: State law (ORS 221.770) provides for the distribution of certain revenues to cities in the form of “State Revenue Sharing,” which includes&nbsp;liquor and tobacco taxes.&nbsp; State Revenue Sharing law requires the City to pass an Ordinance or Resolution each year stating the City elects to receive State Revenue Sharing Funds the next fiscal year. The law also requires the City to certify that two public hearings were held to allow public comment on the possible uses of State Revenue Sharing Funds. The first public hearing was held before the Budget Committee on May 22, 2018. The second public hearing will be held in conjunction with this agenda item and was advertised as a public hearing before the City Council. In the approved Budget for Fiscal Year 2018-2019 currently before Council for adoption, the City proposes to use the State Revenue Sharing Funds for general governmental purposes.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Elect to receive State Revenue Sharing funds for Fiscal Year 2018-2019.</p>
	</li>
	<li>Do not elect to receive State Revenue Sharing funds for Fiscal Year 2018-2019.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>If Council approves&nbsp;Option 1, the City will receive an estimated State Shared Revenues of approximately $643,975.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>If Council approves Option 2, the City will not receive the estimated State Shared Revenues of approximately $643,975.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:</p>

<p>Staff recommends Council&nbsp;approve Option 1;&nbsp;approve the resolution electing to receive State Shared Revenues&nbsp;and use the funds for general government purposes.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Citizen Members of the Budget Committee</p>

<p><br>
<u>DOCUMENTS ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Proposed Resolution</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council adopt&nbsp;the 2018-2019 Budget of the City of Klamath Falls, Making Appropriations for Fiscal Year 2018-2019 and Levying Taxes?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">The 2018-2019 Budget was approved as presented by the City’s Budget Committee on May 22, 2018.&nbsp;Taxes were approved by the Budget Committee at a rate of $5.4423 per $1,000 of assessed value for operating purposes in the General Fund and Airport Fund, and <span style="background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">$</span><font style="background-color: rgb(46, 204, 113);"><span style="background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">220,000</span></font> to pay general obligation bonded debt. <p>2)&nbsp; Decrease the budget, appropriations, and/or tax levy from what was approved by the Budget Committee.</p>

<p>3)&nbsp; Increase the budget and/or appropriations from what was approved by the Budget Committee. If the appropriation increase is over $5,000 or 10%, whichever is greater, of the fund appropriations, an additional budget hearing is required to occur before July 1, 2018.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

The amounts included have been added to the City’s long-range plan; levying taxes provides the necessary funds to balance the General Fund and Airport Fund operating budgets and pay debt service on the general obligation bonded debt.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Any decrease would need to be accounted for in the long-range plan.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Any increase would need to be accounted for in the long-range plan.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:</p>

<p>Council to approve Option 1; approving&nbsp;the resolution adopting the Budget for FY 2018-2019, making appropriations, and levying taxes as approved by the Budget Committee.</p>
