<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="AXP3QB7ACC45">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jun 18, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">5. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">5.4 </span>DOWNTOWN BUILDING IMPROVEMENT GRANT AWARD - REALLOCATION REQUEST</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><span style="font-family:Tahoma,Geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size:12px;"><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: </span></span>JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family:Tahoma,Geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size:12px;"><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: </span></span>Should Council approve a&nbsp;reallocation of awarded Downtown Building Improvement grant dollars for an alternate project scope&nbsp;per the request of the Klamath Basin Brewing Company?<span style="font-family:Tahoma,Geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size:12px;">&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family:Tahoma,Geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size:12px;"><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</span></span></p>

<p>To improve downtown building aesthetics and facilitate building reuse and occupancy, City Council made $50,000 in leveraged grant funding available within the 2016/2017 Fiscal Budget which carried into the current 2017/2018 Budget Year.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>On the recommendation of a small Citizen Design Review Panel, Council awarded a combined seven&nbsp;Building Improvement and Facade grants, attached to this Agenda Report, at the December 5, 2016 Council meeting. Awarded project work included exterior painting, elevator installation, and structural improvements among other items. Per a Council-provided extension, all grant work and associated reimbursement&nbsp;requests were&nbsp;to have been submitted&nbsp;to City Administration&nbsp;staff by&nbsp;May 31, 2017.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>While most&nbsp;grantees&nbsp;completed&nbsp;their awarded project work,&nbsp;Klamath Basin Brewing Company (KBB) was unable&nbsp;to complete the&nbsp;project scope of its awarded grant application&nbsp;and&nbsp;KBB&nbsp;is asking Council to reallocate the grant&nbsp;dollars to different improvements already constructed. Typically for grants, this type of change would either be disapproved or required prior to making the improvements.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>KBB was awarded $10,000&nbsp;to complete needed building preparation&nbsp;work to construct a new walk-in freezer and expanded kitchen area within an adjacent, and&nbsp;then newly&nbsp;purchased building.&nbsp;The proposed project would&nbsp;renovate&nbsp;the space previously occupied by Craig&nbsp;Douglas Photography&nbsp;and&nbsp;connect into the existing&nbsp;restaurant area. While the KBB Board envisioned completing said improvements at the time of its grant application&nbsp;award, construction was&nbsp;pushed back due&nbsp;to strained&nbsp;project financing&nbsp;and to address more near-term business&nbsp;needs.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The KBB Board&nbsp;is asking&nbsp;that&nbsp;Council&nbsp;consider&nbsp;reallocating&nbsp;its&nbsp;previously awarded&nbsp;$10,000&nbsp;Building Improvement grant to partially cover the build-out costs of a recently&nbsp;completed bottling room facility located within the same recently purchased and&nbsp;adjacent building.&nbsp;In reviewing the bottling room project prior to its completion with KBB Board President&nbsp;Terry Wagstaff, the needed&nbsp;improvements seemed in-line with&nbsp;Building Improvement grant program&nbsp;intentions&nbsp;and to facilitate&nbsp;the re-use&nbsp;of previously vacant spaces.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>To complete the bottling room area, KBB redesigned and replaced unstable building support columns, added floor drains and a new sloping floor surface, completed needed water, sewer, and electrical enhancements, and created new connections between the existing brewery area and the bottling room and between the bottling room and the building's Klamath Avenue rear.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Whether or not KBB's&nbsp;grant award is reallocated for different project use, staff has gained&nbsp;takeaways from the&nbsp;pilot grant program's implementation and to apply to&nbsp;the solicitation, award, and follow-up for&nbsp;similar City-sponsored&nbsp;grant opportunities. For example, leveraged grant funding&nbsp;for building change of use and facade work has been included&nbsp;within the proposed 2018/2019&nbsp;Fiscal Budget.&nbsp;If the requested grant&nbsp;award reallocation is not approved by Council, KBB will have the same opportunity&nbsp;as other businesses and property owners to apply for&nbsp;future building improvement funding&nbsp;opportunities. While staff is supporting this request, it isn't without reservation.&nbsp;Changing a grant scope of work can set a difficult precedent for the future.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family:Tahoma,Geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size:12px;"><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</span></span></p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve&nbsp;KBB's&nbsp;request to&nbsp;reallocate&nbsp;awarded&nbsp;Downtown Building Improvement grant dollars for an alternate project use.</li>
	<li>
	<p>Deny KBB's&nbsp;request and provide&nbsp;staff further direction.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><span style="font-family:Tahoma,Geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size:12px;"><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</span></span></p>

<p>$50,000 was allocated within the 2017/2018 Fiscal&nbsp;Budget’s Economic Development/Property Fund to&nbsp;support downtown&nbsp;building change of use and face work. If Council approves&nbsp;KBB's&nbsp;request for&nbsp;project and award reallocation, a qualifying $10,000 reimbursement would be drawn from this&nbsp;budgeted source.&nbsp;If grant&nbsp;project reallocation is not approved,&nbsp;any&nbsp;leftover funds would remain in the Economic Development/Property Fund and could be used differently going forward.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family:Tahoma,Geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size:12px;"><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:</span></span></p>

<p>Staff recommends approving Council Option 1: move to approve&nbsp;Klamath Basin Brewing's&nbsp;request to&nbsp;reallocate&nbsp;awarded&nbsp;Downtown Building Improvement grant dollars for an alternate project use.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family:Tahoma,Geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size:12px;"><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</span></span></p>

<p>Terry Wagstaff</p>

<p>Klamath Basin Brewing&nbsp;Company, Board President</p>

<p>1320 Main&nbsp;Street</p>

<p>Klamath Falls, OR 97601</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family:Tahoma,Geneva,sans-serif;"><span style="font-size:12px;"><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</span></span></p>

<ul>
	<li>Downtown Improvement Grant Award Listing</li>
	<li>KBB Modified&nbsp;Grant Reimbursement Request</li>
	<li>KBB Grant Agreement &amp; Application</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.2 </span>RESOLUTION FOR WORKERS' COMPENSATION COVERAGE TO CERTAIN PUBLIC SAFETY VOLUNTEERS FOR FISCAL YEAR JULY 1, 2018 - JUNE 30, 2019</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: BROOKE MARSHALL - SUPPORT SERVICES DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp; Should the City adopt a resolution extending Workers' Compensation Coverage to Certain Public Safety Volunteers from July 1, 2018 through June 30, 2019?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>Since 2005, the City has granted Workers' Compensation Coverage for Firefighters, Paramedics&nbsp;and all Reserve Police Officer Volunteers.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Two Firefighter Paramedics employed&nbsp;by Klamath County Fire District #1 (KCFD #1) volunteer their services to the SWAT Team. As part of the City's agreement with KCFD&nbsp;#1, the City agrees to extend coverage to the two individuals only while serving on the SWAT Team, at the agreed-upon assumed monthly wage of $6,000.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Staff recommends the City continue to cover all nine active Reserve Police Officers who volunteer over 6,000 hours annually at the Police Department.&nbsp; The assumed monthly wage for these Officers is $4,100.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Staff also recommends the City grant coverage to eight Volunteers in Police Service (VIPS) who provide daily service in the form of vehicle maintenance, deliveries and purchases, vacation house checks, and neighborhood vehicle speed assessments.&nbsp; The assumed monthly wage for these officers is $500.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Klamath Falls Police Department would like to continue this coverage for the above-mentioned volunteers for the period of July 1, 2018 through June 30, 2019, while they perform these much appreciated and critical community services.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1) Adopt the Proposed Resolution.</p>

<p>2) Reject the Proposed Resolution.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1) It is estimated this coverage will cost approximately $17,140.&nbsp; The funds to cover this expense will come from the 2018-19 Fiscal Year budget.</p>

<p>2) Without insurance, the potential risk is unknown.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:</p>

<p>Council to approve Option 1;&nbsp;and&nbsp;introduce the Resolution and read it by title only; and move to approve the Resolution.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.3 </span>2018 AIRFIELD CRACK SEAL PROJECT WITH MUSSER SEALCOAT &amp; STRIPING IN THE AMOUNT OF $49,550</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp; JOE GOETZ -&nbsp;AIRPORT OPERATIONS MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp; Should the City enter into a contract to perform crack sealing on airfield pavements to meet FAA Part 139 requirements and perform routine pavement maintenance to extend the life of Airport pavement?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>Annually the Airport performs routine pavement maintenance activities to maintain compliance with Part 139 standards and extend the life of airfield pavements. There are approximately 100 lane miles of pavement on the Airport. A vast majority of this pavement is asphalt pavement. This year approximately 21,200 pounds of crack seal material will be applied to asphalt pavements at the Airport.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The work covered by the contract will include the preparation of the cracks for sealing, removing all vegetation from the cracks, application of crack seal material, and touch up paint of airfield markings affected by crack seal material per FAA Part 139 standards.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Quotes for this project were solicited based on a total weight of material applied as opposed to linear foot. Due to the varying depths and age of pavement present at the Airport, the cracks being sealed vary in size and depth. This makes it difficult for contractors to accurately quote the amount of material that would be needed for this project.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The following quotes were received for the work:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Musser Sealcoat and Striping Inc. - $49,550.00</li>
	<li>Webb Asphalt - Did Not Respond to Advertisement</li>
	<li>Rocky Mountain Construction - Did Not Respond to Advertisement</li>
	<li>Albina Asphalt - Does Not Perform This Work In Klamath Falls</li>
	<li>Knife River - Does Not Perform This Work in Klamath Falls</li>
</ul>

<p>Musser Sealcoat and Striping's quote this year amounts to $2.33/lb of applied material which compares to last year's awarded contract (also to Musser Sealcoat and Striping) of $2.19/lb of applied material.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Approve a contract with Musser&nbsp;Sealcoat&nbsp;&amp; Striping.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reject the contract and direct staff to revise the project scope and obtain new quotes.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>The Airport has budgeted funds for this work under its Fiscal Year 2019 operating budget.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp; Council approve Option 1;&nbsp;move to authorize staff to execute a contract with Musser Sealcoat &amp; Striping in the amount of $49,550 for 2018 Airfield Crack Seal Project.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Musser Sealcoat and Striping Inc.</p>

<p>Rocky Mountain Construction</p>

<p>Webb Asphalt</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Informal Solicitation Quote Record</p>

<p>- Proposed Contract with Musser Sealcoat and Striping Inc.</p>

<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.4 </span>AIRPORT 2018 RUNWAY 14/32 MARKING PROJECT WITH APPLY-A-LINE IN THE AMOUNT OF $72,723.50</div>

<div class="rightcol">Action</div>

<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE GOETZ -&nbsp;AIRPORT OPERATIONS MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City enter into a contract to refresh paint markings on the airfield to meet FAA Part 139 requirements?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>Annually, the Airport refreshes a portion of the airfield’s markings to maintain compliance with Part 139 standards. There is an approximate total of 350,000 square feet of pavement markings on the airfield and the Airport schedules a third of these markings to be refreshed each year. This year approximately 108,000 square feet of markings on Runway 14/32 are scheduled to be refreshed.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The work covered by the contract will include the removal of approximately 22,000 square feet of old markings as needed and the application of new paint and glass beads per FAA Part 139 standards.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Airport requested quotes from the three Oregon companies who provide this service and the following quotes were received for the work:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Apply-A-Line $72,723.50</li>
	<li>Hick’s Striping &amp; Curbing - Did Not Respond to Request for Quotes</li>
	<li>Specialized Pavement Marking - Did Not Respond to Request for Quotes</li>
</ul>

<p>Last year we received three bids for approximately 145,270 square feet of paint markings and 12,660 square feet of markings removal.&nbsp; We&nbsp;received bids from the above three bidders and&nbsp;Apply-A-Line was the successful bidder last year.&nbsp; The bid received&nbsp;this year is similar to the range of bids received last year.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve a contract with Apply-A-Line in the amount of $72,723.50.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Reject a contract and direct staff to revise the project scope and obtain new quotes.</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>The Airport has budgeted funds for this work under its Fiscal Year 2019&nbsp;operating budget.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council approve Option 1;&nbsp;m<span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">ove to authorize staff to execute a contract with Apply-A-Line for 2018 Runway 14/32 Marking Project in the amount of $72,723.50.</span></p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jun 18, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.5 </span>AUTHORIZATION FOR CITY INSURANCE COVERAGE FOR FISCAL YEAR 2018-2019 FROM VARIOUS INSURANCE CARRIERS AS PROPOSED BY THE CITY'S INSURANCE AGENT OF RECORD, GREAT BASIN INSURANCE</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp; BROOKE MARSHALL - SUPPORT SERVICES DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp; Should the City purchase various insurance coverages as recommended by Great Basin Insurance?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The City's Insurance Agent of Record, Great Basin Insurance, recommends purchase of the following insurance, either Option A or Option B:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>OPTION A</u></p>

<ul>
	<li>Commercial Property from City County Insurance Services (CIS) for $108,949.66&nbsp; This is an increase from last year by $7,670.63 due to higher renewal property values for building and contents as well as PIO coverage. This is an increase of approximately 7% above last year;</li>
	<li>Commercial Public Entity General Liability from CIS for $245,675.65.&nbsp; This is an increase of almost 10% over last year's rates in this category;</li>
	<li>Commercial Auto Physical Damage from CIS for $19,672.53; this is an increase of $632.64; an increase of approximately 3%;</li>
	<li>Excess Crime Coverage (for employee theft) from CIS for $755.00; this is the same amount as last year;</li>
	<li>Workers Compensation from SAIF for $130,871.00; this is a decrease compared to last year of approximately 23%; and</li>
	<li>Airport Liability for $14,177; this is the same amount compared to last year.</li>
</ul>

<p><u>OPTION B</u></p>

<ul>
	<li>Commercial Property from CIS for $87,463.46; this is a decrease of approximately 22%.&nbsp;This reflects a significant premium reduction due to increasing the Commercial Property Deductible from $15,000 to $50,000.&nbsp;Based on analysis and discussion of the City's property claim trends with Great&nbsp;Basin Insurance over several years, the City could save significantly ($21,486.20 this year) by increasing to a $50,000 deductible.&nbsp;Additionally, as part of this Option, staff is recommending Council establish a Risk Fund, to be funded&nbsp;with premium savings and additional reserve funds in an amount to be approved by Council.&nbsp; This fund would be established from the General Fund's Reserve Fund, and dedicated to the specific purpose of saving for payment of the deductible should the City incur a large claim(s). <strong>This increase in deductible is the <u>only</u> difference from Option A</strong>;</li>
	<li>Commercial Public Entity General Liability from CIS for $245,675.65.&nbsp;This is an increase of almost 10% over last year's rates in this category;</li>
	<li>Commercial Auto Physical Damage from CIS for $19,672.53; this is an increase of $632.64; an increase of approximately 3%;</li>
	<li>Excess Crime Coverage from CIS for $755.00; this is the same amount as last year;</li>
	<li>Workers Compensation from SAIF for $130,871.00; this is a decrease compared to last year of approximately 23%; and</li>
	<li>Airport Liability for $14,177; this is the same amount compared to last year.</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Under either Option, the City receives a credit for ($12,511.20) from CIS because it purchases multiple lines of credit.&nbsp; The City is also credited by contracting with Great Basin Insurance.&nbsp; This savings is the amount for an insurance agent ($41,779.47) and the reduced cost of Great Basin Insurance ($23,500).</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>This coming fiscal year, in conjunction with Great Basin Insurance, the Risk Management Committee will continue to research alternative insurance liability plans such as Aggregate and Retro Plans to determine if there would be future prospective savings to the City in choosing one of these plans.&nbsp; After initial analysis in conjunction with staff from Great Basin Insurance, staff determined it would be premature to switch to one of these options at this time, and that further research and planning is necessary.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve Option A, authorize insurance coverage as proposed by Great Basin Insurance in the amount of $532,052.02.</li>
	<li>Approve Option B, authorize insurance coverage as proposed by Great Basin Insurance in the amount of $510,565.82, and direct staff to establish a Risk Fund from the General Fund Reserve Fund and fund with premium savings and additional Reserve Funds in an amount to be determined by Council.</li>
	<li>Decline to purchase insurance, and give direction to staff.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Option A:&nbsp;$532,052.02</li>
	<li>Option B:&nbsp;$510,565.82</li>
	<li>Depending upon Council direction, could reduce insurance and have various impacts.&nbsp;</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:</p>

<p>Move to approve Option B authorizing purchase of insurance coverage <span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; cursor: text; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">in the amount of $510,565.82</span><span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; cursor: text; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"> </span>and directing staff to create a separate category within the General Fund Reserve Fund establishing a Risk Fund.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Great Basin Insurance (Agent of Record)</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Premium Summaries for Option A and Option B</li>

<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.6 </span>CORRECTIONS TO LEGAL DESCRIPTIONS IN SPECIAL ORDINANCE 18-01 VACATING A PORTION OF THE YALE STREET RIGHT-OF-WAY</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council acknowledge and incorporate revised&nbsp;legal descriptions and exhibits into Special Ordinance 18- 01, vacating&nbsp;a portion&nbsp;of the Yale Street right-of-way, previously approved by Council on May 21, 2018?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>Council previously considered&nbsp;a request to vacate&nbsp;an approximately&nbsp;4,000&nbsp;square foot portion of Yale Street right-of-way at its&nbsp;May 7, 2018&nbsp;meeting. Council unanimously approved applicant Joshua Goossen's request&nbsp;to vacate a portion of Yale&nbsp;Street right-of-way and introduced the&nbsp;associated Ordinance for first reading by title only at the May 7th Council meeting. At the May 21, 2018&nbsp;City Council meeting, Council approved the ordinance&nbsp;for second and final reading by title only. The approved Ordinance (18-01) included legal descriptions and drawings for the vacated portion of the right-of-way and an easement that was being reserved for sanitary sewer easement purposes within the vacated portion of the right-of-way.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>After the second&nbsp;reading of the Ordinance, and before&nbsp;becoming&nbsp;effective&nbsp;30 days thereafter,&nbsp;applicant's&nbsp;surveyor&nbsp;advised staff that additional subdivision corners had been located by survey crews when finalizing a related&nbsp;partition plat, and the discovery of those corners necessitated that the legal descriptions for the vacated right-of-way area and the reserved easement needed to be changed.&nbsp;Surveyor Marc Cross provided staff the revised legal descriptions for the vacation area, which is&nbsp;included as Ordinance Exhibit A, and the associated sewer line reservation easement, which is included as Ordinance Exhibit&nbsp;B, and he provided a revised sewer easement visual depiction, Ordinance Exhibit C, which also required&nbsp;correction. To provide Council additional perspective on the corrections, Mr. Cross also provided a drawing (<span style="float: none; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: left; text-decoration: none; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; white-space: normal; word-spacing: 0px; display: inline !important;">attachment labeled</span><span style="float: none; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: left; text-decoration: none; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; white-space: normal; word-spacing: 0px; display: inline !important;"> "Yale Street Vacation - Comparison of </span><span style="float: none; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: left; text-decoration: none; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; white-space: normal; word-spacing: 0px; display: inline !important;">Legals") </span>comparing the vacated right-of-way and easement areas as <u>originally</u> described (in pink on the attachment) with the same areas as depicted by the <u>corrected</u> legal descriptions (in black on the attachment).</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>A copy of the original,&nbsp;approved Ordinance 18-01 vacating a portion of Yale Street right-of-way and reserving the easement, and a copy of the approved Ordinance, inclusive of corrected&nbsp;exhibits, have been attached to this Agenda. Staff believe&nbsp;the changes to the legal descriptions for the vacated area and the easement area are similar in nature to typographical errors and do not change the intent of Council to grant the vacation request and reserve an easement and Council's approval of these revised legal descriptions does not have any meaningful effect&nbsp;on Council's previous approval decision. Staff finds the proposed changes are nominal&nbsp;and do not require a rehearing; therefore, staff requests Council acknowledge&nbsp;and incorporate&nbsp;the corrected exhibits&nbsp;within&nbsp;Special Ordinance 18-01.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>To provide further&nbsp;application background and prior to City Council's initial consideration, the Planning Commission held a public hearing&nbsp;on April 9, 2018 where it&nbsp;took testimony and passed a unanimous motion&nbsp;accepting and approving staff's proposed findings&nbsp;and conditions, and recommending Council approve the vacation&nbsp;as requested.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Planning Division staff sent notice of the vacation request&nbsp;to surrounding&nbsp;property owners&nbsp;and&nbsp;affected agencies and utilized any received&nbsp;comments&nbsp;to&nbsp;prepare the conditions of approval accepted by&nbsp;Planning Commission and later modified and approved by&nbsp;City Council.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Acknowledge and incorporate the&nbsp;corrected legal descriptions and exhibits into&nbsp;Special Ordinance 18-01, vacating&nbsp;a portion&nbsp;of&nbsp;Yale Street right-of-way, previously approved by Council on May 21, 2018.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reject the inclusion of the revised legal description and exhibits and provide staff further direction.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>There&nbsp;are no anticipated financial impacts related to modifying the approved Special&nbsp;Ordinance vacating a portion of Yale Street right-of-way to include&nbsp;corrected&nbsp;exhibits.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>

<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">5.1 </span>APPROVAL OF CONSENT AGENDA - Meeting Agenda and Prior Meeting Minutes (provided under separate cover)</div>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="AYRS3H647968">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jun 04, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>AN ORDINANCE CREATING A RIGHT-OF-WAY MAINTENANCE FEE AND REPEALING THE STREET LIGHTING FEE - FIRST READING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
<a class="goal" unique="AW92ZV6FAC13"><div class="name">Goal #1 - Citizens feel safe and secure in their homes, work sites, and public places.</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;MARK WILLRETT - PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should the Council repeal the existing Street Lighting Fee and replace it with a Right-of-Way Maintenance Fee?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp; The City currently charges $2.50/month on every water meter for a street lighting fee.&nbsp;These funds are used solely for costs associated with the City's street lights.&nbsp; Diligent use of these funds in prior years and the installation of LED fixtures has resulted in substantially lower electrical and maintenance costs, which has contributed to a current carry-over in excess of&nbsp;$300,000 in the street lighting account.&nbsp;It is forecasted that even with electrical costs, maintenance and future capital requirements, there will still be an annual surplus of&nbsp;approximately $60,000.&nbsp;However, these funds are restricted and can only be used for costs associated with street lighting.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Per the City Code, property owners are required to maintain sidewalks and street trees adjacent to their property even though they are in the public right-of-way.&nbsp;This can often create a financial burden on the property owner and creates a difficult enforcement issue&nbsp;for the City.&nbsp;The&nbsp;proposed ordinance is aimed at helping solve this problem from both the property owner's and City's perspective by eliminating the Street Lighting Fee and replacing it with a Right-of-Way&nbsp;Maintenance Fee.&nbsp;If&nbsp; approved by Council, the responsibility to repair and replace existing <span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">public</span><span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"> </span>sidewalks and to prune/maintain street trees within the right-of-way would become the City's,&nbsp;while the responsibility to remove snow, vegetation and sweep sidewalks would remain the responsibility of the adjacent property owner.&nbsp;Likewise, maintenance of grass, weed removal, shrub pruning and watering within the right-of-way would remain the responsibility of the adjacent property owner.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Initially, staff would like to use a portion of the funding to provide contracted services&nbsp;would focus on pruning street trees within the right-of-way that encroach over the roadway.&nbsp; These branches hinder street sweeping and construction activities.&nbsp;Proper pruning can also assist with the health of the tree and improve corridor aesthetics.&nbsp;Once the initial pruning is completed, the City would like to use&nbsp;City workers to maintain the street trees with occasional help from contractors.&nbsp;A portion of the right-of-way maintenance funds would also be used to begin repair on substandard, dangerous sidewalks throughout the City.&nbsp;These funds would generally not be used for new construction and developers would continue to be responsible for the construction of sidewalks and street trees in new subdivisions.&nbsp;While the exact magnitude of needed sidewalk repair is not known at this time, staff would propose to prioritize and contract out the majority of repair work.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>1.&nbsp; Approve the proposed ordinance as presented repealing the existing Street Lighting Fee and replacing it with a Right-of-Way Maintenance Fee.</p>

<p>2.&nbsp; Decline to approve the ordinance and maintain the existing Street Lighting Fee.</p>

<p>3.&nbsp; Decline to approve the ordinance, maintain the Street Lighting Fee and direct staff to prepare the necessary documentation for Council to reduce the monthly charge.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1. No direct impact to funding. Forecasting indicates that adequate funding will be available for street lighting and to begin addressing tree and sidewalk maintenance within the right-of-way.</p>

<p>2.&nbsp;No direct impact to funding.&nbsp;However, the surplus of funds will continue to grow due to their restricted status.</p>

<p>3.&nbsp;A $0.25 reduction in the fee would reduce annual revenue&nbsp;by approximately $20,000.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: N/A</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>- Proposed Ordinance</p>
</div>

<a class="public-file" target="_blank" order="00001" unique="AZAUEJ60C423" href="/or/cokf/Board.nsf/files/AZAUEJ60C423/$file/Ordinance.pdf">Ordinance.pdf (184 KB)</a></div>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="AYV8XB7C9A6D">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jun 04, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.1 </span>ADOPTION OF THE 2017 UPDATE OF THE KLAMATH COUNTY MULTI-JURISDICTIONAL NATURAL HAZARDS MITIGATION PLAN</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW92ZV6FAC13"><div class="name">Goal #1 - Citizens feel safe and secure in their homes, work sites, and public places.</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;MARK WILLRETT - PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp; Should the City adopt the updated Klamath County Multi-jurisdictional Natural Hazards Mitigation Plan?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Klamath County has taken the lead in preparing and updating the Multi-jurisdictional Natural Hazards mitigation plan. The updated 2017 plan serves a couple of purposes. The primary purpose is to identify those natural hazards that are most likely to affect Klamath County, assign levels of risk to those events happening and then identify mitigation measures to reduce that risk. The hope is that with planning and collaboration among public agencies, private sector organizations and citizens, losses can be minimized that come from those natural hazards. </span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">The other driving factor in the preparation and adoption of this plan relates to grants and funding. Formal adoption of this plan enables Klamath County to be eligible for the Emergency Management Performance Grant which funds 50% of the County Emergency Management program every year. It also enables both the County and City to apply for pre-disaster mitigation grants and makes both the City and County eligible for post-disaster federal assistance.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">1. Adopt the 2017 Update of the Klamath County Multi-jurisdictional Natural Hazards Mitigation Plan and authorize the Mayor to sign.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">2. Do not adopt the Plan.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">3. Do not adopt the Plan and direct staff to prepare the City's own stand alone plan.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p><span style="line-height: normal;">1. There are no immediate financial impacts to adopting the plan. Adoption does allow the City to apply for pre-disaster mitigation grants and post-disaster federal assistance. </span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">2. Various federal emergency management grants and disaster relief assistance would be jeopardized by not adopting the plan.</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">3. There would likely be consultant costs in preparing this document. </span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- 2017 Update of the Klamath County Natural Hazards Mitigation Plan</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Jun 04, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.2 </span>AUTHORIZE THE PURCHASE OF PROPERTY LOCATED AT 418 KLAMATH AVENUE</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY:</u> NATHAN&nbsp;CHERPESKI - CITY MANAGER&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp; Should Council give final authorization to close on the purchase of 418 Klamath Avenue in the amount of $60,000?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>: Staff presented the opportunity to acquire the two lots that comprise the site of the recently demolished Masonic Lodge to City Council in March 2018.&nbsp; After receiving authority from Council, City Staff spoke with representatives from the Lodge after the site had been cleared.&nbsp;Staff tendered an offer of $60,000&nbsp;for the property.&nbsp;An escrow account has been established with Amerititle pending due diligence efforts by the City.&nbsp;Staff now seeks authority to finalize the transaction once the due diligence&nbsp;has been completed.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1) Authorize the City Manager to sign the necessary documents needed to purchase and close escrow&nbsp;on&nbsp;the property located at&nbsp;418 Klamath Avenue.</p>

<p>2) Decline to act at this time and provide staff further direction.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>1) Funds for the purchase were approved as part of a recent supplemental budget for Fiscal Year 2017-2018.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>2) The City has deposited&nbsp;$10,000 in earnest money for the purchase.&nbsp; If we withdraw for reasons not associated with the due diligence we will forfeit those funds.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Dan Bevis</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Property Assessor Map</p>

<p>- Property Street View Map</p>

<p>- Purchase and Sale Agreement</p>

<p>- Preliminary Title Report</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="AYP6EM836566">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">May 21, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LAND USE PUBLIC HEARING - QUASI JUDICIAL</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>REQUEST TO REPLAT A PORTION OF THE RAILROAD ADDITION SUPPLEMENTAL PLAT TO INCORPORATE A FORMER RAILROAD SPUR PROPERTY INTO EXISTING LOTS ABUTTING SPRING STREET - Item pulled and may be presented at a future meeting.</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council approve the proposed replat&nbsp;to incorporate a former railroad spur property into existing lots abutting Spring Street?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The applicant proposes to replat a portion of a current subdivision within the Railroad Addition. The subject area is roughly bounded by existing and developed lots fronting South Spring Street to the east, existing and developed lots fronting Market Street to the west, Oak Avenue to the north, and Elm Avenue to the south.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>To the immediate west of the subject parcels fronting Spring Street is a strip of land that appears to be a mid-block alley and which currently functions as if it were City right-of-way. This area is, however, owned by the Union Pacific Railroad, successor of the Southern Pacific Railroad. This <font style="background-color: rgb(211, 84, 0);"><strike><span style="background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">s</span></strike><span style="background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">trip of land</span></font> previously provided rail spur access to the rear side of businesses in the Railroad Addition but is no longer in use.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The adjacent owners of the subject tax lots (listed below) have collectively decided to purchase the area owned by Union Pacific Railroad (R-3809-033BC-01500-000) abutting and behind each of their parcels to enlarge each of their lots.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Subject Parcels:</p>

<ol>
	<li>R-3809-033BB-09900-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, Lots 5A and 5B; 600 Spring Street – Owner.</li>
	<li>R-3809-033BC-01400-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, Lots 7A, 7B, 8A and 8B; James L Robinson – Owner.</li>
	<li>R-3809-033BC-01300-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, Lots 9A, 9B, 10A and 10B; Mickey D &amp; Esther J Cummings – Owner.</li>
	<li>R-3809-033BC-01200-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, Lots 11A, 11B, 12A, 12B and 13A; Mickey D &amp; Esther J Cummings – Owner.</li>
	<li>R-3809-033BC-01100-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, Lots 13B, 14A, 14B and 15A; 600 Spring Street – Owner.</li>
	<li>R-3809-033BC-01000-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, Lots 15B and 16A; Linda Michele Darrah Bogatay – Owner.</li>
	<li>R-3809-033BC-01500-000; Supplemental Plat Railroad Addition, Block 7C, railroad spur; Union Pacific Railroad Co. – Owner.</li>
</ol>

<p>Primary access to all lots will remain from existing from the south Spring Street frontage, and each lot has access to and is served by all requisite utilities.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>On April 23, 2018, the Planning Commission held a public meeting and made a recommendation for subdivision approval to City Council with modified findings as presented below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>REFERRING AGENCY COMMENTS:</u></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>City Engineering</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>There are no City utilities located within the former railroad spur property.</li>
	<li>The proposed replat shows the south 312 feet of the former railroad spur property being attached to Lots 15B and 16A to create the new Lot 5. It is understood the property owner, Linda Michele Darrah Bogatay, may in the future utilize the former railroad property beginning at its southern boundary on Elm Avenue to access the remainder of the newly created Lot 5. The former railroad spur area, Map/Tax Lot Number R-3809-033BC-01500-000, is currently unimproved and does meet City paving standards for areas used for the parking and maneuvering of vehicles.</li>
</ul>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">While not a condition of approval of the proposed subdivision, this portion of the former railroad spur must be improved to driveway standards, including pavement, prior to its use for vehicular access. A standard driveway approach, meeting the City of Klamath Fall Public Works Engineering Standards, must also be installed on Elm Avenue prior to this location being used for vehicular access. The driveway approach will include new curb, driveway apron, sidewalk through the driveway, and an additional sidewalk panel on either side of the driveway to establish future sidewalk location.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>County Building Department</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Klamath County Building Division has concerns that this replat will result in the following listed buildings/structures to be in violation of code compliance as they now would not have the adequate setbacks from property lines to meet fire separation distances as required in Oregon Structural Specialty Code (OSSC) Table 602. It is assumed that these buildings are classified as “F-1”, “S-1”, “M” or “B” occupancies (or mixed in combination) and typically type 5-B construction type. This would dictate 10 foot separation from building to property lines.</p>

<ul>
	<li>515 Market Street</li>
	<li>553 Market Street</li>
	<li>Blue roofed building on Map/Tax Lot (R-3809-033BC-02100-000)</li>
</ul>

<p>To mitigate the fire separations, one option would be an enforceable deed restriction “no build” zone within 10 feet from property line.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>RELEVANT REVIEW CRITERIA, FACTS AND ANALYSIS</u></p>

<p>This proposal is being reviewed according to the provisions of the Klamath Falls Community Development Ordinance (Chapters 10-14), specifically Sections 11.800-11.825 regarding Tentative Subdivision Plans. Prior to making a recommendation on the proposed subdivision, the Council&nbsp;shall analyze the following criteria and incorporate such analysis in their decision.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>A.&nbsp;Criterion: No tentative plat shall be approved which bears a name using a word which is the same as, similar to, or pronounced the same as a word in the name of any other subdivision in Klamath County, except the words “town,” “city,” “place,” “court,” “addition,” or similar words.</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Staff’s Analysis: The applicants have not proposed a name for this subdivision but rather the subdivision will only be identified by its tract number: Tract 1541. Per review of the City Surveyor this is an acceptable title for the proposed subdivision.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Proposed Finding: No tentative plat shall be approved which bears a name using a word which is the same as, similar to, or pronounced the same as a word in the name of any other subdivision in Klamath County, except the words “town,” “city,” “place,” “court,” “addition,” or similar words. The proposed subdivision has a unique tract number assigned by the Klamath County Surveyor. <strong>This criterion is met.</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>B. Criterion: The streets and roads are laid out so as to conform to the plats of subdivisions and maps of partitions already approved for adjoining property as to width, general direction and all other respects unless the Commission determines it is in the public interest to modify the street or road pattern.</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Staff’s Analysis: This subdivision is a replat of several existing Lots. The newly created (revised) Lots will continue to access from Spring Street. Lot 5 will also have access to Elm Avenue. All streets in the vicinity are existing and there will be no change to the existing street layout with the subdivision as proposed. This criterion is not applicable.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Proposed Finding: <strong>This criterion is not applicable.</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>C.&nbsp;Criterion: Streets for public use are dedicated without any reservation or restriction.</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Staff's Analysis: This subdivision is a replat of several existing Lots. The newly created (revised) Lots will continue to ahe applicants shall insure that minimum fire separation distances as required in Oregon Structural Specialty Code (OSSC) Table 602 will be provided between any new development on the subject Lots and existing development on the properties abutting Market Street to the west. This may be accomplished by dedicating a “no build” easement on the plat, by recording a restrictive covenant prohibiting building along the west property boundary, or by some other method proposed by the applicant and deemed acceptable by staff. The “no build” area width and location along with easement/covenant language must assure that minimum fire separation distances will be provided. The easement and/or restrictive covenant will be reviewed by both City Development Services staff and Klamath County Building Division staff once submitted by the applicant to verify that this condition is met.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>At the&nbsp;April 23, 2018 Planning Commission meeting, the Commission unanimously approved a modification of staff's finding for Criterion G striking the proposed Criterion G condition entirely.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Proposed Finding for approval: <strong>This criterion is&nbsp;met.</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Decision 1 </strong>- Findings as approved by Planning Commission</p>

<ol>
	<li>Accept the proposed findings.</li>
	<li>Modify the proposed findings to mitigate any concern identified during the public hearing to approve the application.</li>
	<li>Modify the proposed findings to deny the application.</li>
</ol>

<p><strong>Decision 2</strong> - Recommendation&nbsp;of Subdivision</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the Subdivision with the proposed conditions from the Planning Commission.</li>
	<li>Approve the Subdivision&nbsp;with additional conditions as desired.</li>
	<li>Deny the Subdivision application.</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: There is no negative fiscal impact to the City.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council approve Option 1; for both Decisions 1 and 2 as listed above.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Matt Bogatay,&nbsp;Bogatay&nbsp;Construction</li>
</ul>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Tentative Subdivision&nbsp;Plan</li>

<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">May 21, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LAND USE PUBLIC HEARING - QUASI JUDICIAL</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.2 </span>A SPECIAL ORDINANCE ANNEXING 1.1 ACRES OF GENERAL COMMERCIAL ZONED PROPERTY LOCATED AT 2922 SOUTH SIXTH STREET – FIRST READING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council&nbsp;approve the proposed annexation of a property contiguous to Klamath Falls City limits?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>The applicant, Adkins Consulting Engineering, LLP, on behalf of Curt Baney, LLC, proposes to annex 1.1 acres of General Commercial zoned property into the City of Klamath Falls. The property is located at 2922 South Sixth Street and was recently developed with a Starbucks Coffee location. The property owner is proposing to construct a second commercial shell building on the same property which will require a change to the site’s water utility service. The development of both buildings has been permitted through Klamath County Planning.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The review of development plans for the Starbucks and proposed second shell building has been a joint effort between both the City and County planning departments. All standards appear to be in conformance with the City's Community Development Ordinance with the exception of the existing Starbucks freestanding sign. The freestanding sign is approximately 15 to 20 feet in height and setback approximately 5 to 10 feet from the property line. The City Standard for freestanding signs is a 15 foot setback from all property lines if the freestanding sign is 9 to 15 feet in height and a 25 foot setback from all property lines if the freestanding sign is 16 to 25 feet in height.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>This property is currently zoned General Commercial in the County. If annexed, the property's zoning will be General Commercial in the City which permits the same uses allowed by County zoning. The subject property is identified as Tax Assessor Map R-3909-3BC, Tax Lot 1000 and further described as Parcel 1 of Klamath County Land Partition 29-14.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>On November 27, 2017, the Planning Commission held a public meeting and made a recommendation for annexation approval to City Council.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>This matter was previously to have been heard&nbsp;at the&nbsp;February 5, 2018 City Council meeting. The item was pulled per the applicant's request and Council postponed&nbsp;the public hearing to a future date certain of April 16, 2018. At the April 16, 2018 meeting, the item&nbsp;was postponed to the present&nbsp;May 21, 2018 City Council meeting&nbsp;to allow for sufficient agenda noticing.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Decision 1</strong> - Findings as approved by Planning Commission</p>

<ol>
	<li>Accept the findings as written to approve the application;</li>
	<li>Modify the findings to mitigate any concern identified during the public hearing to approve the application; or</li>
	<li>Modify the findings to deny the application.</li>
</ol>

<p><strong>Decision 2</strong> - Approval of the Annexation through Ordinance&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the annexation and introduce the Ordinance by title for first reading;</li>
	<li>Approve the annexation with conditions and modify the Ordinance; or</li>
	<li>Deny the annexation.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:&nbsp;There is no negative fiscal impact to the City.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council approve Option&nbsp;1;&nbsp;for both Decisions 1 and 2 as listed above.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Adkins Consulting Engineering, LLP</li>
	<li>Curt Baney, Inc.</li>

<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;SCOTT SOUDERS&nbsp;- CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the Council adopt an ordinance banning tobacco use in City-Owned Parks, Marinas, Cemeteries, and Natural Areas?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In March 2018, representatives from Healthy Klamath and Blue Zones approached the City about prohibiting smoking and tobacco use&nbsp;in&nbsp;City-Owned Parks, Marinas, Cemeteries, and Natural Areas.&nbsp;They had previously&nbsp;presented the idea to the Parks Board, where a recommendation was made to bring the request before Council.&nbsp;As part of the presentation they provided a sample ordinance.&nbsp;Council directed staff to work with the Ordinance and adjust it to&nbsp;accomplish the goal.&nbsp;City Staff altered the proposed Ordinance to remove a provision in the sample ordinance prohibiting smoking or tobacco use within 10 feet of the boundary of any&nbsp;City-Owned Parks, Marinas, Cemeteries, and Natural Areas.&nbsp; Staff believed it would be inappropriate to regulate those activities on properties that are not owned or controlled by the City and recommended that the provision should be stricken.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Ordinance, with&nbsp;that change, is similar to the one previously presented to the Parks Board and City Council.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>1.&nbsp;Approve the Ordinance as written and introduce it for first reading by title.</p>

<p>2.&nbsp;Amend the Ordinance and introduce it for first reading by title.</p>

<p>3. Decline to act at this time and provide staff further direction.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>1. Adopting the Ordinance will not directly cost the City funds. However, it may require additional resources to enforce, and we should note that enforcement will begin with the proper signage in our parks. Community partners, such as the Blue Zones Project, Healthy Klamath Initiative, and Klamath Tribal Health, among others, will donate funds to pay for sign materials and production costs. Parks staff will install where needed.</p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt;">2. Same as above, depending upon the change.</p>

<p>3. No impact.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:</p>

<p>- Hold a public hearing</p>

<p>- Move to introduce the Ordinance for first reading by title only (<em>either as-is or with changes</em>).</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Blue Zones</p>

<p>Healthy Klamath</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Proposed Ordinance</p>

<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: SCOTT SOUDERS - CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City execute a construction services contract with Bob’s Excavating Inc. in the not-to-exceed amount of $74,147 for construction of the Airport Terminal Sewer Replacement Project?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>Staff has identified, through the Capital Improvements Program, various failing and aging sewer collections infrastructure that is in need of replacement and/or repair. The existing 6-inch clay pipe that serves the Airport terminal building is 70+ years old and contains broken sections, offset joints and has extensive cracking. This project will replace a 238-foot segment of failing sewer main with a new 8” pipe as well as the installation of new manholes at each end. The project also includes an operational advantage to the Airport through the installation of a LAV cart dumping station for aircraft service. Barghausen Consulting Engineers, Inc. was retained by the City to assist in design and preparation of bid documents, construction plans and associated estimate of probable construction costs.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>A formal request for construction bids was publicly advertised in the Herald and News and the Daily Journal of Commerce. A non-mandatory pre-bid meeting was held on April 24, 2018 where bidders had the opportunity to discuss the project with the design team and staff. Bids were received from one company on May 3, 2018. The bidder and their price is summarized below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Engineer's Estimate (Published) was $74,000 to $84,000</u></p>

<p>Bob’s Excavating, Inc. Bid - $74,147</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Although only one bid was received, staff reviewed the bid and supporting documents and have determined them to be acceptable.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. in an amount not-to-exceed $74,147 and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $14,829.</li>
	<li>Reject a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc., modify the project scope and rebid the project.</li>
	<li>Reject a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. and postpone the project.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>Design Phase and Bid Phase soft cost expenditures are anticipated to total approximately $17,882. Staff anticipates an additional soft cost allowance of $3,500 for construction inspection and materials testing during construction. The total probable project expenditure equals $110,608, including a 20% construction contingency allowance, if necessary. Refer to the attached Budget Analysis Form for further detail.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Although the funds to construct this Project were originally expected to be allocated with the FY 2018/19 Budget, it was determined that the Water Recovery Division has enough capital<span style="background-color: rgb(211, 84, 0);"> </span>remaining in their overall budget to move forward with the construction this fiscal year. Should there be a shortfall of funds within the capital outlay portion of the Budget, the Finance Department has indicated there are adequate funds within Personnel Services to cover the expense.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve&nbsp;Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>RECOMMENDED MOTION(S)</u>: Move to authorize staff to enter into a Construction Services Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. for the Airport Terminal Sewer Replacement Project in the not-to-exceed amount of $74,147 and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $14,829.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Project Location Exhibit</li>
	<li>Budget Analysis Form</li>
	<li>Confirmation of Bid Opening</li>
	<li>Notice of Intent to Award</li>
	<li>Sample Contract</li>
</ul>

<p><u>REPORT SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Bob’s Excavating, Inc.</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">May 21, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.4 </span>CONSTRUCTION SERVICES CONTRACT WITH BOB’S EXCAVATING INC. FOR THE 2018 MISCELLANEOUS SEWER REPAIRS PROJECT (PHASE I) IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $33,333</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: SCOTT SOUDERS&nbsp;- CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council&nbsp;authorize a construction services contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. in the not-to-exceed amount of $33,333 for construction of the 2018 Miscellaneous Sewer Repairs Project (Phase I)?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>Staff has identified, through the Capital Improvements Program, various failing and aging sewer collections infrastructure that is in need of replacement and/or repair. The 50+ year old sewer main located in the alley of the 1300 Block of Shelley Avenue is severely blocked due to root intrusion and believed to contain broken sections, offset joints, and/or extensive cracking. Due to root blockage, crews are unable to access the line for maintenance and inspection. Currently there are two parallel sewer mains in the alley serving the adjacent residences. The parallel mains were initially scheduled within the CIP to be replaced by one common sewer main.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>RC Group was retained by the City to assist in design and preparation of bid documents for the common sewer main replacement project. Through the initial engineering process, it was determined that one of the existing sewer mains is in adequate condition and at an appropriate depth to serve all of the adjacent residences. The scope of the project was then modified to repair the better of the two mains and transfer service of homes to the single sewer main. RC Group was then asked to limit their scope and prepare construction documents to only address the new service connections and abandon the failed sewer line in place.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Following the change in scope of the Shelly project, it was estimated there would be enough budget remaining to add another sewer spot repair project and combine both projects into one bid package.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Holabird Avenue, north of Van Ness Avenue, currently has a failing sewer line located beneath existing mail boxes and retaining walls. This line also receives effluent discharge from a private pump station located near the Pelican Cinemas. Due to complexity and location of the failing line, it was determined that in-situ pipe lining would be the best solution to repair this line. An Engineer's Estimate, based on regional historical data, indicated the in-situ replacement would be the appropriate repair for this line and the project was believed to be within budget. Construction documents were then finalized for bid.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>A formal request for construction bids was publicly advertised in the Herald and News and the Daily Journal of Commerce. A non-mandatory pre-bid meeting was held on April 24, 2018 where bidders had the opportunity to discuss the project with the design team and staff. Bids were received from one company on May 3, 2018. The lone bidder and its price is summarized below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Estimate (Published) $80,000 to $90,000</u></p>

<p>Bob’s Excavating, Inc. -&nbsp; $151,515</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>As bid, the total combined project exceeds the budgeted funds available for construction. Based off the individual bid schedules, the Shelly Project fell within the anticipated budget range. However, the Holabird&nbsp;Project greatly exceeded the anticipated target budget. After further research and contractor discussion, it was determined that the limited amount of work associated with the proposed in-situ repair was not favorable to outside subcontractors mobilizing to Klamath Falls. Therefore, bids received for the specialty work drove up the cost of construction to a point where the project needs to be delayed for re-evaluation.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Staff has determined adequate budget is available to construct only the Shelly improvements portion of the project. The bidder has agreed to drop the Holabird portion of work and limit the construction contract to only the Shelly Project. The results of the Value Engineering effort led to a revised negotiated bid of $33,333.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. in an amount not-to-exceed $33,333 and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $6,667.</li>
	<li>Reject a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc., modify the project scope and rebid the project.</li>
	<li>Reject a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. and postpone the project.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>Design Phase and Bid Phase soft cost expenditures are anticipated to total approximately $15,225. Staff anticipates an additional soft cost allowance of $4,250 for construction inspection and materials testing during construction. The total probable project expenditure equals $59,725, including a 20% construction contingency allowance if necessary. Refer to the attached Budget Analysis Form for further detail.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The funds for this project are available through the City’s FY 2017/18 Adopted Budget in the Water Recovery Capital Outlay Fund for the 1300 Block Shelley Avenue project in the amount of $75,000.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:</p>

<p>Staff recommends approving Council Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Project Location Exhibits</li>
	<li>Budget Analysis Form</li>
	<li>Confirmation of Bid Opening</li>
	<li>Notice of Intent to Award</li>
	<li>Sample Contract</li>
</ul>

<p><u>REPORT SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Bob’s Excavating, Inc.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">May 21, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.5 </span>APPROVAL OF MEAD &amp; HUNT, INC. FOR AIRPORT ENGINEERING AND PLANNING SERVICES</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp; LINDA TEPPER&nbsp;-&nbsp;AIRPORT BUSINESS MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp; Should Council approve the selection of Mead &amp; Hunt for Airport engineering and planning services for the period of June 2018 through May 2023 for FAA Airport Improvement Program Projects?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) requires the Airport to undertake a selection process for a firm that will handle engineering and planning services for projects funded by Airport Improvement Program (AIP) grants. The FAA allows an engineering firm to be selected for a period of no more than five years.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>During the last selection process in 2014, Mead &amp; Hunt was selected not for a specific time period, but rather through the completion of Taxiway B construction which is estimated to be this June. City Council subsequently also authorized Mead &amp; Hunt to complete the environmental assessment process for the Taxiway G rehabilitation project which is currently underway and is expected to be completed by December 2018. In preparation for beginning the design process for the Taxiway G rehabilitation project the Airport needs to have a new engineer selected and approved.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>A Request for Statement of Qualifications (SOQ) to provide engineering and planning services was published nationally in March 2018 and Mead &amp; Hunt was the only firm to submit a response by the deadline of April 19, 2018. The Airport is satisfied with Mead &amp; Hunt’s performance on past projects and the FAA has no objections on their selection as the Engineer of Record for the period of June 2018 through May 2023. Projects anticipated over the next five years may include rehabilitation of Taxiways G, D, B, F and Runway 7/25.</p>

<p style="margin: 0in 0in 0pt; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Airport recommends retaining Mead &amp; Hunt for a five-year period for engineering and planning services in association with AIP projects. For each AIP project, a separate contract will be negotiated with Mead &amp; Hunt. In accordance with FAA regulations, each contract will undergo an independent fee estimate and will also be subject to FAA approval and the City’s standard contracting policy procedures.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the selection of Mead &amp; Hunt, Inc.&nbsp;<span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">for Airport engineering and planning services for the period of June 2018 through May 2023 for FAA Airport Improvement Program Projects</span>.</li>
	<li>Reject selection of Mead &amp; Hunt and direct staff to reissue Request for Statement of Qualifications.</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>: None.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp; Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Mead &amp; Hunt, Inc.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>: N/A</p>

If there are multiple people from one Group/Entity that wish to convey "one message" they can have a Group Speaker and, upon request, would be given 5-10 minutes from Council to speak.</p>
