<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">May 07, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LAND USE PUBLIC HEARING - QUASI JUDICIAL</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>REPORT ON A SPECIAL ORDINANCE VACATING A PORTION OF THE YALE STREET RIGHT-OF-WAY</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should the City approve a request to vacate an approximately 4,000 square foot portion of the Yale Street right-of-way adjacent to Lots 14 and 15 of Block 40 and Lot 11 of Block 39 of the Buena Vista Addition?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p><span style="line-height: 115%;">The applicant requests the City vacate an approximately&nbsp;4,000&nbsp;square foot portion of the Yale Street right-of-way so the&nbsp;vacated area may be used for an existing driveway and residential use. The subject portion of Yale Street is not improved and provides access to a single residential property owned by the applicant at&nbsp;2300 Yale Street. Yale Street presently terminates at Map/Tax Lot R-3809-030AB-01700 and does not provide through access to West Oregon Avenue for public use. The applicant obtained the written consent of more than two-thirds of the surrounding property owners for the proposed vacation, meeting the requirements of ORS 271.080. </span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Planning Commission held a public hearing&nbsp;on April 9, 2018 where it&nbsp;took testimony and passed a unanimous motion&nbsp;accepting and approving staff's proposed findings&nbsp;and conditions, and recommending Council approve the vacation&nbsp;as requested.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="line-height: 115%;">Planning Division staff sent notice of the vacation application to the potentially affected agencies for&nbsp;review and utilized&nbsp;the following agency comments to&nbsp;prepare&nbsp;conditions of approval, which Planning Commission accepted&nbsp;and recommended&nbsp;for City Council approval.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><u>REFERRING AGENCY COMMENTS</u>:</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><u>City Engineering</u>:</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="tab-stops: .75in;"><span style="color: rgb(12, 12, 12);">A portion of the Yale Street right-of-way was previously vacated, making Yale Street a dead-end street. There are approximately 3 or 4 properties located on the north side of West Oregon Avenue that are extremely difficult to serve with sanitary sewer, given the topography in the vicinity. Sewer service could have been provided to these properties through the Yale Street right-of-way had it not been vacated. With this request to vacate an additional right-of-way area, a sanitary sewer easement shall be dedicated to the City to allow for the connection of the sewer system from West Oregon Avenue to Yale Street. The easement must be 16’ wide, centered on the existing manhole in Yale Street, and connect to West Oregon Avenue in a straight line. The applicant’s engineer shall coordinate with thr City Engineering to determine the exact location for the required easement.</span></span></p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><u>Pacific Power</u>:</p>

<p class="MsoBodyText" style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="color: rgb(12, 12, 12);">There is an existing power pole located on the west side of the portion of the Yale Street right-of-way requested to be vacated. Pacific Power would like to retain the ability to route power service across the portion of Yale Street to be vacated to serve properties on the east side of Yale Street. An easement, restrictive covenant, or other legal agreement shall be reserved across the portion of Yale Street to be vacated to allow Pacific Power to route service across this area. </span></p>

<p class="MsoBodyText" style="margin-left: 40px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p class="MsoBodyText" style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="color: rgb(12, 12, 12);">*Following the Planning Commission's approval, Pacific Power investigated the area further and&nbsp;has informed the City they do not wish to retain an easement.&nbsp;</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u><span style="color: rgb(12, 12, 12);">PUBLIC NOTICE:</span></u></p>

<p><span style="color: rgb(12, 12, 12);">Notice of this&nbsp;public hearing was published in the Herald and News on April 15&nbsp;and April 22, 2018. Notice of the April 9, 2018 Planning Commission meeting was published in the Herald and News on March 18 and March 25, 2018. Notice of the land use application and proposed vacation was&nbsp;mailed to&nbsp;14 area property owners on February 28, 2018. No responses were received.&nbsp;</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the findings and conditions of the Planning Commission; and approve the vacation request introducing the Ordinance for first reading by title only.</li>
	<li>Adopt revised findings and approve the vacation request by modifying the conditions to NOT require an easement for Pacific Power service; and approve the vacation request introducing the Ordinance for first reading by title only.</li>
	<li>Adopt revised findings as deemed necessary by Council and approve the vacation request.</li>
	<li>Adopt revised findings and deny the vacation request.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>There&nbsp;are no anticipated financial impacts related to approving the vacation request.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Hold a Public Hearing; and Council to approve Option 2.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Joshua Goossen&nbsp;(Applicant)</p>

<p>1803 Carlson Drive</p>

<p>Klamath Falls, OR 97601</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Marc Cross (Agent)</p>

<p>Rhine Cross Group</p>

<p>112&nbsp;N&nbsp;5th Street</p>

<p>Klamath Falls, OR 97601</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>1. Relevant Review Criteria,&nbsp;Findings, and Conditions</p>

<p>2. Planning Commission Minutes from April 9, 2018</p>

<p>3. Vacation Area Visual</p>

<p>4. Email Request dated May 3, 2018 from Pacific Power</p>

<p>5. Proposed Ordinance with Exhibits</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">May 07, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.1 </span>WASTE MANAGEMENT RATE INCREASE REQUEST</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: NATHAN CHERPESKI - CITY MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should Council approve the requested rate increase from Waste Management?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>In Oregon, communities our size are required to have a Recycling Program.&nbsp; We utilize Waste Management to operate our Program. City staff work closely with the local Waste Management&nbsp;staff on many issues&nbsp;within the community.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In July 2017, China announced the National Sword Policy which limits the import of contaminated recyclable commodities and increases inspections of recyclable commodities.&nbsp;Because they represent a significant part of the market, costs to process recycling have risen.&nbsp;Waste Management is requesting an increase of $1.22 per residential customer and 3.26% per commercial customer to cover these new costs. The County recently approved a similar rate increase.&nbsp;Waste Management&nbsp;has&nbsp;asked that Council consider approving the requested rate increase, making it effective retroactively to May 1, 2018. Per&nbsp;the City's&nbsp;Franchise Agreement, Council has to consent to such a rate increase (see agreement section below).</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><em>d) In considering proposed rate revisions the City shall balance the interests of the Grantee&nbsp;and the consumer in establishing fair and reasonable rates. In carrying out its duty to&nbsp;protect customers of Grantee and the public&nbsp; &nbsp;generally,&nbsp;the City has broad discretion in&nbsp;setting rates, so long as rates provide revenue for all prudently incurred operating&nbsp;expenses and capital costs of the Grantee and provide the Grantee with a fair and&nbsp;reasonable margin.</em></p>

<p style="margin-left: 80px;">&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the rate increase as requested by Waste Management and make effective May 1, 2018.</li>
	<li>Make findings and approve of a different rate.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>This action would increase revenues for Waste Management, allowing them to&nbsp;offset the increased costs of the Recycling Program.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council approve&nbsp;Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Ben Hirengen - Waste Management</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Waste Management's Rate Increase Request</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">May 07, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.2 </span>ORDINANCE TO ESTABLISH A FRANCHISE FEE FOR CITY-OWNED UTILITIES</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: NATHAN CHERPESKI - CITY MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the Council establish a franchise fee for city-owned public utilities and dedicate the funds&nbsp;to streets capital improvements?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The City’s streets have long suffered from a lack of significant dedicated funding for capital work. While we receive a portion of the gas tax, it covers operational needs and is not dedicated to capital improvements.&nbsp;The condition of City streets has continued to deteriorate each year as deferred maintenance accrues.&nbsp;While we are actively working on alternatives to traditional paving, in hopes to spread our dollars further, without a dedicated funding stream for capital replacement our streets will continue to deteriorate.&nbsp;The rate of deterioration accelerates as a street fails. <span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">Recently the City has experimented with </span>Microsurfacing<span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"> as a solution for some residential streets.&nbsp; While this appears to be working well, dedicating additional resources to both maintenance and rehabilitation is a necessary action.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>This past year, the City hired Capital Asset and Pavement Services Inc to analyze the current condition of our street system and make recommendations for financing needs.&nbsp;The study is grim.&nbsp;It calls for $41 million over 5 years to raise the pavement condition index to 83 from 67.&nbsp;After analyzing their recommendations, it is impossible for the City to generate that level of resources.&nbsp; We need to determine a pathway forward to maintain our existing infrastructure now and into the future.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The study shows that while we have done good job with our arterial streets and a decent job with collectors, our residential streets are failing quickly and many will soon reach a point where maintenance efforts will not be effective and they will require full reconstruction at significantly higher costs.&nbsp;For FYE 2011 to FYE 2015, we averaged about $755,000 on streets pavement and concrete work.&nbsp;The last two years we are closer to $850,000.&nbsp;The average over that entire time is about $785,000.&nbsp;While the models in the study give various numbers scenarios, I propose we attempt to be somewhere between $1.1 million and $2.1 million.&nbsp;If we can add an additional $700,000 to $850,000 per year to streets we can move closer to $1.55 to $1.65 million per year.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Council authorized staff to explore the potential of assessing a franchise fee on City owned utilities.&nbsp;The proposed ordinance would dedicate a portion of the fees for services from Water and Wastewater as a franchise fee dedicated to capital street work.&nbsp;This would allow the city to place additional funding towards street work in the future.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the proposed ordinance as presented establishing a franchise fee for water and wastewater.</li>
	<li>Decline to act at this time and give staff further direction.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>At this time there wouldn't be a direct impact to the City utility fees.&nbsp;It is anticipated that the current fees could absorb the franchise fee in the near term.&nbsp;These funds would be dedicated to capital street improvements.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: N/A</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Road Chart</p>

<p>- Proposed Ordinance</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">May 07, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">9. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">9.1 </span>CONSIDERATION OF A REVISED SCOPE OF WORK FOR THE HDR CONTRACT TO ESTABLISH A QUIET ZONE AT PORTLAND STREET AND THE CRATER LAKE PARKWAY</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action (Consent)</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: SCOTT SOUDERS - CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City accept a revised scope of work from&nbsp;HDR Engineering in the amount of $28,558 to investigate the feasibility of establishing a quiet zone at the Portland Street Rail Crossing?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>: The discussion of a quiet zone at the Portland Street Crossing has been around for some time. Discussions around this topic in 2009 led to the possible formation of a Local Improvement District to install a wayside horn but the majority of the residents surveyed opposed the installation or cost.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Fast forward a few years and we have some new residents in the area that would like the City to help establish a quiet zone or at least some relief from the train horn. Also, the regulations governing quiet zones were reconfigured in 2013 making the process easier to navigate.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>On October 2, 2017 the City Manager brought this issue before Council seeking direction on whether to explore options for establishing a quiet zone by meeting with the State and railroads or to decline acting at this time. Council voted unanimously to have staff explore options with the state and railroads.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>On November 7, 2017 staff met with representatives from the Oregon Department of Transportation (ODOT), Federal Rail Administration(FRA), and the Union Pacific Rail Road (UPRR). Initially, staff was interested in finding out more about a temporary quiet zone that would operate between the hours of 10 pm and 7 am. The City learned that the road would need to be closed during the night time with barricades and reopened each day. In addition, the same equipment would be required for a temporary quiet zone that is required for a full time quiet zone. Although the conditions are not&nbsp;perfect due to the close proximity of the rail to the Crater Lake Parkway, the team discussed three options that would satisfy the FRA requirements for a quiet zone. The options are: a four-quadrant gate system, a raised median, and changing this section of Portland Street to one way. Further discussions with the team were encouraging.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><em>*This item was brought before Council on April 2nd and staff was directed to renegotiate the contract with HDR and eliminate the study of two of the options. Those options were:&nbsp;changing Portland Street to a one-way; and installing a four-quadrant gate system. The only option being reviewed with this proposal is that of a raised median. The cost of the contract did go down, but not substantially.</em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Authorize staff to enter into a contract in the not-to-ecxeed amount of $28,558 with HDR Engineering to perform a quiet zone analysis.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Deny staff to enter into the contract with HDR Engineering.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Cost for the contract work is $28,558. However, staff would need direction from Council on where to obtain funding for this work as it was not budgeted.</p>
	</li>
	<li>There would be no fiscal impact for not entering into a contract with HDR. Staff would consider the project closed if no contract is approved.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF</u><u>’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>HDR Engineering</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>-Draft Contract with HDR with revised Scope of Work</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">May 07, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">9. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">9.2 </span>PURCHASE OF A NEW 2017 CATERPILLAR MODEL: 249D COMPACT TRACK LOADER SKID STEER MACHINE WITH MULTIPLE ATTACHMENT CAPABILITIES</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: TERRY SELLARS - PARK SUPERVISOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City Parks Division purchase a New 2017 Caterpillar Model 249D Compact Track Loader Skid Steer in the amount of $50,808 from Peterson Cat under the NJPA pricing?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The Parks Division would like Council approval to purchase a New 2017 Caterpillar Model 249D Compact Track Loader Skid Steer from Peterson Cat under the National Joint Purchasing Alliance (NJPA) pricing program.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The New 2017 Caterpillar Model 249D Compact Track Loader Skid Steer is a multi-use machine. There are various attachments that could be purchased or even rented to allow this piece of equipment to be used for many different projects not only in the Parks Division but throughout the City. The Parks Division currently owns a stump planer attachment that is compatible with this machine and we have used the stump planer for downtown tree replacement and other stump removals as needed within the Parks and City rights-of-way. We currently rent a machine to be able to utilize this attachment. This equipment becomes essential to the Parks Division as we continue to do more projects in-house like the Kit Carson Drive Tucker Walking Trail System.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve the purchase a New 2017 Caterpillar Model 249D Compact Track Loader Skid Steer from Peterson Cat through the NJPA.</li>
	<li>Deny the purchase.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Purchase of the skid-steer loader would impact Parks' Capital Equipment Budget in the amount of $50,808. This piece of equipment was previously identified within the CIP as a FY 2019/20 purchase. However, due to increased demand for the equipment, Parks staff have re-prioritized the purchase of a large area mower to a later date in order to accommodate the skid-steer loader this fiscal year.</li>
	<li>Denying the purchase would require the Parks Division to continue to rent the equipment necessary and would impact the Facilities Maintenance Budget.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Bill Dion Representative from Watson</p>

<p>Peterson CAT</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Quote from Peterson CAT</p>

<div class="rightcol">May 07, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">9. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">9.3 </span>AIRPORT GRANT APPLICATION 3-41-0030-038 FOR FAA AIRPORT IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp;JOHN BARSALOU - AIRPORT DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City submit a grant application to the FAA and accept funds, if offered, in the amount of $620,000 for updating the Airport's Master Plan?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>An airport's master plan represents a blueprint for long-term development and is used by the FAA to identify and program funding for future&nbsp;airport capital projects.&nbsp;&nbsp;The FAA recommends an airport's master plan be updated every five to ten years.&nbsp; The Crater Lake - Klamath Regional Airport's master plan was last updated in 2005, and the FAA has requested it be updated.&nbsp; <span style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">The </span><span style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">existing </span><span style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">Master Plan&nbsp;is&nbsp;now outdated per FAA design standards </span><span style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">and current </span><span style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">activity trends, and </span><span style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">it does not contain </span><span style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">an FAA</span><span style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">-required</span><span style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"> Airports-GIS (AGIS) Survey </span><span style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px rgb(51, 51, 51); border-image: none; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; white-space: normal; box-sizing: border-box; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;">or</span><span style="font: 400 11px/normal Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; text-align: left; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"> base mapping.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In accordance with FAA Advisory Circular 150/5070-6B&nbsp;Airport Master Plans, goals of a master plan are to:&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Document the issues that the proposed development will address.</li>
	<li>Justify the proposed development through the technical, economic, and environmental investigation of concepts and alternatives.</li>
	<li>Provide an effective graphic presentation of the development of the airport and anticipated land uses in the vicinity of the airport.</li>
	<li>Establish a realistic schedule for the implementation of the development proposed in the plan, particularly the short-term capital improvement program.</li>
	<li>Propose an achievable financial plan to support the implementation schedule.</li>
	<li>Provide sufficient project definition and detail for subsequent environmental evaluations that may be required before the project is approved.</li>
	<li>Present a plan that adequately addresses the issues and satisfies local, state, and Federal regulations.</li>
	<li>Document policies and future aeronautical demand to support municipal or local deliberations on spending, debt, land use controls, and other policies necessary to preserve the integrity of the airport and its surroundings.</li>
	<li>Set the stage and establish the framework for a continuing planning process.&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>The FAA has funding in the amount of $620,000 programed in 2018 for updating the Crater Lake - Klamath Regional Airport's Master Plan under the Airport Improvement Program (AIP).&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Authorize staff to submit a grant application to the FAA in the amount of $620,000 for an Airport Master Plan update.</li>
	<li>Reject submittal of a grant application and abandon plans to update the Airport Master Plan.</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>In addition to the $620,000 in funds available from the FAA, the Airport was successful in obtaining a State of Oregon Department of Aviation Critical Oregon Airport Relief (COAR) Grant in the amount of $44,000 for the Master Plan update project.&nbsp;These two grants, in addition to $19,986 in Airport budgeted funds, will fully fund the total project cost of $683,956.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council approval of Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>FAA Grant Application 3-41-0030-038</li>
</ul>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">May 07, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">9. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">9.4 </span>CONTRACT WITH MEAD &amp; HUNT, INC. FOR AIRPORT MASTER PLAN UPDATE IN THE AMOUNT OF $683,956</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOHN BARSALOU - AIRPORT DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City execute a contract with Mead &amp; Hunt, Inc. to update the Airport's Master Plan, including an Airport-GIS survey and other FAA-required items, in the amount of $683,956?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>An airport master plan represents a blueprint for long-term development and is used by the FAA to identify and program funding for future&nbsp;airport capital projects.&nbsp;The FAA recommends an airport master plan be updated every five to ten years.&nbsp; The Crater Lake-Klamath Regional Airport's master plan last updated in 2005 and the FAA has<span style="text-align: left; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-transform: none; text-indent: 0px; letter-spacing: normal; font-family: Verdana,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 11px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; word-spacing: 0px; float: none; display: inline !important; white-space: normal; orphans: 2; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px;"> requested it be updated</span>. The existing Master Plan&nbsp;is&nbsp;now outdated per FAA design standards and current activity trends, and it does not contain an FAA-required Airports-GIS (AGIS) Survey or base mapping.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In September of 2017 the Airport advertised nationally a Request for Qualifications (RFQ) for firms interested in assisting the Airport in updating its master plan.&nbsp;Only one firm, Mead &amp; Hunt, submitted a&nbsp;proposal by the deadline of October 26, 2017.&nbsp;With approval from the FAA, the Airport proceeded with the next step in the process which was to develop a Scope of Work (SOW)&nbsp;with Mead &amp; Hunt for the project.&nbsp;The SOW conforms to FAA Advisory Circular 150/5070-6B Airport Master Plans and will include: stakeholder coordination and outreach (including coordination with the Joint Land Use Study - JLUS and the Guard's Installation Development Plan); inventory and environmental overview; aviation activity forecasts; facility requirements; improvement alternatives; capital improvement plan and financial feasibility; and airport layout plan drawings.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Scope of Work was approved by the FAA on March 20, 2018 and an Independent Fee Estimate (IFE) was conducted by Century West Engineering.&nbsp;An IFE is a required&nbsp;FAA process&nbsp;to independently determine the reasonableness of a proposed fee.&nbsp;An independent firm, in this situation Century West Engineering,&nbsp;formulates a fee for a proposed SOW which is then compared to the fee&nbsp;submitted by the&nbsp;firm that will be contracted to&nbsp;do the work.&nbsp;The fee calculated by Century West Engineering had a less than 1% difference compared with the fee proposed by Mead &amp; Hunt, well within the 10% difference allowed by the FAA.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve a contract with Mead &amp; Hunt, Inc. to update the Airport's Master Plan, including an Airport-GIS Survey and base mapping, in the amount of $683,956.</li>
	<li>Reject the proposed contract with Mead &amp; Hunt, Inc., direct staff to seek a modification&nbsp;to the Scope of Work from the FAA and renegotiate a contract with Mead &amp; Hunt.</li>
	<li>Reject a contract with Mead &amp; Hunt, Inc. and request a postponement of the master plan update from the FAA.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>The FAA is providing an Airport Improvement Program Grant in the amount of $620,000 which will fund just over 90% of the contract with Mead &amp; Hunt.&nbsp;The remaining $63,986 will come from a State of Oregon Department of Aviation Critical Oregon Airport Relief grant ($44,000) and budgeted Airport funds ($19,986).</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Mead &amp; Hunt, Inc.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Proposed Contract</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">May 07, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">9. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">9.5 </span>RESOLUTION DESIGNATING GREAT BASIN INSURANCE AS THE INSURANCE AGENT OF RECORD FOR THE CITY OF KLAMATH FALLS AND AUTHORIZING AN AGREEMENT WITH GREAT BASIN INSURANCE</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: BROOKE MARSHALL - SUPPORT SERVICES DIRECTOR</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City select Great Basin Insurance as the City's Agent of Record?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The City utilizes the services of an Insurance Agent of Record due to the City's wide variety of unique insurance needs. The purpose of the Agent of Record is to serve as an outside risk consultant and provide the City support for its multiple lines of coverage including airport liability, general liability, property, casualty, medical/dental/vision, and workers compensation.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The City's Agent of Record contract&nbsp;expired on April 6, 2018. Staff issued a Request for Quotes (RFQ) that was published in the Herald and News on April 5, 2018, and mailed to&nbsp;seven insurance agencies. Two agencies responded - Great Basin Insurance and Monte Johnson Insurance.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Selection was based upon the following: compliance with the minimum criteria set forth in the RFQ; evaluation of the applicant’s responses to the required information; which company is most likely to perform the most cost-effective services; and which firm will best serve the public's interest.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The City selection committee unanimously determined based on the RFQ criteria and proposal information submitted to the City by both agencies that Great Basin Insurance would best provide the services as requested. The Contract with Great Basin&nbsp;Insurance as the City's Insurance Agent of Record&nbsp;will be&nbsp;set up for a three-year period, with an option to renew for an additional two years at the discretion of the City.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve selecting Great Basin Insurance as the City's Insurance Agent of Record and allow staff to execute the necessary&nbsp;contract and approve the proposed resolution.</li>
	<li>Deny selecting Great Basin Insurance and re-bid, or give staff further direction.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>The City proposes a flat rate for the City's liability and property insurance carrier in the amount of $23,500 per year for the term of the contract, which is the same rate paid by the City since 2015. For the remaining lines of insurance, the Agent of Record is paid by the selected insurance companies who determine the Agent of Record’s commission which is automatically incorporated into the City's insurance premiums.</li>
	<li>Unknown</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council approve Option 1.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>- Great Basin Insurance</p>

<p>- Monte Johnson Insurance</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Letter and RFQ</p>

<p>- Great Basin Proposal</p>

<p>- Monte Johnson Proposal</p>

<p>- Proposed Contract&nbsp;</p>

<p>- Proposed Resolution</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Apr 16, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>ENTERPRISE ZONE REDESIGNATION</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: CITY MANAGER - NATHAN CHERPESKI and Betty Riley, SCOEDD Executive Director</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the Council authorize SCOEDD to apply for redesignation of the existing enterprise zone with some modifications?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>An enterprise zone is a key economic development tool for Oregon.&nbsp;An enterprise zone designation allows local economic development efforts to offer a similar incentive&nbsp;enjoyed by many&nbsp;other Oregon communities.&nbsp; Without this zone, we would be severely hampered in efforts to attract new businesses or assist existing businesses to expand.&nbsp;In the last three years, this zone has assisted in helping existing businesses to create more than 35 new jobs.&nbsp;While not yet a primary item for a siting decision, it does keep the community at the table when speaking to large companies looking to expand.&nbsp;The zone allows for a 3 year abatement of property tax by right for those that qualify.&nbsp;Additionally, the local sponsor may allow longer abatement if State set criteria are met.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>According to the State website the following are necessary to qualify for the enterprise zone</u>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Eligible Businesses</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Eligible businesses include manufacturers, processors, shippers and a variety of operations that serve other organizations, as well as call centers and headquarter-type facilities. Hotel/resort businesses also are eligible in some of the enterprise zones. Otherwise, retail, construction, financial and certain other defined activities are ineligible.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Qualified Property</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>A new building/structure, structural modifications or additions, or newly installed machinery and equipment qualify for exemption, but not land, previously used property value and miscellaneous personal property.</p>

<h3><span style="font-size: 11px;">Criteria for Qualifying Projects</span></h3>

<p>For the basic, three-year enterprise zone exemption period, the business needs to:</p>

<ul>
	<li>increase full-time, permanent employment of the firm inside the enterprise zone by the greater of one new job or 10% (or less with special-case local sponsor waivers);</li>
	<li>generally have no concurrent job losses outside the zone boundary inside Oregon;</li>
	<li>maintain minimum employment level during the exemption period;</li>
	<li>enter into a first-source agreement with local job training providers; and</li>
	<li>satisfy any additional local condition that has been established (only) in an urban zone.</li>
</ul>

<h3><span style="font-size: 11px;">Criteria for extended tax abatement (for a total of four or five exemption years)</span></h3>

<p>These include the above criteria for the three-year period (which need to be maintained during the extra years), in addition to:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Special local approval (before authorization application is approved) by written agreement entered into with the local zone sponsor (city, port and county, or tribe), in which the sponsor may reasonably request additional requirements that the business must also satisfy, and</li>
	<li>Except in the urban zones of the Salem and Portland areas, the average of new employees'—
	<ul>
		<li>compensation (including benefits), during all years of the abatement, needs to be at or above 130% or 150% of the county average wage as set at the time of authorization; and</li>
		<li>wages must be equal to or greater than the current county average wage in that fourth/fifth year.</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
</ul>

<p><a href="http://www.oregon4biz.com/Oregon-Business/Tax-Incentives/Enterprise-Zones/Eligibility/">http://www.oregon4biz.com/Oregon-Business/Tax-Incentives/Enterprise-Zones/Eligibility/</a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>1. Approve the Resolution as presented.</p>

<p>2. Make changes to the Resolution and adopted as amended.</p>

<p>3.&nbsp;Decline to act at this time.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>If a company receives an abatement under this program, the City will not receive any property taxes from the property during the length of the abatement.&nbsp; However, we will benefit from the increased employment in the community.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;Council to approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Betty Riley, SCOEDD Director</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>Enterprise Zone Map</p>

<p>Enterprise Zone Property Legal Descriptions</p>

<p>Proposed Resolution</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Apr 16, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.2 </span>ROSS RAGLAND THEATER SPECIAL EVENT AGREEMENT</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW934Y6FE44C"><div class="name">Goal #2 - Customer Service</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: JOE WALL - PLANNING MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City execute a new 5 year agreement with the Ross Ragland Theater for their 2 annual events?&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The Ross Ragland Theater’s 5 year Agreement allowing temporary use of an Annual Liquor License, Special Events Authorization and a Waiver of City Code Sections 5.438 and 7.620 in conjunction with the Taste of Klamath event and Ross Ragland Season Launch Street Party will expire in May, 2018. The Ross Ragland Theater is requesting a new 5 year Agreement for temporary use of their Annual Liquor License to allow beer and wine sales at two upcoming functions as well as a Special Events Authorization for public gatherings within the City Right-of-Way.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The events will be held in the Ragland Cultural Center lobby, courtyard area and in a large tent on North 7th Street directly in front of the Theater. North 7th Street will be closed for event setup and for the duration of the events. The applicant is aware of the application process through the City Development Services Division for street closure and will begin that application process in a timely manner.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Alcohol is proposed to be served and/or consumed within the City Right-of-Way (street, sidewalk, or parking lot) therefore, the Ross Ragland Theater must request and be granted by City Council a Waiver of City Code Sections 5.438 permitting public drinking and Section 7.620 to allow intoxicating liquor at the events. The events also require street closure so the Ross Ragland Theater must apply for an Obstruction of Public Right-of-Way Permit from the City Development Services Division. Conditions related to blocking the street will be addressed in the permit, and not through the Wavier or Special Event Request.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In approving such consumption of beer and/or wine, the Council may require the serving and consumption of the alcohol occur in an area segregated from the general public in attendance and any or all of the following:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>The permittee shall provide appropriate liability insurance coverage, which includes or names the City as an additional insured;</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>The permittee shall obtain appropriate OLCC permits for the event;</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>The permittee shall insure appropriate security and identification checks are in place;</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>The permittee shall obtain an Obstruction of Public-Right-of-Way permit from City Development Services Division; and</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Such other conditions as Development Services Staff and Council&nbsp;deem desirable.</p>

	<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>The Police Department&nbsp;reviewed&nbsp;the request and has no comments.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>For these reasons, staff recommends Council approve the proposed 5 year Agreement with conditions as presented.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Council to&nbsp;hold a Public Hearing, take testimony and make a recommendation to the OLCC for the Temporary Sales requests to allow the consumption of beer and wine in conjunction with the Taste of Klamath fundraising event and for the Season Launch Party to be held at the Ross Ragland Theater; approve the proposed 5 year Agreement with the Ross Ragland Theater in conjunction with the Taste of Klamath Event and Ross Ragland Season Launch Street Party, allowing the Ross Ragland Theater to hold two special events to take place within the North 7th Street Right-of-Way,&nbsp;and waiving the City Code Sections 5.438 and 7.620 to allow public drinking within the North 7th Street Right-of-Way in conjunction with the Ross Ragland Theater events with the following conditions: a) permittee shall provide appropriate liability insurance coverage, which includes or names the City as an additional insured; b)&nbsp;permittee shall obtain appropriate OLCC permits for the event; c)&nbsp;permittee shall insure appropriate security and identification checks are in place; and d)&nbsp;permittee shall obtain an Obstruction of Public Right-of-Way Permit from City Development Services Division.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Deny the Request and give staff further direction.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>There is no financial impact related to making a recommendation to OLCC, authorizing the Special Events, or waiving City Code sections 5.438 or 7.620.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:</p>

<p>Staff recommends approving Council Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Ross Ragland Theater/Ragland Cultural Center</p>

<p>218 N 7th Street</p>

<p>Klamath Falls, OR 97601</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>OLCC</p>

<p>Kent Oldham</p>

<p>107 S 7th Street</p>

<p>Klamath Falls, OR 97601</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Apr 02, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">5. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">5.1 </span>WATER RESALE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE CITY OF KLAMATH FALLS AND F.B. OWEN, INC. FOR HOMEDALE TERRACE MOBILE HOME PARK, LLC</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp; SCOTT SOUDERS&nbsp;- CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:</p>

<p>Should the City approve a Water Resale Agreement with F.B. Owen, Inc. for the Homedale Terrace Mobile Home Park?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="tab-stops: -1.0in;">The Homedale Terrace Mobile Home Park&nbsp;is located at 1255 Homedale Road and has been served by City water service since May of 2000.&nbsp;Currently, the&nbsp;development is served by a single 3" City water meter near the&nbsp;private road entrance from Homedale&nbsp;Road.&nbsp; The applicant indicates there will be no change in service to the property.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="tab-stops: -1.0in;">In order for the park owner to equitably recapture the costs associated with supplying water to each of the home&nbsp;spaces within the park, the owner wishes to separately meter each home and bill the occupants based on their actual usage. Per state statute, the terms of water resale shall be governed and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Oregon. Therefore, a public hearing must be held with an approval granted by City Council in order for the owner to separately bill their occupants based on water consumption.</span></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;"><span style="tab-stops: -1.0in;">Staff has drafted the attached Water Resale Agreement for Council consideration.</span></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Approve the Water Resale Agreement as written.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Approve the Water Resale Agreement based on modifications proposed by Council.</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Deny the Water Resale Agreement</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">There is no financial impact to the City. The existing 3” water meter will remain in place and the owner will continue to be billed on a monthly basis.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:&nbsp;<span style="line-height: normal;">Council approve Option 1.</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Fred Owen</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">F.B Owen, Inc.</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">3400 Crater Lake Avenue</span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><span style="line-height: normal;">Medford, OR 97504</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Water Resale Agreement</li>
	<li>Exhibit A: Homedale Terrace Replat</li>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="AX537G045FBC">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Apr 02, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.2 </span>PURCHASE OF CRACK SEALANT FROM PAVEMENT MANAGEMENT SUPPLY, INC. IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $51,210</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action (Consent)</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: CHUCK COX - STREETS MANAGER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:&nbsp;Should Council allow staff to purchase crack sealant from Pavement Management Supply, Inc.?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p><w:sdt docpart="A3CD5D928F9E49AAA9EE6D7D36BDC8AE" id="-2038533466" sdttag="Summary/Background" title="Summary/Background">The Street Division of the Public Works Department utilizes crack sealant in the maintenance and repair of city streets and rights-of-way. The Streets Division has several roadways in need of crack sealing as determined through our Pavement Management System (PMS) and areas that will be prepared for chip seals and microsurfacing. Two different types of crack sealant are used, one for normal size cracks and the other for lane ruts and larger cracks. Both types of sealants, Crafco Roadsaver 221 and Crafco Mastic One Leveling Sealant are designed for our climate with high and low temperature range to ensure a lasting seal of roadway cracks. This purchase amounts to 45,000 pounds of Crafco Roadsaver 221 and 44,100 pounds of Crafco Mastic Sealant which is projected to supply maintenance crews and contractors through this maintenance season.</w:sdt> Pavement Maintenance Supply, Inc. is the only supplier of this crack seal product.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Authorize staff to purchase 45,000 pounds of Crafco Roadsaver 221 and 44,100 pounds of Crafco Mastic One Leveling Sealant from Pavement Maintenance Supply, Inc., for a total purchase price not to exceed $51,210.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Deny staff to purchase crack seal and direct staff to utilize a different crack seal product.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Council deny purchase of crack sealant and have staff investigate other options.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Funds for this project in the amount of $51,210 are available in the&nbsp;Streets' materials and services budget.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>: N/A</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Quotes</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Apr 02, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.3 </span>ESTABLISH A QUIET ZONE AT PORTLAND STREET AND THE CRATER LAKE PARKWAY</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action (Consent)</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: SCOTT SOUDERS - CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City enter into a contract with HDR Engineering to investigate the feasibility of establishing a quiet zone at the Portland Street Rail Crossing?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>The discussion of a quiet zone at the Portland Street Crossing has been around for some time. Discussions around this topic in 2009 led to the possible formation of a Local Improvement District to install a wayside horn but the majority of the residents surveyed opposed the installation or cost.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Fast forward a few years, and we have some new residents in the area that would like the City to help establish a quiet zone or at least some relief from the train horn noise. Also, the regulations governing quiet zones were reconfigured in 2013 making the process easier to navigate.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>On October 2, 2017 the City Manager brought this issue before Council seeking direction on whether to explore options for establishing a quiet zone by meeting with the state and railroads, or to decline acting at this time. Council voted unanimously to have staff explore options with the state and railroads.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>On November 7, 2017 staff met with representatives from the Oregon Department of Transportation (ODOT), Federal Rail Administration (FRA), and the Union Pacific Railroad (UPRR). Initially, staff was interested in finding out more about a temporary quiet zone that would operate between the hours of 10 pm and 7 am, but he City learned that the road would need to be closed during the night time with barricades and reopened each day. In addition, the same equipment would be required for a temporary quiet zone that is required for a full-time quiet zone. Although the conditions are not&nbsp;perfect due to the close proximity of the rail to the Crater Lake Parkway, the team discussed three options that would satisfy the FRA requirements for a quiet zone. The options are: a four-quadrant gate system, a raised median, and changing this section of Portland Street to one-way. Further discussions with the team were encouraging.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>While there are several options that may satisfy the requirements for a quiet zone, the City needs to further analyze each option and, ultimately, submit the quiet zone request and all preliminary engineering drawings, calculations and forms to the appropriate parties. To help facilitate this work, staff reached out to HDR Engineering who has personnel that specialize in this type of work. Their scope of work is attached. The City has already entered into a contract with Union Pacific, a requirement for their participation, for $10,000.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Authorize staff to enter into a contract with HDR Engineering to perform a quiet zone analysis, contingent upon approval of a future supplemental budget.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Deny staff to enter into the contract with HDR Engineering.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>The cost for the contract work is $31,750. Staff recommends that the funding for this come from the Cogen Effluent funds in a future supplemental budget.&nbsp;</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>There would be no fiscal impact for not entering into a contract with HDR. Staff would consider the project closed if no contract is approved.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF</u><u>’S RECOMMENDATION</u>: Council approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>HDR Engineering</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>-Draft Contract with HDR Proposal</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Apr 02, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.4 </span>CONSTRUCTION SERVICES CONTRACT WITH VSS INTERNATIONAL, INC. FOR THE FY 2017/2018 MICROSURFACING &amp; OREGON AVENUE BIKE LANE PROJECT IN AN AMOUNT NOT-TO-EXCEED $475,626.20</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<div class="leftcol">Goals</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="goals-viewer">
<a class="goal" unique="AW93576FF269"><div class="name">Goal #3 - Economic Viability/Community Livability</div></a>
</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>:&nbsp; SCOTT SOUDERS - CITY ENGINEER</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>:</p>

<p>Should the City execute a construction services contract with VSS International, Inc. in the not-to-exceed amount of $475,626.20 or construction of the 2017/18 Microsurfacing and Oregon Avenue Bike Lane Project?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>On February 20, 2018, Council approved execution of a contract with Blackline, Inc. (Blackline) for the 2017/18 Microsurfacing and Oregon Avenue Bike Lane Project – see attached agenda report for reference. Contracts were then executed with Blackline and a subsequent pre-construction meeting was held on Wednesday, March 14th.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>During the pre-construction meeting, it was discovered that Blackline would be unable to perform the work in conformance with the specifications. More specifically, there was misunderstanding with Blackline regarding the provision requiring streets to be opened to traffic within one hour after material application. Unfortunately, Blackline does not possess the equipment required to place a product within these time constraints. Therefore, Blackline withdrew themselves as the contractor per the attached “Motion to Terminate Contract” letter dated March 16, 2018. City staff has accepted this request to terminate.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Following notification of Blackline’s intent to issue the above referenced letter, staff contacted the second-place bidder, VSS International, Inc. (VSS), to verify interest and availability to perform the work as bid. VSS responded that they are available and able to meet the original timelines and specifications for the project. A subsequent Notice of Intent to Award to VSS was issued on March 19th to all bidders.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The bid price for VSS, including selected bid alternates 2 and 3, is $7,533 above that of Blackline. Therefore, upon Council approval, the new contract will be in the not-to-exceed amount of $475,626.20.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve a Contract with VSS International, Inc. in an amount not-to-exceed $475,626.20 and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $47,563.</li>
	<li>Reject a Contract with VSS International, Inc. and rebid the project.</li>
	<li>Reject a Contract with VSS International, Inc. and postpone the project.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>Design Phase and Bid Phase hard cost expenditures are anticipated to total approximately $37,000. Staff anticipates an additional hard cost allowance of $14,000 for construction inspection and materials testing during construction. The total anticipated hard cost project expenditure equals $574,691, including a 10% construction contingency allowance if necessary. Refer to the attached Budget Analysis Form for further detail. It should be noted that the charges for internal staff time are not included in the overall hard cost budget as these services are provided through the General Fund.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Funds for this project are available through both the City’s FY 2017/18 Adopted Budget in the Street Division Capital Outlay Fund plus a Sky Lakes Medical Center Foundation donation. A $350,000 allowance from the Streets Capital fund was allocated for the 2017/18 Microsurfacing Project. An additional $16,000 is available from the crack seal program. Design and construction costs for the Oregon Avenue Bike Lane Project are covered through a $209,000 donation received from the Sky Lakes Medical Center Foundation.</p>

<ol>
	<li>Council Option 1 will utilize funds allocated for this project.</li>
	<li>Council Option 2 will delay the project into next fiscal year and potentially impact the ability to construct during the summer of 2018.</li>
	<li>Council Option 3 will cancel the project for summer of 2018.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:</p>

<p>Staff recommends approving Council Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>All parties who submitted bids for this project as listed in the attached Confirmation of Bid Opening.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<ul>
	<li>February 20th Council Agenda Report – Blackline, Inc.&nbsp;Award</li>
	<li>Blackline, Inc. Motion to Terminate Contract Letter</li>
	<li>Project Location Exhibit</li>
	<li>Budget Analysis Form</li>
	<li>Confirmation of Bid Opening</li>
	<li>Notice of Intent to Award</li>
	<li>Draft Contract</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="AWPPLZ6388DD">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 19, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">5. </span>CONSENT AGENDA</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">5.4 </span>AIRPORT JANITORIAL CONTRACT WITH TROY’S JANITORIAL IN AN AMOUNT NOT-TO-EXCEED $20,000 ANNUALLY</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: Airport Director - John Barsalou</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City enter into a contract with Troy’s Janitorial cleaning of the Airport terminal building?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>In February, the Airport sent Request for Quotes to nine local firms for custodial services for the terminal building and public use areas. Four companies, Mentor Oregon, Sanitech Building Maintenance, Servicemaster, and Troy’s Janitorial, contacted the Airport and completed walk-throughs of the terminal building. The following quotes were received by the submittal deadline:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Troy’s Janitorial $1,500/month; $35/hour Call Out Service Fee</p>

<p>Sanitech Building Maintenance $2,245/month; $25/hour Call Out Service Fee</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Troy’s Janitorial submitted the lowest quote and has provided custodial services at the Airport since approximately July 1985. The current contract with Troy’s Janitorial is for $2,080.00/month, but under the new contract they will no longer be responsible for cleaning the Airport Administration Building, as that will now be handled by Airport staff. In addition, a number of areas in the terminal building, such as the passenger screening area, have had cleaning requirements reduced since without passenger service they don’t require the same level of cleaning.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Airport has been very satisfied with the services provided by Troy's Janitorial Service to date and recommends contracting with them for a two year period effective April 1, 2018 to March 30, 2020, with the possibility of two, two year extensions at the discretion of the Airport.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Approve a contract with Troy’s Janitorial in an amount of $1,500 per month, not to exceed $20,000 per year including additional call out service fees.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reject a contract with Troy’s Janitorial, modify the scope of work and request quotes a second time.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reject a contract with Troy’s Janitorial and request staff explore options to perform the work with Airport/City employees.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>The Airport currently budgets $2,080/month for janitorial services which covers the terminal building and the Airport Administration Office. The new quote of $1,500/month would be an annual cost savings of $580/month or $6,960/year.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>No immediate financial impact to the Airport.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>The Airport believes that it would be difficult to find an option that utilized City/Airport employees without hiring additional personnel at a greater cost than $1,500/month.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:</p>

<p>Staff recommends Council Approval of Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>- Sanitech Building Maintenance</p>

<p>- Troy’s Janitorial Service</p>

<p><br>
<u>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED</u>:</p>

<p>- Informal Quote Solicitation Record</p>

<p>- Proposed Contract with Troy’s Janitorial Service</p>
</div>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>This retail outlet, a grocery store, is set to open in 2018 at the former downtown Safeway/Haggen grocery store location. The Police Department also reviewed the request, and their comments are included below.</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="AWP5AL02547B">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 19, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">9. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">9.1 </span>CONSTRUCTION SERVICES CONTRACT WITH ROCKY MOUNTAIN CONSTRUCTION, LLC FOR THE NORTH ELDORADO AVENUE IMPROVEMENT PROJECT IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $962,000</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p><u>REPORT GIVEN BY</u>: City Engineer - Scott Souders</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL</u>: Should the City execute a construction services contract with Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC in the not-to-exceed amount of $962,000 for construction of the North Eldorado Avenue Improvement Project?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND</u>:</p>

<p>In a continuing effort to extend the life of the City’s roadway wearing surfaces, the City Streets Division has identified North Eldorado Avenue, between Dahlia Street and Van Ness Street, as a good candidate for asphalt grind and inlay treatment. Since North Eldorado carries significant traffic to the hospital and Oregon Tech area, staff has also taken this opportunity to evaluate additional bicycle,&nbsp;pedestrian improvements and traffic calming along the project route. Through this evaluation staff identified traffic calming opportunities, improved bicycle accommodations, and sidewalk connectivity infill.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Barghausen Consulting Engineers was retained by the City to assist in conducting a planning level evaluation and to prepare construction documents for the improvement project. Barghausen and City staff began by consulting with the Blue Zones Project and Spokes Unlimited to identify potential improvement opportunities. This effort led to the preparation of roadway improvement and sidewalk infill design documents. Through the design process, public meetings were held on January 19, 2017 and October 3, 2017 where community members had an opportunity to view exhibits of the proposed improvements and submit comments. Based on these comments, Barghausen prepared the final bid documents and associated estimate of probable construction costs. In an effort to seek funding partnership, City Staff also presented the proposed project to the Board of Klamath County Commissioners. This effort led to a commitment by Klamath County to allocate $400,000 towards the project.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>A formal request for construction bids was publicly advertised in the Herald and News and the Daily Journal of Commerce. A non-mandatory pre-bid meeting was held on February 6, 2018 where bidders had the opportunity to discuss the project with the design team and staff. Bids were received from one company on February 15, 2018. The bidder and their price is summarized below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Engineers Estimate (Published) $850,000 to $950,000</u></p>

<p>Rocky Mountain Construction, Inc. $1,049,400</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>As bid, the project exceeded the budgeted funds available for construction. Staff then worked with the bidder to seek opportunities where scope or approach may be modified in order to bring the project within budget. After review of several options, the team was successful in identifying strategies to award the project while still retaining the originally anticipated scope of work. Examples of identified strategies included; refinement of bid item unit quantities, removal of construction items from the contractors scope and self-perform with City resources, increase budget allocation through financial participation from the Water and Wastewater Divisions for work related to those divisions, and contractor reduction of general mobilization and traffic control pricing.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The results of the Value Engineering effort led to a revised negotiated bid of $962,000.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>COUNCIL OPTION(S)</u>:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Approve a Contract with Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC in an amount not-to-exceed $962,000 and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $96,200.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reject a Contract with Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC, modify the project scope and rebid the project.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reject a Contract with Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC and postpone the project.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p><u>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S)</u>:</p>

<p>The North Eldorado Avenue Improvement Project will bring a notable positive impact to the built environment of Klamath Falls. By linking sidewalk connectivity, creating designated travel ways for bicyclists, and reducing traffic speeds, the quality of life for citizens living within and traveling through the neighboring community will be improved. These multi-modal amenities will enhance the desire to live and work in our community and in-turn will have a positive financial impact on the area through increased home and property values.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Design Phase and Bid Phase soft cost expenditures are anticipated to total approximately $95,485. Staff anticipates an additional soft cost allowance of $7,500 for construction inspection and materials testing during construction. The total probable project expenditure equals $1,162,147, including a 10% construction contingency allowance, if necessary. Refer to the attached Budget Analysis Form for further detail. It should be noted that the charges for internal staff time are not included in the overall budget summary as these services are provided through the General Fund.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The majority of funds for this project are available through the City’s FY 2017/18 Adopted Budget in the Street Division Capital Outlay Fund $615,000, plus participation by Klamath County through a project contribution of $400,000. Divisional Managers have also verified that additional fund allocations of $19,200 from the Water Division and $27,880 from the Wastewater Division are available through their respective FY 2017/18 capital budgets.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Project construction will span into next fiscal year. An additional budget allocation of roughly $100,000 will be necessary from FY 2018/19 in order to complete the project. Those funds will be identified within next year’s CIP and associated fiscal budget request.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
	<li>Council Option 1 will utilize FY 2017/18 funds available for this project, plus anticipated allocation from FY 2018/19.</li>
	<li>Council Option 2 will delay the project into next fiscal year and negatively impact the ability to construct during the summer of 2018.</li>
	<li>Council Option 3 will cancel the project for summer of 2018.</li>
</ol>

<p><u>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION</u>:</p>

<p>Staff recommends approving Council Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>AGENDA SENT TO</u>:</p>

<p>Rocky Mountain Construction, LLC</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p>Project Location Exhibit</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Budget Analysis Form</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Confirmation of Bid Opening</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Notice of Intent to Award</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Sample Contract</p>
	</li>
</ul>
