<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 05, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">8. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">8.1 </span>Liquor License for Full On-Premises Sales for Denny's Restaurant located at 2947 South 6th Street</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p>REPORT GIVEN BY: Management Asst. to the City Manager/Senior Planner - Joe Wall</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL: Should Denny’s be permitted to sell distilled spirits, malt beverages, wine, and cider for consumption at their business?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND:</p>

<p>Evergreen Enterprises, Inc., dba Denny’s #7741, is applying for a New Outlet Liquor License to allow Full On-Premises Sales at their restaurant establishment located at 2947 South 6th Street. This would allow for the sale of distilled spirits, malt beverages, wine, and cider for consumption at the licensed business. This business has been operating at this location for many years.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The business location is zoned General Commercial. The operation of a restaurant is consistent with the zoning. The business is open 24 hours a day.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The business will not restrict entrance to the business by age, so the Adult Business Overlay Zone (CDO 12.490-12.496) does not come into effect.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Notice was sent on January 18, 2018 to adjacent property owners within a 100-foot radius of the business location. No response has been received to date.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Police Department also reviewed the request and their comments are included below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>COUNCIL OPTIONS:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Recommend APPROVAL to the OLCC for full on-premises sales for Denny’s Restaurant.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Recommend DENIAL to OLCC for full on-premises sales for Denny’s Restaurant.</p>

	<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>FINANCIAL IMPACT: There is no financial impact related to making a recommendation to OLCC.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION: Staff recommends approval of Option #1; Council to recommend to OLCC approval of full on-premises sales for Denny’s Restaurant.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>AGENDA SENT TO:</p>

<p>Evergreen Enterprises, Inc. dba Denny's #7741</p>

<p>2947 South 6th Street</p>

<p>Klamath Falls, OR&nbsp; 97603</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>OLCC&nbsp;</p>

<p>Kent Oldham</p>

<p>735 Commercial Street #7000</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="AWDAWH29AC61">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Mar 05, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">9. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">9.1 </span>Construction Services Contract with Bob's Excavating, Inc. for the Mitchell and Orchard Sewer Replacement Project in an amount not-to-exceed $115,160</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p>REPORT GIVEN BY: City Engineer - Scott Souders</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL: Should the City execute a construction services contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. in the not-to-exceed amount of $115,160 for construction of the Mitchell and Orchard Sewer Replacement Project?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND:</p>

<p>The City of Klamath Falls, through the Capital Improvement Program, identified the Mitchell and Orchard Sewer Main Realignment/Replacement in the Wastewater Division’s System Rehabilitation Program. Currently there is approximately 240 lineal feet of 6-inch clay sewer pipe that is located beneath existing yards, fences and a garage structure. The 70+ year old sewer line suffers from broken sections, offset pipe joints, cracked pipe and numerous root intrusions. This project will replace the failing and unmaintainable line with a new 8” sewer main in Orchard Avenue as well as allow for the installation of new manholes and cleanouts. Some work on private lots is required to re-align the existing house sewer laterals and direct them to the new sewer main. Agreements are in-place with the home owners to allow the City to perform the work. Adkins Consulting Engineers was retained by the City to assist in preparation of bid documents, construction plans and associated estimate of probable construction costs.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>A formal request for construction bids was publicly advertised in the Herald and News and the Daily Journal of Commerce. A non-mandatory pre-bid meeting was held on February 6, 2018 where bidders had the opportunity to discuss the project with the design team and staff. A single bid was received on February 15, 2018. The Company and their bid price is listed below.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><u>Engineers Estimate (Published) $ 145,000 to $165,000</u>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Bob’s Excavating, Inc. $ 115,160</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>COUNCIL OPTION(S):</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Approve a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. in an amount not-to-exceed $115,160 and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $23,032.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reject a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc., modify the project scope and rebid the project.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reject a Contract with Bob’s Excavating, Inc. and postpone the project.</p>

	<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>FINANCIAL IMPACT(S):</p>

<p>Design Phase and Bid Phase expenditures are anticipated to total approximately $28,972. Staff anticipates an additional allowance of $8,500 for construction inspection and materials testing during construction. The total anticipated project expenditure equals $175,914, including a 20% construction contingency allowance, if necessary. Refer to the attached Budget Analysis Form for further detail.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Funds for this project are available through both the City’s FY 2016/17 and FY 2017/18 Adopted Budgets in the Wastewater Division Capital Outlay Fund. A $140,000 allowance from the Wastewater Capital fund was allocated for the Mitchell and Orchard Sewer Replacement Project. An additional $36,000 is available from the unused allocation associated with removal and replacement of the KFI Manhole as identified in the FY 2017/18 budget.</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Council Option 1 will utilize funds available for this project.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Council Option 2 may delay the project into next fiscal year and potentially impact the ability to construct during the summer of 2018.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Council Option 3 will cancel the project for summer of 2018.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION:</p>

<p>Staff recommends Council approve Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>AGENDA SENT TO:</p>

<p>All parties who submitted bids for this project as listed in the attached Confirmation of Bid Opening.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED:</p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p>Project Location Exhibit</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Budget Analysis Form</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Confirmation of Bid Opening</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Notice of Intent to Award</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Sample Contract</p>

	<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</li>
</ul>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Feb 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">6. </span>GENERAL PUBLIC HEARING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">6.1 </span>A RESOLUTION ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENTAL BUDGET FOR FY 2017-2018 WITHIN THE GENERAL FUND, DEBT SERVICE FUND, AND WATER FUND</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL: Should Council adopt a Supplemental Budget for FY 2017-2018 for the changes listed below?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND: On June 19, 2017, the City Council adopted the FY 2017-2018 Budget. Supplemental Budgets for FY 2017-2018 were adopted for the General Fund and Economic Development/Property Fund on August 21, 2017; the General Fund on November 6, 2017; and the Airport Fund and Escrow Reserve Fund on December 18, 2017. The following unforeseen items have taken place since adoption:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>General Fund</p>

<p>Police – Materials &amp; Services needs to increase:</p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p>$5,775 for Homeland Security Taskforce Officer Training and Rolling Surveillance training as Homeland Security Taskforce Officers; and</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Intergovernmental revenue will increase $5,775 due to the State and Local Overtime (SLOT) Reimbursement Program through the US Department of Homeland Security.</p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p>Transfers Out – needs to increase:</p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p>$70,000 for an operating inter-fund loan to the Debt Service Fund to cover debt service payments as the County taxed the wrong amount. The County is unable to bill the additional tax this year, but will bill it next year along with the regular amount. Once taxes are received the inter-fund loan will be paid back; and</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reserves will decrease $70,000.</p>

	<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p>Debt Service Fund</p>

<p>Transfers In – needs to increase:</p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p>$70,000 for an operating inter-fund loan from the General Fund to cover debt service payments; and</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Property Taxes need to decrease $70,000 due to the County taxing error.</p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p>Water Fund</p>

<p>Utility Billing – Personnel Services needs to increase:</p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p>$8,000 for straight-time overtime; this item was moved to a different general ledger account in error, and was missed during the budgeting process; and</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reserves will decrease $8,000.</p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p>COUNCIL OPTIONS:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Adopt the Supplemental Budget as presented.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Choose not to adopt the Supplemental Budget and provide staff with further direction.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>FINANCIAL IMPACTS:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Revenue from outside sources will decrease $64,225 and expenditures to outside sources will increase $13,775. Appropriations will increase $83,775 and reserves will decrease $78,000.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION: Adopt the Supplemental Budget as presented.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>RECOMMENDED MOTION(S):</p>

<p>Move to introduce the Resolution by title only</p>

<p>Move to approve the Resolution</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>DOCUMENT(S) ATTACHED:</p>

<p>Proposed Resolution</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Citizen Members of the Budget Committee</p>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="AW8VDQ68FA71">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Feb 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.2 </span>A RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING AN INTER-FUND OPERATING LOAN FROM THE GENERAL FUND TO THE DEBT SERVICE FUND</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL: Should Council approve an inter-fund operating loan between the Debt Service Fund and General Fund to finance the debt service payments on the General Obligation Bond?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND: The State of Oregon discovered that Klamath County had taxed the incorrect amount for the City of Klamath Falls General Obligation Bond with a separate levy. The County is not certain how the mistake occurred. The Fiscal Year 2017 amount of $185,000 was taxed instead of the $255,000 requested for Fiscal Year 2018. The error was discovered too late to re-bill tax payers during this fiscal year, so the tax will not be collected until next fiscal year. The County will bill the $70,000 difference along with the regular levy amount in tax year 2018/2019. Unfortunately, this reduction in property taxes will leave the fund unable to pay all of its debt service payments.</p>

<p>The total requested inter-fund operating loan amount between the Debt Service Fund and General Fund will be $70,000, but could be less depending on the taxes received. If Council approves, the borrowing will occur on May 15, 2018, to insure funds are available for the June 1 debt service. Under Oregon budget law (ORS 294.468), inter-fund operating loans need to be budgeted and repaid in the next fiscal year.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>COUNCIL OPTIONS:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Approve the inter-fund loan as presented</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Choose not to approve the loan, and provide staff with further direction</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>FINANCIAL IMPACTS:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>This transaction reduces available cash of $70,000 in the General Fund, however, it allows the City to remain in compliance with its General Obligation Bond debt service payments. The funds will be repaid in the next fiscal year.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION: Staff recommends that the General Fund loan monies to the Debt Service Fund in order to make the required debt service payments.</p>

<a class="public-file" target="_blank" order="00001" unique="AW8VJV69E24B" href="/or/cokf/Board.nsf/files/AW8VJV69E24B/$file/item%204.pdf">item 4.pdf (98 KB)</a></div>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="AW8VMD6A25FB">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Feb 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.3 </span>METHOD FOR SETTING GEOTHERMAL RATES AND IRA'S REQUEST FOR SPECIAL GEOTHERMAL RATE</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL: Should the City of Klamath Falls change how it sets rates for Geothermal use and also consider IFA’s request?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND: Since about 2002, IFA has been the City’s largest Geothermal User. The City offered an introductory rate of 75% of commercial natural gas rate (schedule 420) capped at no more than $0.80 per therm. Other users pay 80% of the Schedule 420 rate.</p>

<p>In 2012, IFA requested an additional 5 years of the lower rate to help them purchase a backup natural gas heating system. The Agreement expired and they are currently paying our normal rate. Recently, IFA has made a new request for Council to consider. They are requesting an additional 5-years of the lower rate to off-set the cost of adding alternative heat. This is very similar to the request they made in 2012.</p>

<p>Staff believes we should reject this request for two primary reasons. Since incentives are intended to be time limited and to help a company starting out, staff doesn’t feel it is appropriate to extend the past agreement for an additional 5 years which is 10 years past the original offer. Secondly, given current natural gas prices, the discount proposed would provide heat below our cost to produce it. Staff believes we should change the way we set rates for geothermal. Since our costs are not tied to natural gas pricing, staff believes the City should consider setting a rate, not tied to natural gas, that covers our cost but still offers a discount for all users.</p>

<p>Recently, the price for a therm of natural gas (schedule 420) dropped to $0.89882 with a $17 base charge. This decrease, under current policy would dictate a decrease in the Geothermal Rate. However, our costs have not fallen but remain relatively stable.</p>

<p>At 80% the next rate would be $0.71906 per therm. A 75% rate would yield a rate of $0.67412 per therm. These new rates do not reflect the cost for the utility to provide the service. Based on some initial analysis, our cost is closer to $0.72 to $0.735 per therm depending upon how much capital replacement you plan. Since providing the service will cost more than the 80% of natural gas, should we continue to set our rates based on a percent of the cost of natural gas?</p>

<p><img src="data:image/png;base64,"></p>

<p>The chart above shows the revenues and expenses for the utility over the last several years. The large difference in 2015 came when the City paid off two loans. An original loan for approximately $800,000 to replace a mainline and extend another mainline and a loan for $100,000 to extend the line to IFA (we also received a $100,000 grant to offset the cost for this extension). We also no longer charge personnel costs here as part of the budget. The utility is billed for actual staff time (at a fully loaded rate) for operations and maintenance. This reduced the annual cost since they now only pay for actual services. Prices swings for natural gas are shown below.</p>

<p><img src="data:image/png;base64,"></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>If we make a change why would geothermal still be an option? With natural gas, you pay for the potential heat. How much heat you extract from the gas combustion process relates to how efficient your boiler burns. With the geothermal heat, you are only charged for the actual heat you extract through your heat exchanger. Once the water is hot, how efficiently it heats space is essentially the same. Since boilers vary in efficiency from the mid 50% to high 90% range, this value of geothermal will vary by customer. With an upper mid-range boiler at 84% efficient, the true cost of a therm of heat is (price of 1 therm of natural gas divided by the boiler’s efficiency) <img src="data:image/png;base64,"> per therm. Geothermal is more efficient in that regard. The proposed current rate is still more than $0.16 less per therm than natural gas regardless of efficiency.</p>

<p>Improvements to the Utility</p>

<p>Over the last few years we have researched other communities and geothermal utilities and learned quite a bit. Over time, we need to switch the type of pipe and/or the methods we use when installing the pipe for our mainlines and we should place service connections in vaults. This will reduce the corrosion we see in many of our lines. With a base rate of $0.73, the utility covers its basic operations and we project some money for capital. Additionally, we need to add users. Like other utilities, users could be incentivized through one-time grants of assistance to purchase a heat exchanger or a similar program.</p>

<p>Investments are needed to improve reliability. Reliability would be most improved by looping the system. In a looped system when you have a line break, you can isolate the break and back feed users. In a non-looped system, users downstream of the break, lose service. This is an expensive option but may make sense as we redevelop the Spring Street industrial area or look at creating smaller loops. The Geothermal Utility has value to the City, such as the snowmelt system, and the potential to pay for itself. With the right investments and all parties paying for their share, the system can be a valuable part of the City’s infrastructure.</p>

<p>COUNCIL OPTIONS:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Approve extending the contract with IFA for an additional 5 years. They will receive the incentive rate for a total of 20 years if extended. At the current natural gas price, the City would be providing this heat at a loss</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Decline to extend the 75% rate and direct staff to proceed with developing a fixed rate plan for all users. This would entail outreach and notice to our current customers. The current 80% rates do cover our cost but won’t allow as much future capital.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Decline to act at this time. IFA will pay the basic rate paid by all users of 80% of residential natural gas therm cost with no cap. The current 80% rate does cover the City’s cost.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>FINANCIAL IMPACTS:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>The loss incurred by the City will depend upon the total number of therms used. A five-year average shows the loss to be about $600 per average month.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Initial analysis shows that an appropriate rate near the current 80% rate could cover our costs and provide some for capital improvements.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Option 3 would simply charge them the amount all other users pay. The current standard rate covers our cost.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION: Staff Recommends option 2; declining to extend the 75% rate and directing staff to return with a fixed rate for all users.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>RECOMMENDED MOTION:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Move to decline extending the 75% rate and direct staff to return with a fixed rate plan for all users.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>DOCUMENT ATTACHED:</p>

<p>Request from IFA.</p>

<p>Minutes from 2012 hearing on last extension request</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>REPORT SENT TO:</p>

<p>IFA</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Feb 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.4 </span>DESIGN SERVICES CONTRACT WITH RH2 ENGINEERING, INC. FOR THE STEWART LENOX WATER SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS PROJECT PHASE I IN THE NOT-TO-EXCEED AMOUNT OF $73,155</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL: A request for authorization to enter into a design services contract with RH2 Engineering for Phase I of the Stewart Lenox Water System Improvements Project.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND:</p>

<p>The City Water Division has identified the need to improve fire flow capabilities in the Stewart Lenox area south of Highway 66, between Agate Road and Granite Street. The existing infrastructure, consisting of mostly 2” water lines, cannot provide adequate fire protection to the area. When the area was developed, prior to being part of the City, there were no fire hydrants or adequately sized pipes installed as part of the water system infrastructure.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>In the Fall of 2017, the City retained RH2 Engineering, Inc. to perform an Alternatives Analysis that studied water infrastructure improvement opportunities for the area. The Alternatives Analysis has been attached for reference. City staff has determined that Alternative 2 is the appropriate solution. This alternative divides the work into two phases, as follows:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p>Phase I will consist of design and construction of approximately 2,700 lineal feet of new 12-inch water main beginning at the corner of Hwy 66 and Agate Street and ending near the intersection of Highway 66 and Cortez Street.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Phase II will consist of design and construction of approximately 1,000 lineal feet of 12-inch water main and 2,500 lineal feet of 8-inch water main along the adjoining residential streets. These segments will include new fire hydrants and domestic services.</p>

	<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p>The services proposal currently under consideration is for design of Phase I. The City anticipates construction of this phase to commence in July/August of 2018, within the fiscal budget year 2018/19. The subsequent design of Phase II will also occur in fiscal year 2018/19 with construction activity anticipated in fiscal year 2019/20.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>COUNCIL OPTIONS:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Approve the Design Services Proposal for RH2 Engineering, Inc.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Deny the Design Services Proposal for RH2 Engineering, Inc., revise the scope and reissue proposal solicitation.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Deny the Design Services Proposal for RH2 Engineering, Inc. and postpone the project.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>FINANCIAL IMPACTS:</p>

<p>The 2017-2018 Fiscal Year Capital Outlay Adopted Budget allocates $3,406,000 for Water Fund Capital Outlay. Of this amount, staff originally projected $50,000 towards design of the initial phase of the anticipated Stewart Lennox Distribution Improvements. However, after further identifying project challenges, it was determined that an alternatives analysis was warranted and staff retained RH2 to perform that work for approximately $3,500.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The results of the alternatives analysis revealed additional fees would be needed to adequately design the proposed Phase 1. It has been determined that roughly $77,000 will be needed to complete both the alternatives analysis and the Phase 1 design. The additional $27,000 design fee allocation is available within the capital budget for the Pelican City Booster Phase III Project.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Council Option 1 will utilize funds available for this project.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Council Option 2 may utilize funds available for this project pending subsequent Council approval.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Council Option 3 would not utilize funds available for this project.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION:</p>

<p>Staff recommends approving Council Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>RECOMMENDED MOTIONS:</p>

<p>Move to Approve Option 1; Authorizing Staff to Enter into a Design Services Contract with RH2 Engineering, Inc. for the Stewart Lenox Water System Improvements Project Phase I in the Not-to-Exceed Amount of $73,155.</p>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Feb 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>

<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.5 </span>CONSTRUCTION SERVICES CONTRACT WITH BLACKLINE, INC. FOR THE 2017/18 MICROSURFACING &amp; OREGON AVENUE BIKE LANE PROJECTS IN AN AMOUNT NOT-TO-EXCEED $468,092.86</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL: Should the City execute a construction services contract with Blackline, Inc. in the not-to-exceed amount of $468,092.86 for construction of the 2017/18 Microsurfacing and Oregon Avenue Bike Lane Project?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Streets Division has identified several roadways within the City that are in need of surface restoration improvements. In 2017, staff introduced an additional treatment alternative to their surface restoration options. Microsurfacing is a blend of quick setting asphalt emulsion, water, high quality aggregate, and additives that has zero emissions, is applied cold, and can be ready for traffic in less than one hour. The treatment provides similar benefits as a traditional chip seal application, but limits inconvenience to the motoring public, is more conducive to bicycle traffic, and presents a more aesthetic appearance to the roadway system.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Last summer the City tested the Microsurfacing product within the south suburb region and areas around the Shasta Way/Washburn Way intersection. The test proved to be successful and staff proceeding with a second year of application for the summer of 2018. The areas to be treated generally fall within the President streets, Biehn Street, the corridor along Oregon Avenue and 9th Street, and several adjacent areas immediately west of this corridor. The zones scheduled to be treated are further identified on the attached exhibit.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Packaged with the Microsurfacing project is the Oregon Avenue Separated Bike Lane. This project will include a separated two-way bike lane along the westerly and southerly side of Oregon Avenue and 9th Street, between Biehn Street and Main Street. The project will provide a safe corridor for bicyclists traveling in the area. The project includes installation of candlestick style delineators as well as bike lane and pedestrian specific striping and signage along the route.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>This segment of the bike lane is anticipated to be phase one of an ultimate project that will connect a designated bicycle route between Moore Park and Downtown. Funding for the bike lane is being provided through a donation by the Sky Lakes Medical Center Foundation.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>A formal request for construction bids was publicly advertised in the Herald and News and the Daily Journal of Commerce. A non-mandatory pre-bid meeting was held on January 30, 2018 where bidders had the opportunity to discuss the project with staff. Bids were received from four companies on February 8, 2018. The bidders and their prices are summarized below. It should be noted that these prices reflect acceptance of the Base Bids + Bid Alternates 2 &amp; 3 only. The City will not be constructing alternates 1 or 4 at this time.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Engineers Estimate (Published) $ 460,000 - $ 490,000</p>

<ol start="5">
	<li>International, Inc. $ 475,626</li>
</ol>

<ol start="101">
	<li value="2147483647">Inc. $ 468,093</li>
	<li value="1">Slurry Seal, Inc. $ 504,093</li>
</ol>

<p>California Pavement Maintenance Co. $ 559,615</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>COUNCIL OPTIONS:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Approve a contract with Blackline, Inc. in an amount not-to-exceed $468,092.86 and authorize an additional not-to-exceed contingency allowance of $46,809.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reject a contract with Blackline, Inc., modify the project scope and rebid the project.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reject a contract with Blackline, Inc. and postpone the project.</p>

	<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>FINANCIAL IMPACTS:</p>

<p>Design Phase and Bid Phase hard cost expenditures are anticipated to total approximately $37,000. Staff anticipates an additional hard cost allowance of $14,000 for construction inspection and materials testing during construction. The total anticipated hard cost project expenditure equals $566,400, including a 10% construction contingency allowance if necessary. Refer to the attached Budget Analysis Form for further detail. It should be noted that the charges for internal staff time are not included in the overall hard cost budget as these services are provided through the General Fund.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Funds for this project are available through both the City’s FY 2017/18 Adopted Budget in the Street Division Capital Outlay Fund plus a Sky Lakes Medical Center Foundation donation. A $350,000 allowance from the Streets Capital Fund was allocated for the 2017/18 Microsurfacing Project. An additional $10,000 is available from the crack seal program. Design and construction costs for the Oregon Avenue Bike Lane Project are covered through a $209,000 donation received from the Sky Lakes Medical Center Foundation.</p>

	</li>

<input name="agenda-item-unique" type="hidden" value="AW8VS26B6182">
<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Feb 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.6 </span>AUTHORIZATION TO COMMIT $5,000 AS CITY MATCH FOR TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANT AWARD FOR BUILDABLE LANDS INVENTORY AND INDUSTRIAL LANDS ASSESSMENT</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL: Whether to commit $5,000 in City funding towards the completion a Buildable Lands Inventory and Industrial Lands Assessment?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>At the October 16, 2017 City Council meeting, Council supported a resolution seeking funding through the Oregon Department of Land Conservation and Development’s (DLCD) Technical Assistance Grant Program to Complete a Buildable Lands Inventory and Industrial Lands Assessment.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Staff was informed by DLCD of a tentative $40,000 grant award pending the City’s ability to provide $5,000 in matching funds. Though the Technical Assistance Grant Program does not require a local match, other awarded and high scoring program applicants offered cash contributions.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>If funded, the Residential Buildable Lands Inventory would include an assessment of available residential lands compared to expected twenty-year needs and determine if any excess land could be converted to industrial use. The Industrial Lands Assessment would evaluate all industrial sites within the Urban Growth Boundary (UGB) for developability with consideration given for constraints such as: access to and cost of infrastructure; topography; wetlands; and any other factors that could limit, prevent, or otherwise constrain development potential. The assessment would include recommendations for the City and partners to prepare identified industrial sites for future development.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>As the completed 2009 Economic Opportunities Analysis (EOA) identified the lack of and need for a single large-lot industrial site, the Industrial Lands Assessment will include studies of sites both inside and outside the UGB to identify sites to meet the large-lot need. While not part of this grant project, the Industrial Lands Assessment would provide recommendations to rezone an appropriate site within the current UGB and/or utilize a future UGB amendment to bring a site into the UGB for large-lot industrial purposes.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>COUNCIL OPTIONS:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Approve a $5,000 City match contribution to support the completion of a Buildable Lands Inventory and Industrial Lands Assessment</li>
	<li>Decline to act at this time</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>FINANCIAL IMPACT:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>The total project cost is estimated at $45,000 with $40,000 provided through grant funding and $5,000 from local sources. If approved, funds would be drawn from the Economic Development Property Fund which is expected to have a small surplus at the end of the 2017-2018 Fiscal Year. Depending on when the City receives its grant reimbursement request, funds may also be expended in the Fiscal Year 2018-2019 Budget. Staff will monitor the funds and determine if a supplemental budget request is necessary. If approved the City will be able to leverage $5,000 to obtain $40,000 in State funds.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>STAFF’S RECOMMENDED ACTION:</p>

<ul>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Feb 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.7 </span>AUTHORIZE STAFF TO ACCEPT GRANT FUNDING THROUGH THE CASCADE HEALTH ALLIANCE (CHA) ANNUAL GRANT PROGRAM</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL: Should the Parks Department accept a grant reward from Cascade Health Alliance in the amount of $50,000?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND:</p>

<p>Cascade Health Alliance (CHA) accepted grant application proposals for their annual grant cycle December 1, 2017. The intent of the program is to help local community partners address social determinants of health and increase local health ranking metrics. The Parks Department was successfully selected as a recipient for $50,000 to begin the fund-raising initiative towards the purchase and install of a playground structure at Mills-Kiwanis Park detailed in our 2018/2019 Capital Improvement Plan.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Mills-Kiwanis Park is located in an area with one of the largest population of children per capita within the City. The park has been without a playground structure for 20 years. The current play equipment consists of one swing set. Studies provide significant information about the importance of safe outdoor play areas for children. These play areas provide rich opportunities for children to grow, learn, and develop. We plan to accept grant funding opportunities toward the purchase and install of a two playground structures for Mills-Kiwanis Park to address this need. One structure will be designed for children between the ages of 2 and 5. And the other structure will be designed for children between the ages of 5 and 12.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>COUNCIL OPTIONS:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Authorize staff to accept grant funding through Cascade Health Alliance.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Decline authorization to accept grant funding through Cascade Health Alliance.</p>

	<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>FINANCIAL IMPACTS:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Staff intends to allocate all funds towards matching requirements for additional grant application opportunities. There is no required financial match for this grant.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>STAFF’S RECOMMENDED ACTION:</p>

<p>Council Approve Option 1; Authorizing staff to accept grant funding through Cascade Health Alliance.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>DOCUMENTS ATTACHED:</p>

<p>Cascade Health Alliance Agreement Letter</p>

<p>Cascade Health Alliance Grant Agreement</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>REPORT SENT TO: Cascade Health Alliance</p>
</div>

<h2>Agenda Item Details</h2>
<div class="leftcol">Meeting</div>
<div class="rightcol">Feb 20, 2018 - AGENDA FOR COUNCIL MEETING</div>
<div class="leftcol">Category</div>
<div class="rightcol"><span class="agendanumber">7. </span>LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS</div>
<div class="leftcol">Subject</div>
<div class="rightcol" id="ai-name"><span class="agendanumber">7.8 </span>SERVICES CONTRACT WITH JOE SLAUGHTER, AICP FOR ONGOING PLANNING SERVICES IN SUPPORT OF THE CITY'S DEVELOPMENT SERVICES DIVISION</div>
<div class="leftcol">Type</div>
<div class="rightcol">Action</div>
<br><br>
<div class="bothcols" key="publicbody"><p>ISSUE BEFORE COUNCIL: Should the City retain the services of Joe Slaughter, AICP, to support the ongoing planning needs of the Development Services Division?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>SUMMARY AND BACKGROUND:</p>

<p>On December 20, 2017, the City’s Planning Manager resigned from his position in the Development Services Division effective January 5, 2018. Since that time, Staff has analyzed opportunities to replace the position utilizing both internal resources and private consultant support. It was determined that the Management Assistant to the City Manager, Joe Wall, would fill the role as interim Planning Manager for the next 12 months. Mr. Wall is educated in the field of Land Use Planning and has expressed a desire to accept this opportunity and advance his experience in the Planning Department. Although Mr. Wall has the education background with planning services, he currently has a limited depth of work experience in many aspects of the position. It is important to note that in addition to his role as interim Planning Manager, Mr. Wall will also be continuing many of the duties that he currently addresses as Management Assistant to the City Manager.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>To support Mr. Wall during his first year as Planning Manager, Staff has identified an opportunity to retain the services of private sector planning consultant, Joe Slaughter. Mr. Slaughter was previously employed by the City of Klamath Falls as a Senior Planner for seven years. In 2013, Mr. Slaughter relocated to the Rogue Valley where he has gained further experience working with other local Governments in Southern Oregon as well as private sector clients. He is currently self-employed, offering his land use planning and development services to both private developers and public agencies.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Staff has negotiated an agreement with Mr. Slaughter to provide ongoing planning assistance for a flat rate fee of $6,067 per month for 87 hours of service. Mr. Slaughter will work remotely, utilizing telephone communication and computer software that interfaces with the City’s technology systems. The Agreement also anticipates two trips per month to the Klamath Falls offices where staff will have the opportunity to interact in person. The Agreement does include provisions for additional service hours and travel, if deemed necessary.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The professional services relationship is being proposed for a twelve-month duration. During that time, staff will have the ability to evaluate options for the long-term vision and needs of related services provided by the Division, as well as utilize the expertise and job experience that Mr. Slaughter has to offer.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>COUNCIL OPTIONS:</p>

<ol>
	<li>
	<p>Approve a Contract with Joe Slaughter, AICP, to provide professional planning consultant services for a 12-month duration at a fixed fee amount of $6,067 per month for 87 hours of service. Services beyond the fixed basis to be provided per the terms of the attached Contract.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p>Reject a Contract with Joe Slaughter, AICP, and advise staff how to proceed with providing planning services.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>FINANCIAL IMPACT:</p>

<p>The impact of this contract is limited as it will be funded from the funds currently budgeted for the Planning Manager position. During the limited duration of the Contract, City staff will be analyzing the most cost-effective way to provide these services.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>STAFF’S RECOMMENDATION:</p>

<p>Staff recommends approving Council Option 1.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>RECOMMENDED MOTION:</p>

<p>Move to Approve Option 1; Authorizing Staff to enter into a Contract with Joe Slaughter, AICP, to provide professional planning consultant services for a 12-month duration at a fixed fee amount of $6,067 per month for 87 hours of service. Services beyond the fixed basis to be provided per the terms of the attached Contract.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>DOCUMENT ATTACHED:</p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p>Draft Contract</p>

	<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p>REPORT SENT TO:</p>

<p>Joe Slaughter, AICP</p>

<p>280 Stanford Avenue</p>

<p>Medford, OR 97504</p>
</div>
